PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CADMAN; CAMERON; CROSS; DRUMMOND; HAWKER; ROCHER
PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Donald Cameron,Mr Cross,Mr Drummond,Mr Hawker and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys,Mr Kent,Mr Mildren and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of the proposed plant breeder's rights legislation. The reasons are as follows:
(1) We believe it will restrict free growing and exchange or sale of non- chemically treated seeds.
(2) We believe it will cause a decline in the genetic diversity of plants as evidenced in Europe following implementation of similar legislation there.
(3) We believe that prolonged public debate is necessary as is a referendum before a final decision is made.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take positive action as soon as possible to arrest the implementation of such legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Robert Brown and Mr Hand.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a referendum rejected the introduction of territorial government or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to territorial or local government
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of territorial or local government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron and Mr Dobie.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Ronald Edwards.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the Australian Capital Territory Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law
the power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Groom and Mr Newman.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedom;
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment condusive to the development, including moral development of their children.
Deny to parents their rights to have their children enjoy single-sex sporting activities e.g., boys cricket team, boys football team, etc.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Kelly and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Curfew
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show:

That the potential noise hazard to residents of Sandgate, Shorncliffe, Brighton , and Nudgee Beach (including 4,000 aged people), will become intolerable when the new Brisbane Airport is operative in 1987, if protective action is not taken .
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will, when the redevelopment of the Brisbane Airport becomes operative, ensure that
(i) no jet aircraft use the 32'14' crosswind runway;
(ii) the Department maintain the curfew on the runway from 10 p.m. to 6 a.m.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Rebate List: Infertility Treatments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:

That at present, certain infertility treatments including; hormonal drugs, procedures and laboratory services, are not covered by any health insurance due to non-itemisation on the Commonwealth rebate list. The psychological and emotional stress of infertility is therefore increased by the added financial stress.

Your petitioners therefore pray, that the Parliament will view our plight to create life with sympathy, by recognising our needs, and taking action to include the abovementioned items on the Commonwealth rebate list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we, loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our wish to have the traditional place of Her Majesty the Queen as Head of State retained in our national and constitutional and democratic affairs and institutions, and also strongly advocate the retention of our present Australian Flag, standing for historic and loyal links with the United Kingdom, the nation which founded our Australian way of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Library of Australia: Child Care Facilities
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully believing that:

There is demonstrated evidence of a need for child care facilities by staff, users, and potential users of the National Library of Australia and surrounding buildings in Parkes, Australian Capital Territory;
There are at present no such existing facilities;
Provision has already been made for inclusion of the facilities in planned extensions to the Library,

Humbly petition that your Honourable House reverse the decision by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment disallowing provision for child care facilities in the extensions to the National Library of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Victor Harbor to Adelaide Railway Line
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the railway line and train-passenger service remain in service.
1. that the railway line remain maintained
2. that the passenger service include return trips, and
3. that the services become more frequent.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Railway Line between Victor Harbor and Adelaide remains.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Mr Porter-I raise a point of order relating to the petition lodged by me. That petition, which has some 4,730 signatures, expresses an interest in wanting to maintain the Victor Harbor to Adelaide railway line. Perhaps some indication ought to be given as to the support that petitions have. I know that this matter was considered some time ago. I wonder whether it has been considered more recently. The Standing Orders--

Mr SPEAKER-Order! The honourable member has made his point of order. I remind him that the practice that is followed now is different to the practice that was followed when I first became a member of Parliament. We are following the practice adopted by the House. If the House wishes to change that practice the action must come from the House itself.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. The Hawke Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements, and
2. The Government's proposed assets test legislation, presently under re- examination, is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Government to:
1. Totally abandon its proposed assets test legislation.
2. Either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter, and
3. Following the report of such a wide enquiry, institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of Medicare has not resulted in a cheaper, fairer system of health care as promised by the Federal Government.
Rather, it is an expensive, bureaucratic scheme, depersonalising medical services and conducive to medical mediocrity.
While recognising the responsibility which exists to assist those in need, we humbly request the Government to review this system which moves towards the nationalisation of Australian medicine.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cross,Mrs Darling and Mr Moore.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:
Last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
Alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
Alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
Alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that-

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled: The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectively showeth that :
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned electors of the Division of Ballarat, request that the Australian Government:
1. Recognise the apolitical nature of the International Committee of the Red Cross in its humanitarian work to people regardless of race, nationality, creed, sex or culture.

2. Recognise the ICRC reports that their activities on the main island of East Timor have been suspended owing to the refusal of the Indonesian authorities to grant their delegates access to all villages requiring assistance.

3. Recognise the breach of the internationally accepted Geneva Convention of 1949, which states that the occupying power ''shall agree to relief actions on behalf of the population and facilitate them by all means at its disposal by authorising in particular the relief activities of the Protecting Power, the neutral state, and the ICRC, or any other humanitarian body''. At present the ICRC is confined to visits to the island of Atauro.

4. Approach the Indonesian Government to give assurances which will allow the ICRC to extend its humanitarian work of distribution of food, provision of medical assistance, and visitation of prisons throughout the whole of East Timor .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(2) congratulates Film Australia, the Director Gil Brealey, and the cast of the film 'Annie's Coming Out', as an outstanding contribution to world cinema, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move :

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) deplores the decision of the Standing Committee on Spoken English of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to abandon the English language in favour of 'Femtalk', and

(b) the man-on-the land remains the man- on-the-land;
(c) statesmen remains statesmen;
(d) cattlemen remain cattlemen, and
(e) females remain feminine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that up to the week ending 4 May 1984 the number of applications received under the first home owners scheme were, for Australia, 69 807 and for Western Australia, 10 454;
(2) further notes that the number of inquiries received were, for Australia, 479 775 and for Western Australia, 79 907, and
(3) recognises that Federal Government initiatives have had a substantial impact on recovery in the housing industry.
The motion will be seconded by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Gear).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) confirms its understanding that the main thrust of ALP policy on immigration is family reunion;
(2) recognises that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has confirmed the policy, and
(3) calls on the Government to implement its policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move, and my colleague the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) shall second:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes the estimate of the Federation of College Academics that during the years 1976 to 1983 1000 teaching positions disappeared in the CAE sector, and with them many times that number of possible student places, and
(2) condemns the previous Government's neglect of this important sector of the education system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that the former President of the ACTU, the Prime Minister, possesses considerable experience in the matter of understanding and influencing the trade union movement, and
(2) expresses disappointment that, despite his background, the Prime Minister has not lifted a finger to force an end to the costly 14 week old strike at the new Parliament House site.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON BUSINESS AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Joint Standing Committee, to be known as the Joint Standing Committee for Business Affairs, be appointed:
(a) to review-
(i) Commonwealth legislation with a view to removing
(A) provisions (including provisions that require information to be furnished to a person) that impose or may impose unnecessary burdens on business and on industry, and
(B) unnecessary or out-of-date provisions;

(ii) the administrative practices of Commonwealth Departments and instrumentalities, so far as those practices have an effect upon the operations of business and industry, with a view to ensuring that those practices do not impose unnecessary burdens and demands on business and on industry;

(iii) such laws and practices with a view to ensuring that, in respect of business and industry in Australia, they comply with international obligations assumed by Australia, including through the United Nations, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the International Labor Organisation;

(iv) suggestions for the improvement of Commonwealth laws and practices in relation to activities of business and industry, whether made by business and industry, representative bodies or otherwise, and
(v) reports of commissions and other inquiries with a view to making recommendations for the enactment of laws that may be made by the Parliament concerning business and industry in Australia, and
(b) to recommend, in relation to the activities of business and industry, appropriate laws that may be made by the Parliament and that may have effect uniformly throughout Australia.

(2) That the committee, for the purpose of performing its functions, may consider any proposed law or other document of information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the House.

(3) That the committee consist of 9 Members, 3 Members of the House of Represenatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(4) That further details in respect of the operation of the committee be the subject of a subsequent resolution.
(5) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that-
(a) union picketing of the new Parliament House site is preventing contractors from recovering valuable and costly equipment to use elsewhere, and
(b) as a result of this picketing many of the small contractors are suffering great financial difficulties;
(2) deplores the stranglehold applied by the pickets which again shows that under the Government unions are outside and above the law, and
(3) calls on the Government to take immediate action to see that the millions of dollars of stranded equipment is removed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House deplores the Government's total lack of responsibility evidenced by its announced intention to cut taxation when the total public sector debts, at local, state and federal levels, is presently $76 billion and growing daily which is 41.5% of Gross Domestic Product, representing a cost of $ 20,000 to a family with 2 children, and which places a burden of $6 billion in interest per year on all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House urges the Prime Minister to use his influence to bring to an immediate end the strike that has paralysed Broken Hill, but under terms and conditions that are no more generous than that provided by the ALP/ACTU accord on prices and incomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes the statement by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, on 7 March 1984, that there is lessening interest in family reunion from Europe and the UK;
(2) endorses the information from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that there is an 18 per cent increase in applications for family reunion from Europe and the UK, and
(3) calls on the Minister to substantiate his claims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that-

(2) calls on the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to take the matter up with the airlines in order to rectify this anomaly.

The previous rule stopped at three. I will allow the honourable member to give his notice, but I ask him and other honourable members to take note of that precedent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not test the previous ruling, Mr Speaker, I assure you. I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) considers that Australia's migration program is being administered by decisions that reflect the personal political attitude of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs;
(2) condemns the Minister for his-
(a) secrecy in regard to details of the program;
(b) failure to support his claim that there is lessening interest in family reunion from Europe and the UK;
(c) personal intervention to ensure unequal treatment of migrants, and
(d) belligerence in the conduct of his office, and
(3) calls on the Prime Minister to remove the Minister from the immigration portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the actions of the fascists of the left in denigrating and defaming members of the Opposition who dare to express a view on immigration policy which is contrary to the views of the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

Mr Hollis-Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I would like to know whether the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) was referring to members of the Australian Labor Party when he used the term 'fascist'. If he did, I ask that that term be withdrawn because I find it offensive for any honourable member of this House to be called a fascist.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will examine the notice of motion. The term was used in the generality. It was not really directed at any honourable member of Parliament. I will examine it to see whether the import of the term is unparliamentary.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 4]

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
DIVIDEND RECOUPMENT TAX BILL 1983 [No. 2] ]
Debate resumed from 9 May, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the debate on this Bill resumes, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 [No. 2].

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I entered this House in 1980. When I look back over my files and over the records of speeches, it seems that this House has spent an inordinate amount of time discussing the topic of retrospective taxation. It is very difficult when one is speaking on legislation such as the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and the cognate Bill to bring new points into the debate. However, what I aim to do, first of all, is take issue with some of the points that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) raised in his speech on these Bills. I was surprised by many of his comments. He began his speech by talking about his legislation-that is the legislation of the previous Government-and he claimed that that legislation had brought an end to tax avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: At the same time as he argues that, members of the Opposition will refuse to support retrospectivity. I cannot understand the logic of that argument. On the one hand they say, yes, they agree with the principle of moving in against tax avoidance; they say tax avoidance is dead. Yet, this legislation is not prospective at all; it is retrospective. It is to move in on the period when tax avoidance was rife. Everyone in this House knows that in the 1970s tax avoidance was rife. That is the whole aim of this legislation. It is not to look into the future but only to look into the past, to the areas in which it is acknowledged by everyone that there was tax avoidance.

Yet, at the same time as the honourable member for Bennelong claims that tax avoidance has been brought to an end, we have people like the Peter Clynes of this world who have spent a large proportion of their lives making money from schemes which are designed to avoid tax and outmanoeuvre the Australian Taxation Office. It is true that at the moment Mr Clyne is awaiting trial on a charge of breaking Reserve Bank foreign exchange regulations. In one of his handbooks he said:
It takes an hour to think up a new loophole, lurk or scheme. It takes the enemy -
the Taxation Office or the Government-
four or five years to understand what we are up to and devise an antidote.

So that is the whole reason why we need retrospectivity. There is no way that one can efficiently and effectively fight tax avoidance unless the people who are practising these schemes know that there is a threat and the threat has to be that they have to pay up what they should have paid up and what they have illegally avoided paying. Without that, this House can legislate till the cows come home and the measures will not be effective.
I acknowledge that the previous Government does have a good record in the area of moving in on tax avoidance and tax evasion schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very reluctantly though.

—The comment has been made that it was reluctant in its support for that. That is true. Very many members of the then Government did not vote in support of such legislation. The then Government brought in many pieces of legislation to deal with tax avoidance and tax evaders and I congratulate it on that. However, it was only in 1982 that it recognised the issue of retrospectivity. It was only then, with the assistance of the then Opposition, that the previous Government got that legislation through this House. So the previous Government recognised the problem after the horse had bolted. It decided that it would close the stable gate but the horse had already bolted. The real problem with this legislation is that if one is to be fair dinkum it has to be retrospective.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is serious about smashing tax evasion and avoidance and that is why we make clear statements about our intentions in relation to tax avoidance and retrospectivity. This Government has not just made many statements; there has been action. In the May statement last year we undertook to investigate the tax avoidance penalties of that sacred cow, lump sum superannuation schemes. Last September the prescribed payments scheme was introduced and has been a considerable success as a tax avoidance deterrent. Its success can be gauged by the 45,000 requests for new tax file numbers, a quarter of which had never previously been lodged on income tax returns. Last week we reintroduced the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1984 No.2 which deals with the so-called cherry-picker schemes. We have foreshadowed an increase in penalties for tax avoidance. Now, again, we attempt to strengthen the unpaid company tax legislation. So I think that the Government stands on its record. We have a mandate for the action we are undertaking. The only trouble is that we are suffering frustrations because the Opposition is not fair dinkum about its claims to move in on tax avoidance and tax evasion schemes.

The second issue I would like to take up with the honourable member for Bennelong is in respect of the points he made in reference to the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). He quoted the Minister for Finance as saying that the tax avoidance is over and is not a problem. I query that. I sat and listened. I know that the honourable member for Bennelong is a respected member of this House, so I went to seek the information on which he had made his judgment. I could find no evidence at all. In fact, what I found is an answer to a question asked by the honourable member for Bennelong on 1 May in this House. I will quote sections of that answer and then I would like honourable members from both sides of the House to ask themselves: Is this the answer of a member of this House who believes tax avoidance no longer exists?

TALK.START.PARA: —Go to the speech to the Society of Accountants.

—The interjection was that the speech was to the Australian Society of Accountants. I acknowledge that. In reply the Minister for Finance made reference to that and clarified the point. I will take the time to read his response so that the accuracy of his account of the situation can be recorded in this House and honourable members can make their own assessment of the position of the Minister for Finance. I quote from a reply to a question on 1 May when the Minister spoke about the record of this Government and said that when he was the Minister in charge of taxation:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I indicated that whenever a blatantly artificial tax avoidance scheme was identified we would legislate retrospectively to close off that scheme from the date of its first known operation.
He then mentioned tax avoidance and said:

The reason why that policy has not been capable of full implementation is that the Liberal Party in the Senate continues time and again to protect the tax dodgers. Members of that Party have refused to pass the legislation which we have put up on a number of occasions in order to ensure that these tax avoidance schemes are ended and that no new schemes will grow up in the future. What I was saying on that occasion--
that is, to the Society of Accountants--

was that notwithstanding the attitude of the Liberal Party and the National Party in the Senate and their gutlessness in the face of the tax avoidance industry, the professions now recognise that the game is up. However, we are faced with a dreadful legacy--
Opposition members should listen to this because they should understand that this is the implication of their actions--

as a result of the neglect of the former Government. As the Auditor-General has revealed, something like $3 billion is outstanding as a result of the dreadful experience of tax avoidance in this country.
I ask honourable members of this House: Is that the response to a question of a Minister who believes that there is nothing further he can do in the areas of tax avoidance and tax evasion?

TALK.START.PARA: —He is acknowledging that tax avoidance is dead. It is absolutely clear.
—The honourable member is taking that out of context.
—No, you are trying to redefine--
—Order!
—the same way as you are trying to redefine income.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Hume.
—Mr Speaker--
—The honourable member has had an experience of answering back after a warning before.

—What the Minister for Finance was saying is that there is a new awareness and a new consciousness in the community of the problems of tax avoidance and evasion and there is no doubt that people who previously practised these schemes are now thinking about it. The only reason they think twice about it is that they know that the policy of this Government is retrospectivity. They know they can escape while members of the Opposition continue to block that legislation. However, one day they know that we will have control of the Senate and this legislation will get through, or that maybe one day members of the Opposition will come to their senses and realise their responsibilities in this area. One can only hope.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point I want to raise relates to a reference that the honourable member for Bennelong made in his response to the effects of tax avoidance on employment. The honourable member for Bennelong pleaded the case of small business. I think this Government recognises the problems that small business had under the previous Government. It has been very sympathetic to the situation of small businesses in this community. But we are not sympathetic to people who are not paying the tax that is rightly due to revenue.

This legislation is particularly generous in that it has allowed a time to pay provision under which personal tax to be recouped can be paid, free of late payment penalty, by instalments over a 12-month period. Also, there has been no evidence that existing legislation has caused unemployment in companies, despite the predictions that this would occur when the Opposition legislation was introduced. Companies would generally be sold as going concerns and, if that is the case, there would be no or minimal loss of jobs. I have found, through dealing with some companies involved in this area, that banks and other financial institutions have been lending money to meet tax debts on security of businesses that have been expanded as a result of the erosion and avoidance of tax liabilities. These people cannot have it both ways.

I wish to quote to the House from a case that came up in the Melbourne courts recently, the case of Gasbourne Pty Ltd and others. It involved the winding up of petitions against 11 bottom of the harbour companies. There is an outline of the explanation of the case. A section of the judgment states:
A net sum of approximately $50,000 had therefore been saved and there was the additional bonus that such portion of the current year profits as would have been paid to the Joneses--
The claimants in this case--

in the form of dividends was converted into capital and was thus not liable to the payment of income tax. Mr. Jones freely conceded that the transaction was a very attractive one from his point of view and he indicated that it remained attractive to this day despite the passage of the 1982 Act having regard to the many years' interest-free use of relevant moneys and the income tax saving involved.

These people freely admit that they had been getting benefits over a period from not paying the tax that was due to revenue. Yet members of the Opposition say that these are the sorts of people who should be protected. They say: 'These are the people who do not need to pay that tax. Let us shelter them'. That is what they are trying to do. They must remember that while they do that the money has to come from somewhere; other people have to pay that debt. Who has to pay? It is the wage and salary earners who continue to pay that amount of money.

The former Treasurer also said that this legislation is penal in character. I take issue with that. No penalties or additional taxes are imposed, as could well have been the case. The Bill simply seeks to recover tax that ought to have been paid years ago when the profits were stripped from the company. In particular, the legislation does not impose any additional amount to compensate for the fact that repayment of escaped tax will be in today's money values and not in the money values of the years when the tax should have been paid. So these people are getting enormous benefits. Even if they pay the tax due in today's terms, they have had the benefit of that money over a period of years and have gained financial benefit from it. There is no denying that. So even if they pay up they will still be better off. They are the sorts of people that members of the Opposition are protecting. They are the sorts of people who are not paying what they should fairly pay, and it is the pay as you earn taxpayers of Australia who have to compensate for that. Members of the Government believe that that is an inequitable situation and should not continue.

Who is the Opposition protecting? Let me tell all members of the House, who have not been able to work through the Opposition's language on the sanctity of individual freedom, the sorts of arguments they use: 'The individual has a right to operate within the letter of the law providing that fraudulent practices are not engaged in. The public has a right to expect that the government it elected will make every attempt to ensure that all pay tax according to their ability to pay, and that it will distribute that revenue for the benefit of the public'.

One would think that that is a legitimate aim but members of the Opposition obviously claim that they are in this House to protect people who have benefited unjustly over a period of years. Remember that this is not prospective legislation; it is only retrospective. It is only to make people pay the contribution from which they have gained benefit over a number of years. So what I think members of the Opposition mean by individual freedom is that those who have got the benefits, those who are wealthy, get wealthier, and conversely, those who are poor get poorer. The people who have been paying their tax legitimately over those eight years continue to pay more while the people who have avoided paying tax continue to benefit from that money. This Government will not stand for that. What the Opposition calls initiative, the Commissioner of Taxation and the courts call tax evasion. What the Opposition calls fair reward, the Commissioner of Taxation calls tax avoidance.

It is crucial that so called initiatives and fair rewards which hide beneath the cloak of individual freedom are exposed for what they are. Quite clearly they are methods of cheating ordinary Australians of tax revenue and of goods and services. The House must understand that that is clearly the implication of the Opposition refusing to pass these retrospective Bills. This Government has no illusion that tax avoidance and evasion stops with the cash economy or with the schemes devised by the Clynes and the Mahers of this world or the bottom of the harbour type of variations. This Government will be vigilant in its task of smashing tax avoidance. It is time that the Opposition supported this principle and permitted the Government to get on with the program for which it has a mandate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I commence by asking after the health of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). Is he well? Is he in good voice? We do not see him in the House any more when we are debating tax measures, particularly when the tax measures before the House deal with avoidance or evasion. Let us remind ourselves that the Minister has first hand knowledge of tax avoidance. He should be able to give this House the benefit of that knowledge and of his great insight into the social issues that tax avoidance and evasion raise. He has had his affairs detailed, somewhat embarrassingly, by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and has not ventured back into the House to debate avoidance or evasion legislation since then. Why is he not back here? He is not back here for two reasons: First, he is afraid to come back here when avoidance or evasion measures are before the House and, secondly, no doubt he has been given his orders by that very able tactician , the Leader of the House (Mr Young), and has been told to stay out. However, I do hope that he summons up his courage and comes back because we would all like to hear his contribution on the subject of avoidance and evasion. Perhaps he could give us a few hints on new fields of avoidance on which we can concentrate our attention in the future. He is, after all, the leading practical expert in these matters on the Government benches, so far as we presently know.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before the House seeks to amend the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982 and the allied measure passed with that Act. The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act, introduced and passed by the Fraser Government in 1982, has recently been upheld in all respects, by the High Court of Australia save for one minor procedural matter. If one wants to get a clear understanding of what that measure sought to do, there is no better way of understanding such a complex measure than going to the judgment of the High Court and to the joint judgment of the Chief Justice and Justices Wilson, Deane and Dawson, which in the opening paragraph, describes the Act in these terms:
. . . legislation aimed at the collection of moneys found to be irrecoverable by way of company tax from companies which were stripped--
I emphasise the word 'stripped'--
of their assets, including profits before tax and any assets representing provisions for tax, from which payment of the tax might otherwise have been made or recovered.
I emphasise again the word 'stripped'. The judgment went on:

Such companies may conveniently be referred to as 'target companies'. The legislation seeks to impose liability upon the vendors of shares where the sale of the shares was followed by a stripping operation and upon those who promoted the scheme of which the sale formed part.

There we have it encapsulated in a few words. The emphasis clearly in the minds of the justices of the High Court was on stripping operations. The importance of that fact lies in this legislation. Under the Bill before the House the stripping element is to be removed. I shall return to that later.

A great deal is said about tax avoidance. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), attacked anyone, as I understood her, who says that retrospective laws are not good for the purposes of dealing with avoidance or evasion. Those who sought to oppose retrospective laws have been categorised by this Government as supporters of the tax avoidance industry. Indeed there was , until his recent banishment from the House, when these matters came before the House, no more virulent a critic than the Minister for Finance.

Certainty of the law is not just a trite statement. It is an essential need in civilised society. It is essential that people know what the law is and how it affects their actions and their lives. There is a basic presumption in our legal system that actions within the law should not be struck down; that is, struck down by legislation which reaches back from the present to the past. It is, of course, always open to the legislature to pass retrospective laws, but retrospective laws are generally regarded as unjust. This is not a sinister view of the world; it is an essential view of the world and of law.

Although we are talking about taxation measures, let us consider for a moment criminal law. Would anyone in this House think that it was a good principle that criminal law should be altered so as retrospectively to make criminal actions which when they took place were not criminal and to punish people by fines or imprisonment? Would that be just? Would that reflect community values? Would that be a course which should commonly be adopted? In the case of civil conduct, would it be wise, just, and in accordance with our view of the world, to change retrospectively contractual rights, to extinguish retrospectively rights under contracts, to set aside retrospectively contracts entered into at a time when the law was quite different? Would it be right to create by statute new civil rights of action to apply to past transactions or to impose new civil liabilities in relation to past transactions? Is that just? Is that the kind of legislation we should adopt? Is that the kind of approach we should have to law making?

What is the essential difference in relation to tax cases? There is in truth none. We are dealing with a civil obligation and a civil obligation imposed by statute. One need not approve, support or condone tax avoidance or tax evasion. Certainly, that is not part of the view that one needs to have to take as a general principle that laws should not have retrospective operation. None of us on this side are supporters of the tax avoidance or tax evasion industry, least of all the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). We oppose this legislation because it is basically unjust. The Government's counter to this can only be described as the big lie, and one in which, I regret to say, the honourable member for Canberra, who spoke previously, inadvertantly, I think , found herself mired. What does that amount to? It amounts to this: If one criticises measures of this kind one is to be condemned. If one opposes measures of this kind one is guilty of complicity and support. Opponents of measures of this kind are not merely wrong but dishonest it is said, as are those the Government claims to have raped the revenue. It would have been a far easier course for us to let these measures pass and to let the effects be felt by the Australian people. It would have been far easier for us to say that we were not concerned with the injustice of the measures; that we were not going to trouble ourselves about the injustice of the measures but would allow them to be passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you passed retrospective legislation in any event.

—I will come back to that. If the honourable member had read and understood that legislation he would know that the legislation was designed to fix on transactions involving evasion from which, at the end of the day, someone profited, whether knowingly or unknowingly. The second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when the legislation was originally introduced in November 1983 stated, in the context of the big lie:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes to remove one of the pre-conditions to liability for recoupment tax-the requirement that the company was by a stripping scheme rendered unable to pay its tax-which was inserted by the previous Government, it seems for presentational purposes.

It is the stripping arrangement which is central to the legislation which is now on the books; that is, deliberately stripping a company so that it was rendered unable to pay its tax. It is that element which the High Court of Australia fixed on in the opening passage in its judgment to which I have referred. It is that element which is to be taken out by the legislation now before the House. The rationale, in short, is destroyed. The innocent are to be treated in the same way as those who profited from evasion, whether or not they knew that evasion was involved. Those who have suffered commercial misadventure are to be treated in the same way.

I have no basis for saying-nobody here has any basis for saying-what the percentage would be, but we should not, as a general principle, pass laws which will affect some innocent people and affect them in a way that everyone would regard as wrong. All members of this House know of instances under the Fraser Government's 1982 legislation in which people have been caught by that legislation who were not intended to be caught by it. If the Minister for Finance were to venture into this House he would no doubt claim that when he was caught by that legislation he was perfectly innocent. If one assumes that he was perfectly innocent when he was caught-making, as I do, for the moment, that charitable assumption in his favour-it is perfectly obvious that many other people would be in the same position. Some months ago I drew the attention of the House to the case involving an electrician, as I recall, who found himself caught by the existing legislation when he was totally without fault, that is fault in the sense of complicity of any intention to evade.

We oppose, therefore-I put my own view on this very directly-legislation of this kind which takes out the stripping element. I remind the House precisely what that element is. Connected with the imposition of tax on aspects of past transactions going back to 1972 which attract the retrospective legislation which was passed by the Fraser Government is this element: That there was an arrangement or transaction which secured or achieved the result of the company being unable to pay its tax; in short, the stripping of a company. That element is to go out. It is that element which underpinned the introduction of the previous Government's legislation.

I wish to refer to one other specific matter; that is, the introduction of a specific provision to allow persons to be named. That provision is to be found in clause 6 of the Bill. It provides that the Commissioner of Taxation in his report, under section 14 of the Act, may draw attention to a person's failure to pay vendors or promoters recoupment tax. I say again that a failure to pay a tax may be due to a number of things. If the failure is not due to any evasion or any breach of the law, that kind of provision should not be introduced. It has been introduced for one purpose and for one purpose only-to place pressure on people to meet obligations whether or not they believe that they have a legitimate or fair defence to meeting them.

I should like to say one or two things about the previous Government's record. That record has been brought into question. The honourable member for Canberra said that there was more to be done. For the purpose of demonstrating the correctness of her argument she called on the services of Mr Clyne. Mr Clyne is a well known, self-confessed tax dodger. I have no support whatsoever for the kind of proposals that he puts forward. It is absurd, and it demonstrates the poverty of the argument, for anyone on the Government side to have to turn to advertisements of Mr Clyne for himself to find an argument to buttress this legislation. The previous Government outlawed about 28 specific schemes. It introduced the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980, making a wide variety of schemes and actions criminal. It introduced Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act in May 1981.

This Government has been in office since March last year. It came into power on a raft of promises, many of which have been discarded. One of its promises and one of its major criticisms related to tax avoidance and evasion. Anybody who listened to the speeches made by members of the Government when they were in Opposition would think that a vast number of things had to be done and that the law was generally deficient. What have we had? We have had from this Government no single general provision dealing with tax avoidance or evasion. Legislation has been introduced to deal retrospectively with certain matters but we have had no prospective legislation. The best possible indication of the adequacy of everything the previous Government did is the failure of this Government to introduce any prospective legislation. It says: 'We cannot find anything. We have been in office for over a year and we and our advisers are quite unable to find any deficiencies in the general legislation you have introduced'.

Despite that we will have an election campaign based on the big lie by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), perhaps supported by the Minister for Finance, deliberately obscuring the previous Government's focus on fraud, deliberately equating evasion with avoidance, deliberately condemning the innocent with the fraudulent and categorising any opposition as wrong, criminal and supportive of tax dodgers and tax crooks. Nobody was more virulent than was the Minister for Finance in slaying with his tongue the reputation of people outside this House. But we have not seen him in this House debating this matter. I very much fear that we will not be seeing him, but I hope he is still in good health. We look forward to his coming back one of these days to debate one of these measures. He , after all came to this House with impeccable left wing credentials. But what do we find of this champagne socialist, this poacher now pretending to be a gamekeeper? Why, he is a member of the same class that he reviled. He is a member of the same class that he so ruthlessly stigmatised from this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest to the honourable member for North Sydney that he remember standing orders 75 and 76.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I cannot recall for the moment what those interesting regulations deal with. The Minister's own affairs have been examined . We have had no answer from him as to his involvement in schemes of estate planning and interest capitalisation. The Dawkins scheme is, I hope, alive and well. We have seen no legislation to outlaw that scheme.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Standing order 76 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I have not averred an improper motive against the Minister; I have referred to his conduct. This gamekeeper, as he now is, will not come before the House for the purpose of dealing with these matters.
—Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -This legislation and the developments which have given rise to it probably represent one of the most appalling reflections on the genuineness of the present Opposition in connection with tax avoidance that could possibly be imagined. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), attempted to find some kind of contradiction between a statement which was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and a statement which the honourable member alleges was made by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) when he was addressing a conference in Sydney. The statement by the Prime Minister was to the effect that tax avoidance would be an issue at the next election. The alleged statement by the Minister for Finance in Sydney shortly after that was to the effect that as far as the Government is concerned tax avoidance is no longer an issue in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) in her contribution earlier today said that in answer to a question the Minister for Finance indicated that his claim that tax avoidance was no longer an issue in Australia was based on his knowledge of the fact that the tax avoidance industry was now sufficiently aware that this Government would not tolerate tax avoidance and tax evasion and would, if necessary, take retrospective action in order to make sure that those people who would otherwise be able to avoid tax paid tax and that as a result tax avoidance was no longer a political issue. Does that contradict the statement made by the Prime Minister? I suggest that it contradicts it in no way at all.

Tax avoidance will be an issue at the next election because the Australian community knows-we will reaffirm its knowledge-that if the present Opposition were ever to be returned to this side of the House, to government, it would again go soft on the tax avoiders and the tax evaders as it did in the past. There is no question about that.

Let me make sure that some of this is placed on the record. If members of the Opposition come before this Parliament and proclaim before the Australian community that in some way they have some cause to be proud of their record in relation to tax evasion and tax avoidance, let them justify it in the light of these details: In 1975-76, the last year of the previous Labor Government, 861 individuals and companies were identified in Australia as having been involved in tax avoidance. In 1982-83, the last full year of the previous Government for which figures are available, almost 40,000 schemes were identified. The number of people and companies involved in tax avoidance during the term of the Fraser Government absolutely exploded. It exploded because of the insufficiency of the legislation for which the Opposition claims credit, the legislation it was obliged to introduce. The then Government, formed by the parties now in Opposition, was dragged literally screaming into this legislature in order to introduce and enact that legislation. The Opposition knows that what I say is the case.

I refer now to the number of taxpayers who understated their incomes or lodged false returns between the last year of the last Labor Government and the last year of the Fraser Government for which figures are available. In 1975-76 roughly 25,000 taxpayers understated their incomes or lodged false returns. In 1981-82, the last year of the Fraser Government for which figures are available, almost 43,500 did so. So the number went up from 25,000 to 43,500. I have made the claim before-I have indicated that my claim can be substantiated as a result of research and analysis by institutions and academics within the community who are far more competent to carry out that analysis than I am-that the tax avoidance and tax evasion industry in Australia in each year of the previous Government, on average, cost the Australian community and the public revenue something like $7,000m. That is every year. What an appalling reflection on the record of the Fraser Government. What an appalling reflection on its concern for equity. What an appalling reflection on its suggestion that in some way it was concerned about ensuring that all individuals and all companies in Australia paid their appropriate contribution to public revenue. What does that represent in terms of the pay as you earn taxpayers who are left to pick up the bill? It represents something like $30 every week from every household in Australia to make up the difference for the tax dodgers, the tax crooks, the tax lurks and all the rest of the individuals and companies in Australia who were involved in these shady shyster practices.

If honourable members need any further evidence I will go to the report of the Commonwealth Auditor-General that was brought down in March of this year. That report indicated that the amount of tax outstanding had risen from about $1 billion to $3 billion over the last six years. Is that evidence of the former Fraser Government having shown any concern about stamping out tax avoidance and tax evasion? That report also indicated that the tax outstanding, as a proportion of collectable tax, had risen from 9 per cent in 1976-77 to 23 per cent in 1982-83-almost to one-quarter. What reason did he give after this creditable record of the Fraser Government! He said it was mainly because of the increase in the amount that was outstanding from taxpayers involved in artificial tax avoidance schemes. If those figures, by themselves, do not give the lie to the claims that have been made by the Opposition, I do not know what will. The Opposition should not come before this Parliament, nor should it go before the Australian people, and suggest it has a proud record in this area.

We all well remember the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, the present Deputy Leader of the Opposition, introducing the Government's initial Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill on 23 September 1982. Why did he introduce it? I said earlier that the then Government was dragged screaming into this legislature to enact legislation against the tax dodgers. It was forced to act. The anger, the wrath and the concern of the Australian people were such, as a result of the disclosures of the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, that their vengeance forced the Government to act and on 23 September it introduced and tabled legislation concerning bottom of the harbour arrangements. That legislation lay on the table. The corridors of this Parliament were literally filled with the tax dodgers, the friends and the benefactors of the Fraser Government and the Liberal Party. They were hiding in the dark corners of the corridors, trying to force the Government to weaken that legislation-and weaken that legislation it did. Did that Government respond? Did it respond to its benefactors? It did indeed. The legislation which it finally introduced in modified form on 21 October 1982 had been considerably sanitised, considerably watered down and considerably weakened to make sure that all of its friends, members and benefactors were not named. In addition considerable concessions were built into that legislation to make sure that the full amount of tax was not collected.

In the couple of minutes remaining to me I make these points: We indicated perfectly clearly not only at the stage that that initial legislation was considered, but also prior to 5 March last year when we were elected to government, that given the opportunity we would legislate retrospectively to pick up the tax that should have been picked up. We introduced legislation on 18 May last year, about 10 weeks after we took office. That legislation did not index the amount of tax, as we intended originally, to make sure that the real value of that money that the tax dodgers had the benefit of was picked up by the Commonwealth. Had we done so we would have been attempting to pick up $840m that they had the use of in real terms. We chose not to do so. Our original legislation was intended to pick up only $570m, not the indexed $840m. That legislation was opposed by the Opposition in this House and by the Opposition, in collusion with the Australian Democrats, in the Senate. As a result of that the legislation was defeated in the Senate. What did we do? We modified our legislation to take out the question of those capital profits taxes about which so much concern had been expressed. We did that and reintroduced the amended legislation on Budget night on 23 August last year. The amount that we would have then picked up would have been only $270m. Again it was defeated by the combined forces of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in the Senate.

We then introduced a further modified version of that legislation on 3 November last year. We had to come down from the original figure of $840m, to $570m and then to $270m. What did we propose to pick up then? We were going to pick up $ 35m, but it should have been $840m. That is what was ripped off the public revenue. That was the difference that the Australian taxpayers-the pay as you earn taxpayers, the ordinary taxpayers, the households in Australia-had to make up. We finally wanted to pick up $35m but the legislation for that was also defeated by the combined forces of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats in the Senate. Now we have introduced this legislation-mark II-which is exactly the same as that which we introduced on Budget night.

This Government has a clear and unequivocal mandate to enact this legislation and to collect this avoided tax. The Opposition, together with its Democrat allies in the Senate, has on previous occasions denied this Government the right to exercise its mandate. In the process, the Opposition and its Democrat allies have repudiated the judgment made by the Australian electorate on 5 March last year. They have betrayed the ordinary Australian wage and salary taxpayers, who must now pay more tax to compensate for that loss caused by the tax avoiders. They have aligned themselves clearly and unconscionably with the tax avoiders of the Australian community. They have indicated that they will use their combined numbers in the Senate to frustrate the expressed will of the Australian people.

If they again fail to pass this legislation, the judgment of the Australian people will be on them. The Australian electors, in their anger at this betrayal of principle, will relegate more members of the Opposition and more Democrats to political oblivion. There is no place in this Parliament for people who betray Australia and betray Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note the number of times that we have had to sit in this House and listen to the rantings of the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), who poses in here, and displays cant and mock seriousness in regard to matters for which he knows in his heart he feels absolutely no sincerity. He thinks because he can throw his arms around and raise his voice a little and throw in a few fancy words like 'mandate' and 'the people of Australia' here and there-as does his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-that that will add some sort of semblance of respectability to his behaviour. That is absolutely outrageous, and the honourable member knows it is outrageous. He knows that the community has no respect for the stance he and his Government are taking.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the Government that when it is dealing with retrospective legislation it is dealing with something that is terribly dangerous. If the Government is dealing with retrospective legislation it has a heavy responsibility to deal with it in a way which is totally responsible. As we have said in this place and in the other House on a number of occasions, what the Government is doing with this legislation and the way it is being handled is not responsible. That is the critical thing. I am not saying that the Government does not have the right to bring in retrospective legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a mandate to do so.
—You do not have a mandate.
—Yes, we do.

—You have a mandate to deal with tax avoidance; you do not have a mandate to deal with retrospectivity. There is a hell of a difference between the two, and you need to understand that. If you claim a mandate in terms of retrospectivity, it is a very limited mandate. It is not a mandate that would justify the sort of legislation that we are debating here today. The Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and its cognate Bill seek, in their retrospective intent, to tax people who did not get a benefit. I believe that is a very serious point. Whether a scheme was successful or not, you will issue an assessment. You will do so whether or not a benefit resulted from any scheme entered into. In my mind, that is a total abuse of retrospective principles. If you are going to introduce retrospectivity-and I am not saying that it is unconstitutional; it is not and it can be done-you have to be very careful about it. The retrospective legislation that was introduced by the former Government was incredibly tight.
—So it was retrospective legislation.
—Of course it was.
—That is right.
—Yes, of course it was.
—You ought to tell that to some of your colleagues who have denied it.
—No.
—Order! I ask honourable members to cease calling out to each other across the chamber. I ask the honourable member for Hume to address his remarks through the Chair.

—Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, the point that I make is that the legislation that was passed by the then Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is now the shadow Treasurer, was legislation which was extremely tight and it was limited in two very specific ways. The first way was that there had to be a benefit. If there was no benefit, there was no assessment. I believe that is a principle to which we must adhere. This legislation says that recoupment will not be avoided because a tax avoidance scheme which related to a sale proved to be unsuccessful. It is pretty clear to me that if one entered into something which fell down and was not successful, the Government's legislation would still enable an assessment to be made. That is something which we are not prepared to tolerate.

SPEECH.PARA: The financial benefit element in the previous Government's legislation is extremely important. Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I say to honourable members opposite that this is a very important principle and one that ought not to be taken lightly because the power of a government to create a liability in a retrospective fashion is one which must be treated only with the utmost care and caution. If we are going to start creating precedents which the Opposition will agree with and the Senate allows legislation of this type to be passed, we will be creating precedents for all sorts of horrific legislation that will not be in the interests of Australia. People need to understand that. This legislation seeks to lay down a principle whereby we can redefine retrospectively something which is not income, call it income, and having so redefined it, apply a retrospective tax on it. That is something which I think is absolutely objectionable. It is the reason why I have opposed this legislation from the day it was introduced. I will continue to oppose it and I believe that the Senate is on sound grounds in also opposing it. I think that we need to repeat, make clear and make it understood that retrospective legislation is something which is abhorrent. It should be used only in absolutely essential circumstances. The need for retrospectivity does not apply in this case.

If the Government intends to use it, it should do so tightly and not create precedents that can have a broader range of application by future governments which can say: 'Yes, but remember the TUCTA legislation, the good old taxation unpaid company tax assessment legislation that was produced by Mr Keating back in 1983-84'. Everyone said that was wonderful legislation. That legislation redefined income. Having redefined something which was not income at all when a scheme was entered into, five or six years later it is reprehensible to apply income tax to such a scheme. It ought to be seen as being reprehensible. That is why we will continue to oppose such legislation. It is shabby. It is the sort of legislation that ought not be brought forward in any self-respecting parliament.

What would the honourable member for Hunter do if someone came to him, in his electorate, and said: 'This land on which your house is built will be rezoned and called industrial land.
