We will say that it has been industrial land for the past five years and we will apply rates on that land as if it was industrial land for the last five years'? That is the same sort of thing that the Government is doing. It is saying to people who entered into perfectly legitimate arrangements that were sanctioned by the law at the time, and from which they made money which was not assessable income, it is assessable income. It is applying a retrospective tax to that income. That is absolutely reprehensible. I say to honourable members opposite that the Opposition will not have a bar of that sort of nonsense. That is why we will continue to oppose it.

The Government can keep introducing such legislation time and again. The Government can make this a double dissolution issue this year if it wishes, but we are prepared to stand on that principle and the Government ought to understand that. Honourable members opposite may laugh, but they know that I am right, and they would not have had a bar of this sort of legislation. If we had introduced the same legislation, they would have said in here that it was outrageous, and so they should, because such legislation is outrageous. There has to be someone in this place and someone in this country who will stand up for honest people and honest taxpayers who did nothing wrong at the time. What they did was absolutely legal; it was absolutely within the law. Interestingly, the legislation we passed has been validated by the High Court. It is also interesting that the Commissioner of Taxation, when asked in March or some time early last year by the then Treasurer, who was about to be the ex-Treasurer, whether anything needed to be done in this area, said, as I understand it: 'No, everything is okay'. Then honourable members opposite came to power with their high-minded attitude towards taxation avoidance. They have been running around the country talking about it and saying that all sorts of outrageous things were going on. They got into government and called for a report. They were told that: 'It is all fixed, it is all over-there is nothing more to do'. They said: 'Well, there must be something to do because here we are, we have been raising the expectations of all sorts of people across Australia about this. We have to have some legislation about it.' They were told: 'There is nothing that you can do. It is dead, it is all finished, it is over. The legislation of the former Government has fixed it'.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins), of all people, went to the Australian Society of Accountants and said: 'It is over. Tax avoidance is dead'. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), unlike the honourable member for Hunter, made a very reasoned speech here this morning. Like yourself, Madam Deputy Speaker, she is one who brings a lot of talent into this Parliament, unlike others. She understands these things. But she tried to redefine and put into another perspective, in the way that so many members of the Hawke Government try to do, the very clear and unequivocal words of the Minister for Finance when he said: 'It is over. As an issue, it is finished'. Yet the Government came into this place last week with its cherry-picking legislation. This was another phoney attempt to try to drum up in the minds of the public the fact that this Government is doing something about all of the outrageous tax avoidance that is going on.

In the case of the cherry-picking scheme, it has been shown-the Commissioner of Taxation himself has said it on earlier occasions-that there is nothing to worry about and that anything that the Government does in order to get at one or two who may be creating some abuse will upset an awful lot of quite legitimate arrangements. The Treasurer then had to go to the Taxation Commissioner and apply pressure by saying: 'Look, I know you said all these things to the previous Government, but give me some more advice. Give me some more advice as to why this legislation is okay'. I do not want to cast aspersions on the Taxation Commissioner because I have a lot of respect for him. But he was put in an impossible position in that he then had to provide advice and redefine what he had said on an earlier occasion. He had to try and say that in a different context the legislation might have some value. That is absolutely outrageous.

People in the community need to understand that this Government is putting at risk the fundamental rights that people have. Anybody in this country is entitled to enter into legal arrangements. They are perfectly lawful. There is nothing wrong with them. There they stand. Yet, the Government is going way beyond what any government has ever considered before under this arrangement. It is going back into the past, way back into the 1970s. It is re-defining something, creating a totally new situation and then saying: 'Okay, having done that, we are now going to issue you taxation assessments and we are going to collect taxation on that basis'. Is it any surprise that there is opposition to such a proposal? Is it any surprise that the Australian Democrats in the Senate who are not necessarily any friend of the Opposition-the Democrats over there do not support us on very much-have had the courage in this particular instance to stand up and say: 'There is an important principle at stake here. We are not going to have a bar of this sort of legislation'. So they should because nobody ought to have a bar of this sort of thing.

The legislation that the then Treasurer introduced was responsible legislation. I did not agree with it at the time. It was legislation that many of us would rather we never had to introduce. However, he believed that if we were going to do something in a retrospective way it would have to be done extraordinarily tightly. It was done extraordinarily tightly. The only people who were disadvantaged by that legislation were those people who got a benefit from the original tax arrangement. Where a company had been put through a procedure, which was an illegal procedure, and as a result of that illegal procedure it was put in a position where it was unable to meet its tax liability properly assessed, it was deemed appropriate that a liability ought to attach to people who had got the benefit of that illegal action and that it was proper to be able to issue an assessment against them.

But the legislation before the House is a totally different thing. It takes this matter way beyond that. The effect of the Government's legislation is to say: 'We do not care whether there was an illegal act or not. This will apply. We do not care whether the scheme you entered into was successful or not. This Act will apply'. This is absolutely outrageous and it is proper that the legislation be opposed. That is why the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Part 4A would deal with the situations in exactly the same way!
—Order! The honourable member for Hunter will cease interjecting and holding conversations across the chamber with the honourable member for Hume.

—The interesting thing that I suppose I should make some comment about , without referring to anybody at all in the chamber, is simply that if Part 4A is okay, what are we doing sitting here for the fourth or fifth time debating this legislation? We are debating this legislation because the Government wants to go back in time and collect some money from people whom it adjudges were part of some terrible taxation rip-off. What they were doing at the time was not a taxation rip-off. It was something that was totally legal. There was no law against it. People were entitled to order their affairs in such a way as was permitted by the legislation of that day and so they did. It is very difficult to argue that they should not have had the right to do that. Yet, the Government is now saying: 'Well, to hell with all of that sort of principle. That does not matter any more. Nothing is sacred in this country. We are prepared to go back and undo all that. We are prepared to make those people the recipients of taxation assessments.'

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, whatever the provisions of this Bill might be, the principle that is at stake is the way in which retrospective legislation ought to apply. It is that which is my particular interest in relation to this debate and to earlier debates that we have had on the same legislation. I do not care what the provisions are. Any time that this Government comes in here with legislation that has an adverse retrospective impact on people I will stand up and I will speak against it. A line has to be drawn beyond which it is not possible for governments to go. There needs to be an understanding of that. The people of Australia need to be able to understand that if they indulge in some commercial activity today or tomorrow or, if they indulged yesterday, that is within the law, no government will come back to them tomorrow or next year or five or seven years down the track and say: 'Hey, we do not like what you were doing back then . We are going to undo that and we are going to tax you on it'. That is outrageous. One of the principles that ought to be written in blood on the floor of the chamber of this Parliament is that people will not be put in the position of having their arrangements undone in that sort of a fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the wage and salary earners' blood.

—The honourable member ought to understand it. He is supposed to be a person who understands these sorts of matters. He has had some professional association and experience in this area. Yet, he comes in here and defends this outrageous legislation that is impossible to defend. I have just been looking back through the Hansard record of the Committee debate that took place on the last occasion this legislation was being discussed. We had old tangle tongue, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), in here trying to defend it on behalf of the Treasurer.

—Order! I point out to the honourable member for Hume that he should refer to Ministers and members of this House by their correct and proper name and not make offensive comments. I would ask him to withdraw the comment that he just made and to name the Minister in the correct manner.
—I withdraw. I think it is the Minister for Housing and Construction.
—Territories and Local Government, I think.

—Order! I point out to the honourable member for Hume that standing order 80 requires that members refer to other members of this House by the name of the electorate they represent. I again call the honourable member's attention to this and ask that he adhere to the standing order.
—I thank you for your guidance, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—It was my direction, sir.

—I apologise-your direction. On the occasion of that Committee debate, the Minister for Housing and Construction, representing the Treasurer in that debate, was unable to give satisfactory justification as to why the legislation had been introduced and gave unsatisfactory answers to the questions that had been raised by the Opposition as to the effect and impact of the legislation and how it would operate. To my knowledge, those matters remain unsatisfactorily dealt with. It is pretty apparent that this time around the same thing is going to apply.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing needs to be understood: The Opposition is not going to have a bar of legislation of this nature. We have made our position clear. The Government keeps bringing the legislation back. It keeps serving it up again and again. It can keep serving it up again and again. The Opposition will take the same attitude because there is an important matter of principle involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My word there is.

—Yes there is. I agree with the honourable member for Hunter. There is a very important matter of principle. That matter of principle is that people must be free to go about their business. They must be free to go about making their commercial arrangements and to enter into agreements, contracts or whatever one likes. They must be free to do that within the law of the land as it applies at the time they do it. What sort of uncertainty does it create for anybody making a contract today if he thinks that we are living under a regime by which that contract may be declared null and void in five years time and that some advantage that he may gain out of the contract will be penalised. That is the sort of thing with which we are dealing. That is why the Opposition will oppose and will continue to oppose this legislation, because it is a matter of deep and abiding principle. The legislation before the House is an absolute outrage.

—I draw honourable members' attention to the fact that, under standing order 59 and according to the practice of this House and other Houses of Parliament, it is customary and a requirement to debate through the Chair. That does not mean honourable members saying 'Through you, Madam Deputy Speaker' and then shouting out directly to honourable members on the other side. What it means is that direct comment and argument from honourable members on one side of the House to honourable members on the other is not permitted or encouraged within the House. I understand that there has been some leniency by the Chair and that the standing order cannot be too rigidly applied. In drawing the attention of the honourable member for Hume to this fact and the fact that one must use the correct name when addressing other members I am following on the point made by Mr Speaker this week when he said that he wished to raise the level of debate within the House owing to the fact that it has really deteriorated to a great extent, particularly over the last couple of weeks.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. Would you please direct the chamber's attention to the standing order that prevents interjections during an honourable member's speech?

—I will certainly do that. Standing orders Nos 75, 76, 77, 79 and 81 all deal with different aspects of abuse such as referred to by the honourable member for Dawson. I thank him for drawing the attention of the House to that. I impress on honourable members that those standing orders should be adhered to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I will make a couple of comments with respect to the contribution by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher), through the Chair of course. Unfortunately for his colleagues, the honourable member for Hume quickly unloaded them on the issue of retrospectivity . We had the spectacle in here earlier today of seeing and hearing the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) put a most eloquent speech in support of the view that there was no retrospectivity implied in the previous Government's legislation. We also heard the honourable member for North Sydney ( Mr Spender), who once again waxed lyrical on the supposed lack of retrospectivity in the previous Government's legislation. However, up in their rooms they would have been horrified to hear the honourable member for Hume quite blandly concede that the previous Government's legislation was retrospective in its impact. What he said was that the issue was the way retrospectivity ought to apply. So here we have a massive contradiction by members of the Opposition in putting their contributions in this debate. My own view is a strong one. It is not a common thing in terms of the contributions of the honourable member for Hume in this House, but on this occasion he is absolutely correct. That is something that I wish to stress very strongly indeed . I hope that the honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for North Sydney have time to reflect on the contribution made by the honourable member for Hume because it will be referred to often in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong indicated that the previous Government had an excellent record in relation to tax avoidance. Certainly, it did! My colleague, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) has adverted to that excellent record. It was the best record on tax avoidance in the history of this nation. We ought not to forget that. The legislation currently before the House has been before the House, in one form or another, on numerous occasions. Because its intention is to give effect to this Government's election undertaking to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies that were the subject of bottom of the harbour schemes, it is opposed by the Opposition. Why is it opposed? It is opposed simply because the large number of people associated with the Liberal Party will be required to pay, under this legislation, their share of the tax burden that is currently being shouldered by the ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers of this country.

This legislation will be passed. If it is not passed on this occasion it will be passed in the future. It will be passed because there is no other option for any government whose objective is to ensure that the taxation system impacts fairly upon all members of our community. If this legislation is frustrated by the Opposition it will be people such as the constituents of the electorate of Maribyrnong, my constituents who will be obliged to further carry the burden of taxation in this country. That is not an option that I am prepared to accept.

The former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, also adverted to the danger of bankruptcies leading to joblessness. Two points ought to be made about that smokescreen. The first is that the Commissioner of Taxation is more concerned with obtaining the appropriate dues than any precipitate action that would lead to unemployment. To this end it is quite common in dealings with the Australian Taxation Office for arrangements to be entered into that provide for repayment over time.

The second point is that, even if the owner of a company is bankrupted that does not mean that the company stops practicing. Anyone with a rudimentary understanding of how legislation operates in this country would understand that the company is put up for sale and is continued by someone else. That happens every day of the week. There is no reason why, if this legislation were enacted, that situation would change. As I have indicated, the argument is simply a smokescreen. I do not blame the former Treasurer for attempting to create a smokescreen or two. Any smokescreen would be better than an analysis of his period at the reins of Treasury.

Under the Fraser Government, while the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer, this, in part, was the record: Ninety-eight per cent of taxpayers paid a greater proportion of their incomes in tax than under the previous Labor Government. The greatest increases under the former Government were borne by those in the lowest income groups. Once again, that is an indication of the philosophy of the Opposition. Under the former Treasurer, grossly increased tax burdens were encountered by ordinary PAYE taxpayers whilst non-PAYE taxpayers and companies had their respective contributions slashed. Under the honourable member for Bennelong promises relating to tax cuts and to tax indexation were thrown out the window. Tax changes favoured the wealthy. The 1977 tax cuts and surcharges were an example of this. They were both absolutely regressive in impact. Under the former Treasurer a wide array of tax concessions were given to the wealthy, often without any regard being paid to the fundamentals that ought to be taken account of when one is considering various ways of imposing taxation .

The taxing policies of the coalition obviously took little heed of these essential requirements. Firstly, their impact was totally inequitable. The former Government's proposals benefited a very small and very powerful minority at the expense of the great majority of taxpayers. Secondly, its taxation system was entirely non-neutral. It favoured particular activities, often without any rhyme or reason. Thirdly, it did little to promote efficiency. Instead, its taxation systems tended to encourage the overcapitalisation of both rural and manufacturing industries and, hence, often led to direct negative employment implications. Fourthly, those policies resulted in an increasingly complex taxation Act which directly resulted in a massive increase in the levels of tax avoidance because of the opportunities that were thus presented to practitioners in that shameful industry.

This important legislation is an attempt to recover some $270m. My colleague, the honourable member for Hunter, has already outlined that if this Government were to act directly on its mandate it would pursue a sum in the vicinity of $ 840m. The legislation that was knocked back in this House some time ago proposed a recovery of some $500m. These amounts are peanuts in the context of sums like $7 billion that have been mentioned in this House today. The smart operators in our community avoided $7 billion in tax.

I reject absolutely any approach that results in the ordinary PAYE taxpayers of this country, such as those in the electorate of Maribyrnong, paying massive amounts of tax far in excess of what they should have to pay under a fair and equitable system. The honourable member for Hunter struck a figure of $30 per week. I am not sure, in the context of this debate, how accurate that figure is. I have heard mention of figures in excess of $30 per week; I have heard of figures less than $30 per week. Whatever the actual figure is, one fundamental consistent theme remains and that is that the ordinary PAYE taxpayers of this country are paying significantly higher levels of tax because of an involvement by many members of the community, and many people associated with the Liberal Party of Australia, in the tax avoidance industry.

I am confident that when the next opportunity presents itself those ordinary Australian PAYE taxpayers will take note of a couple of points raised during the debate today. They will concede that the honourable member for Hume was correct, that the argument is not about retrospectivity. As he, a member of the Opposition, conceded, the previous Government's legislation was also retrospective. He was not talking about the principle of retrospectivity; he was talking about how it ought to be applied in certain circumstances.

This Government does not resile from that fact. We do not believe that retrospectivity should be embraced across a range of policy areas. That, in a democracy, would be an absurdity. But we do strongly believe, as do many members of the community, that the only way we can guarantee that this industry will be stamped out forever is to embrace selectively, as we have done with this legislation, the necessity of retrospectivity. It is by that mechanism and that mechanism alone that the ordinary taxpayers of Australia will have to meet only their fair share of the burden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — This debate is a continuing one. I believe that the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 [No.4] has been introduced into this House-I think the people of Australia also believe this-for the sole purpose of providing what the Government believes will be a trigger for a double dissolution. If the Government is using this Bill as the basis on which to go for a double dissolution, for an early election this year or early next year, it will be surely disappointed. The people of Australia will find out the depth of the Government's conviction in this regard by its actions to date. Its actions to date have revolved solely around retrospectivity in relation to attacks on tax avoidance. I want to draw the distinction immediately that what we are talking about here is tax avoidance, not tax evasion. The many figures that have been quoted by members of the Government imply that this involves $7 billion, or $30 a week per taxpayer, as a result of tax avoidance. But the problems with income tax in Australia today do not relate to the piddling amounts involved here; they relate to the massive amounts that are evaded by many of the taxpayers of Australia today. If the Government goes forward with the conviction that this is a threat for a double dissolution it is sadly misguided.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an attack, through retrospectivity, on tax avoidance. One has to repeat time and again the comment of the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) who, I believe, and this House believes, has practised a form of tax avoidance within his own affairs. Tax avoidance is not a crime. Tax avoidance involves using the taxation legislation to do things with minimum impact on taxation, Federal or State. That is what tax avoidance is about. When we are talking about avoidance, let us get to the point: A tax avoider is a person who lodges an income tax return. He is a person who discloses in full everything related to that tax return. That tax return is based on the laws of the day or the laws of the preceding year in which he earned his income.

TALK.START.PARA: —He abuses the law though, doesn't he?
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek your protection from interjections.
—Order! Honourable members on my right will not interject.

—I am trying to bring a bit of sane debate into this very ticklish problem. That is basically what tax avoidance is. As I have said, the Minister for Finance probably would confess to practising tax avoidance, as probably would many in this chamber, both on the Government side and on the Opposition side. At a meeting of chartered accountants in Sydney recently, the Minister said that, as far as the Government was concerned, tax avoidance was no longer an issue in Australia. Why did he say that? I had very close working relationships with the Treasurer in the previous Government. He reacted to advice given by the Australian Taxation Office to the extent that, from the time I came into this place in 1975 to the time of the change of government last year , the Income Tax Assessment Act practically doubled in size. That happened for one reason only-the enormous number of tax avoidance measures that were introduced into this House. There were 43 in all. Of course, the main one to which the Minister for Finance was referring was that all encompassing provision that was used to strengthen section 260, a very discredited section of the Act, wherein the Commissioner of Taxation had very little power under decisions handed down by the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I practised tax accounting for over 20 years before I came into this House. I can say that those accountants to whom the Minister was addressing his remarks would probably be the most honourable of the profession. They would have abided by the laws of the country and would have lodged returns in accordance with the laws. The point is that there is no truth in the Government's comments and claims in this and every other debate on taxation. Government members talk in terms of millions and billions of dollars lost. But they are not talking about avoidance; they are talking about evasion. Some such comments were made earlier in this debate.

I listened very intently to the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) when he said that the tax avoidance industry, the tax dodging industry, blossomed in the Fraser years. I will give some facts and figures in connection with where this started. It is up to people to decide whether they want to blame a government for it. A few things are relevant. In the early 1970s the Curran scheme was in fashion. I believe it was Mr Crean who, as the Federal Treasurer at that time, indicated in his Budget Speech that he would attack the Curran scheme. But absolutely nothing was done from the time of that announcement to when Labor lost office in 1975.

There is another relevant fact. Look at the overall statistics through the 1970s, of people paying personal income tax in the highest tax bracket. At the moment the highest figure is 61c in the dollar. Go back to the early 1970s and compare the figure with that of the late 1970s. If honorary members do so they will find that only half of the taxpayers who were paying tax in the highest bracket in the beginning of the 1970s were paying in that same bracket at the end of the 1970s, or even in the mid-1970s. This implies to me that right through the 1970s, in which there were three governments in power-Liberal, Labor and Liberal again-people were looking at the Act and arranging their affairs in such a way as to avoid, legally, higher amounts of tax. Of course our taxation Act provides encouragement for people to earn income in certain directions, and people's actions in that regard could be claimed as being tax avoidance in that the income earned is exempt because of the Act or is an allowance in the form of capital which is transferred as a deduction as far as tax is concerned.

Let us get this legislation into perspective. At the moment the Government would say that this practice of tax avoidance is massive, that it arose during the Fraser years and that the Fraser Government did very little in regard to it. I deny that. That is why the Minister for Finance conceded only a few months ago that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and former Treasurer had introduced 43 separate changes to the Act to try to stamp out tax avoidance. The Minister now admits that that was effective. So how shallow is the Government's action of coming in here with this legislation on two or three occasions and using it as a matter of great public interest to trigger a double dissolution?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a political stunt.

—I believe it is a political stunt and I believe it would be political suicide if the Government thought that it could go to the people on this matter. We have heard the same rhetoric from Labor on all of these Bills and I believe it is time we had a look at its position.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned, tax avoidance is a separate issue altogether from tax evasion and I wonder whether the Government can quantify for me how much of that $7 billion lost every year, according to the honourable member for Hunter, applies to tax avoidance. I assume, from the figures of the Commissioner of Taxation, that it would be less than $1 billion, compared with tax evasion which totals $6 billion. I then ask what the Government is doing about the collection of the tax being evaded in this way.

People lodging their returns, who the Government might claim are tax avoiders, might do so on the clear understanding that their returns comply with the laws of the time and in every respect are legally correct. I am not talking about morals; I am talking about legality. There are no morals in a government that would change the rules, to make illegal the situation where a person lodged a return on that basis, by retrospecting those laws. Retrospecting those laws the Government is, right back to 1972. If this is a case of pure tax avoidance, no government, no person and no Prime Minister has the mandate to change the laws to make illegal what was legal. So I do believe very firmly that this matter should be treated in the way I have suggested.

I go one step further and suggest that the Government has done very little in regard to stamping out tax evasion. What would the situation be if the Government were determined to take the further step of retrospectively making illegal today what was legal yesterday? How does it intend to attack, for instance, the Dawkins scheme? Will it retrospectively apply laws that will bring into account the optional capital gains made in connection with those companies, and will the Western Australian Government retrospectively apply its laws on stamp duties to collect the tax avoided in that regard?

Let us talk in terms of capital gains. Will the Australian Labor Party introduce capital gains measures in such a way that they will retrospectively apply to incomes, including capital appreciations and inflation effects of the past? The same applies to the wealth tax. We already know that the assets test for pensioners certainly will be retrospectively applied, back to August of last year. Will it apply-this is a very personal matter-to our own parliamentary superannuation scheme?

We had rushed through the House last year a law that permitted parliamentarians to take only one half of their superannuation in a lump sum, the other half having to be taken in the form of a pension. That Act has not yet been proclaimed, in spite of the speed with which it was put through this House just to satisfy the Government, so it could say it had done something about it. Does that mean that the former member for Hughes, who retired just three or four months ago, will suffer retrospective application following proclamation? Will his receiving of a full pay-out of his superannuation become illegal? The former member for Hughes took that full amount in light of the Act at the time. I understand he received his full superannuation payment. Will the Government now apply that law?

Tax evasion is something greater. I believe that the $30 a week extra tax that we are paying-I am one of those taxpayers-should not be regarded as making up the loss created by tax avoiders. That $30 a week, if it is a true figure, is an amount which could quite well be taken by one's neighbour who is moonlighting on a second job under a false name. It could quite well be taken by the businessman who is tickling the till and not disclosing his full income, or is making false claims for quite a few other expenditures. I refer to the non-disclosure of income. That is the subterranean economy. That is the billion that people talk about. In fact, I have heard that $16 billion is the actual amount lost through non-disclosure of income in the subterranean economy. What has the Government done in regard to that? It is prepared to penalise some taxpayers in connection with avoidance, but not evaders. I come to the point that if people who are avoiding tax in this regard are tax evaders, not tax avoiders, and if they did not make a full and true disclosure or were doing something that was incorrect, they can be caught under the provisions of the present Act without the necessity of this legislation, which I say lacks depth.

All of us have to examine our consciences in this matter. I refer particularly to those officers from the Australian Taxation Office who now sit on the advisers' benches in this House, as they will be the people administering the Act. Is there a taxpayer in Australia who can say that he is honest, pure and clear as far as his own tax matters are concerned? How as parliamentarians can we do it? I ask any parliamentarian whether, in regard to the disclosure of his income and particularly allowances and his claims for them, he has made an actual check list and audited that with the Taxation Office before the claim was allowed. So do not let us be hypocritical in this House in regard to this legislation when we know that a greater problem exists out there and that perhaps each of us is guilty.

It is nonsense for the Government to pin its hopes on tax avoidance when actually we should be concerned with tax evasion. Perhaps what we are looking for is plastic policemen-identity cards so that we can identify people with income and readily associate that income with the manner in which they take money from the public purse. I know that the card would be said to be an affront to civil liberties and it would be an offence under the Income Tax Assessment Act, but that is the only way we will be able to get to the bottom of the problem that faces us.

I have mentioned the 1,200 or so pages of the present Act. It is time that this Government and this Parliament got their act together and made sure that the taxation laws of Australia are, both directly and indirectly, fair and equitable . For that reason I believe we should be funding a type of taxation foundation which is on tap all the time to supply information to the Taxation Office, to suggest reviews and also to rectify present inequities. We will not correct the taxation system by bringing these spurious Bills before the House and talking about great sums of money being lost when so little of it applies to tax avoidance itself. For that reason I will be voting against the Bill. I believe it is as shallow as the Government's argument on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I think it would be true to say that so far as the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill and associated Bill are concerned, the issues involved have been exhaustively canvassed in this House, both in this debate and in the earlier debate as a result of a Budget Bill last year when the same legislation was dealt with. I guess the matter has also been considered in the context of the other variants of this legislation that have been introduced. So I will not talk for long.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by simply drawing attention to the centrality of the introduction of a greater degree of equity into the tax system to the prices and incomes accord. As honourable members would be aware, the prices and incomes accord is the central element of the Government's economic program. An element of that accord is the introduction of a degree of tax equity. That assumes particular significance at this point of time given the smallness of the consumer price index adjustment that we are likely to see in October because of the Medicare adjustment. Hence there is a need to avoid a collapse of the accord resulting from the smallness of that adjustment; hence also the recognised and perceived need for some tax relief, particularly for people in lower and middle income brackets.

In terms of increasing the scope for tax relief on the one hand and increasing the revenue available for the Government's social objectives-raising basic social welfare benefit payments, for example-it is obviously important to minimise the degree of tax avoidance. There could be no more equitable revenue measure than rigorously to police and enforce tax avoidance measures and to introduce new forms of tax avoidance legislation where earlier legislation has proven to be inadequate. As earlier speakers have pointed out, the Government does not see this Bill as being the first best option. There will be no inclusion of capital profits within the ambit of the Bill. There will be no inclusion of revenue profits for years other than years in which there was an evasion of primary company tax. Those two exclusions will reduce the expected revenue from some $540m to $270m. As the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) pointed out, if we take into account what the amount would have been had the $540m been indexed we are looking at something like $840m. So really there is no doubt that this legislation recoups only a small proportion of what the Government had hoped to recoup.

We have heard a lot from the Opposition about the allegedly draconian retrospective facet of this legislation. I do not think that the Opposition would oppose either in rhetoric or in actions the retrospective collection of a tax in a case in which avoidance of a then existing tax had taken place. Its own legislation, the 1982 principal Act of this legislation, involved the retrospective collection of a tax liability that had been improperly avoided at an earlier time. The Opposition argues, of course, that this legislation retrospectively imposes a new tax liability. It tends to focus on the fact that the totality of the retained earnings so far as the revenue profit is concerned is to be imputed as a dividend and it is claimed that a complete dividend distribution would not in practice occur; that if the business continued to operate only a proportion of the retained earnings would go out in the form of a dividend, but another part of the retained earnings arising from revenue profit would in fact be ploughed back into the company and may possibly ultimately result in a capital gain. That seems to be the basis of the claim that what we are dealing with here is an effective capital gains tax.

I just make the point that a more reasonable way of considering this sort of issue would be to look at what would happen in the case of a company that was liquidated either voluntarily or involuntarily without any avoided company tax liability being involved, without that type of stripping operation involved, rather than considering what would have happened had the company continued to operate. As I understand the existing law, upon liquidation after meeting the obligations of the creditors anything left over that was distributed, would, in fact, be treated as income and subject to personal income tax in the hands of shareholders in the normal way. That being the case I do not think it is unreasonable or inconsistent with that general situation that this Government is seeking to impute a dividend based on the total after-tax retained earnings arising from revenue profits. I think it is a reasonable thing to do and that it is consistent in point of fact with the existing set of arrangements that apply in respect of companies going into liquidation.

Furthermore, I understand that there is a growing body of legal opinion that holds that the amounts which the Government seeks to recoup with these two Bills could in fact have been recouped given a situation in the High Court different from that which prevailed under Barwick. The opinion is that the amounts could have been recouped under the old section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Given an interpretation of legal doctrine different from the literalistic interpretations of the Barwick High Court, it may well have been feasible for these moneys to be collected under the old income tax legislation that applied during the period with which we are concerned. Thus, I really do not think that there is some draconian new principle involved in what is being imposed here; nor is there a question of the retrospective introduction of a tax which did not apply at the time. I do not think that those interpretations are valid.

We are dealing here with the fact that there was an effective distribution of a dividend, to the people involved, the vendor-shareholders. They benefited as if a dividend had in fact been distributed. Therefore, it is reasonable that that should be taken into account in the Government's tax legislation. A tax liability should be attached to the personal income arising from those dividends at the time. Thus I think that the legislation is reasonable. I certainly think that it is equitable and that the pursuit of legislative measures of this type are central to adherence to the prices and incomes accord. Without the vigorous pursuit of anti-tax avoidance measures we could see a real problem with the viability of the prices and incomes accord. I call upon members of this House to support this legislation fully and to reject the specious arguments advanced by the Opposition.
Debate (on motion by Mr Donald Cameron) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELF-GOVERNMENT FOR THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In opening the thirty-third Parliament on 21 April 1983 the Governor-General said:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government is committed to bringing self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. As a first step a broad range of local government powers will be transferred to the ACT House of Assembly.

On 9 November 1983 I appointed a Task Force of four members to advise me on implementation of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. The membership of the Task Force comprises Mr Gordon Craig, OBE, as Chairman and Ms Llois Cutts, Mr John Wood and Mr Alan Ashley. The Task Force was asked to examine a broad range of matters in respect of implementing self-government, to consult widely with the Australian Capital Territory community and to report to me in mid-1984. Because of the significant implications of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory to the people of the Territory and to the nation as a whole, and therefore the need to proceed with maximum consultation and minimum disruption, the Government has decided to take a number of steps which I shall now outline.

Firstly, the Government affirms the objective of a phased introduction of self- government in the Australian Capital Territory, involving a transfer of powers and functions to a newly elected Legislative Assembly. So that there is no misunderstanding, I would like to explain that this affirmation of the objective of self-government refers in broad terms to both the concept of self-government and the process of implementation. The concept of self-government which this Government is prepared to consider involves the election of a Legislative Assembly with powers to make laws and administer functions wider than those traditional to municipal government in the States, but of course, not statehood. The process of implementing self-government which this Government favours involves a staged transfer of powers and functions to allow the smoothest, fairest and most efficient transition to remove unfounded fear in the Australian Capital Territory community about instability or hardship.

In this regard, I want to make it clear that the financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory under self-government would be generally modelled on the Commonwealth-State financial arrangements and principles of fiscal equalisation to ensure that citizens of the Australian Capital Territory are treated fairly and equitably compared with the wider Australian community. Those financial arrangements would be built around a five-year transition period involving appropriate financial guarantees and designed to minimise disruption and enable the fullest opportunity for the negotiation of future funding levels.

At this stage the Government is committed to the widest possible process of public consultation and discussion of self-government options. To facilitate this process and enable the people of the Territory to understand and contribute to proposals, I am releasing the report of the Self-Government Task Force so that public comment can be sought. The Government is not necessarily committed to particular arguments or recommendations of the Task Force and will take full account of community response to the report in the development of its position on implementation of self-government. The Government also expects soon to receive the report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission on Australian Capital Territory finances. That report will be released as soon as possible and will provide additional information and options to guide community and Government consideration of self-government implementation.

In the light of public comment on the Task Force and Grants Commission reports, and in consultation with members of the Task Force, the House of Assembly, the Trades and Labour Council, relevant departments and authorities and other community organisations, the Government will publish a White Paper on self- government implementation in the first half of 1985. The publication of the White Paper will allow for further public consideration of the Government's intentions. In addition, the consultative process will include the establishment of a committee of relevant unions and Government officals to give particular consideration to the question of an Australian Capital Territory administration separate from the Australian Public Service. Following this wide consultative process the Government will give consideration to commencing the implementation of self-government in the second half of 1985.

The smooth implementation of self-government necessarily involves a range of complex administrative tasks. In line with the consultative process I have outlined, we will also be taking steps to co-ordinate necessary administrative arrangements so we are properly positioned to meet a 1985 implementation timetable. I would like to express my thanks to the members of the Task Force for the work they have done and the way they have carried out their tasks. I now table the report of the Task Force on Implementation of Self-Government for the Australian Capital Territory. I present the following paper:
Self-Government for the Australian Capital Territory-Ministerial Statement, 10 May 1984.
Motion (by Mr Howe) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak to the statement made by the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) and the report of the Task Force on Implementation of Self-Government for the Australian Capital Territory. I know that the Minister is anxious to get away, because he has an obligation to speak to the Press in relation to this matter, rather than to hear the whole of the debate. To facilitate that he has brought the matter on for discussion now. I am more than happy for him, as he suggested, not to listen but to read my comments in Hansard so that he can meet his commitment. But before he leaves I ask for some undertaking from him and the Government that this very detailed document which I have before me-it runs to something in the order of 177 pages-dealing with the concept of self-government will be debated not only in relation to this short statement but also in relation to some of the wider principles canvassed. Can the Minister give some assurance about when the matter will come on for debate?
—I cannot give any undertaking. Only the Leader of the House and the Government as a whole can give that undertaking.

—I will seek further advice from the Government on the opportunity to debate this matter more fully. It is a very important question, particularly to the people of the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister's statement today needs to be read very carefully against the Government's promise in this area. I pulled out the Australian Labor Party platform documents in relation to the Australian Capital Territory just to remind myself of the formal nature of the promise that was made by the Government regarding self-government. In the platform under the heading 'Federalism' this statement appears:

SPEECH.PARA: Self-government for the ACT with devolution of powers on terms and conditions suitable to and agreed by both the Federal government and the ACT House of Assembly.

That statement was made in the Government's own document. Statements were also made in the run up to the last election. I understand that in May 1982 the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, made some comments about self-government, because this was the centre of the Labor Party's policies regarding the Australian Capital Territory. If the then Opposition said anything else in relation to the Australian Capital Territory it said: 'There shall be self- government for the Australian Capital Territory'.Mr Hayden, when he was the Leader of the Opposition, said in May 1982, regarding the forthcoming House of Assembly election, that within 12 months of a Labor government being elected there would be self-government for the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did nothing about it when you were in government.

—The Opposition, when in government, was very conscious of the matter of self-government. It was of the view that a great deal more information was needed before it could realistically pursue the matter. It took the view that it needed to have an inquiry in relation to the National Capital Development Commission to look at any relationship that it might have in the context of self -government for the Australian Capital Territory. It was of the view that before anything else it should look at the financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory, because unless it was certain as to what those financial arrangements were there was no point in proceeding to put such a policy in place . The Opposition has always voiced its concern that the community in the Australian Capital Territory needed to have before it information on the financial arrangements before any proposition for self-government could be realistically advanced. It referred to the Commonwealth Grants Commission responsibility to look at the matters in relation to the Australian Capital Territory and gave it a particular term of reference. The Minister made reference to that in his statement today.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I point out these matters with the clarity that I have is that the Labor Party had a commitment. The Opposition clearly said right from the beginning that we have to be very cautious about the way in which the matter is approached because the community needs to have information before it. I might welcome the Government's conversion to this more responsible approach, but I think that it needs to be looked at against its rhetoric. There is a great deal of concern about the question of self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, particularly in the context of the financial arrangements. On every occasion on which I have spoken about self-government I have emphasised the need to have that information available before this matter is pressed.

We are now in a situation in which those people who have been determined to put self-government in place, such as the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) , who interjected, are now putting this initiative on the back burner. They are aware of the very considerable concern in the Australian Capital Territory. They are aware that in the context of any early Federal election the question of self -government will be a higher profile concern in the Australian Capital Territory than it was on the last occasion. I suspect that that fact has the honourable member for Canberra quivering in her shoes or boots today. She is quivering at the prospect of the people of the Australian Capital Territory looking more clearly at this question than they have done in the past other than in the context of a referendum and that matter was addressed by the previous Government .

We know that the Labor Party wants to have the best of both worlds. It wants to put the issue on the back burner and to ensure that it is not discussed in the context of an election, so it has brought down this report. It does not want these issues raised and it will not give the people of the Australian Capital Territory an opportunity of looking at them by way of a referendum. Clearly, the Minister makes no mention of it in his statement.

It is interesting to note some of the matters that the Minister has mentioned in his report. While he has had this Task Force report before him over the last couple of months and while there has been this toing and froing between him and the Task Force to get extra information there has been a great deal of discussion on this question within the trade union movement of the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —So there should.

—Of course there should be. I would be the first to admit that there should be discussion in the trade union movement and that the matter of self- government is of concern to the Public Service. But when we read this statement we wonder whether any other organisations in the Australian Capital Territory are to be interested in this question of self-government. The Minister said in his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of public comments on the Task Force and Grants Commission reports --
when the latter is to hand--

and in consultation with members of the Task Force, the House of Assembly, the Trades and Labor Council, relevant departments and authorities and other community organisations, the Government will publish a White Paper . . .
The statement continues:

In addition, the consultative process will include the establishment of a committee of relevant unions and Government officials to give particular consideration to the question of an Australian Capital Territory Administration separate from the Australian Public Service.

While I think it is very appropriate that the unions be involved, I do not think they ought to be the only organisations involved and I do not think other organisations in Canberra which have an interest in this subject ought just to be grouped together under the amorphous title 'other community organisations'. It is an emphasis of the concern that exists within the Public Service unions in Canberra and the reasons for their holding a meeting to consider the self- government question that the Minister in his statement has put such emphasis upon those organisations and consultations and largely, in my view, ignored other organisations that ought to be involved in the discussion of this question .

I mention two other matters in the context of this report and the Minister's statement. There is wide uncertainty in the Australian Capital Territory about the implications of self-government. People in the Australian Capital Territory have demanded that they be given an opportunity to comment on proposals, to play a role in reaching the decision as to what form self-government might take and to have a say by way of referendum.

I have tabled, as have other honourable members, a number of petitions signed by concerned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory seeking a referendum on these proposals. I think the most clear reason for the people of Canberra, through those petitions, seeking to put a view in relation to self-government is the uncertain arrangements for the finances of the Australian Capital Territory in the event that self-government proceeds. The people of the Australian Capital Territory could not fail to notice the tremendous uncertainty that is left in abeyance and unresolved by the Minister's statement.

The Grants Commission, chaired by Mr Justice Else Mitchell, has been inquiring into Australian Capital Territory finances and has to produce its report. The Minister gives us to understand that the Grants Commission is likely to report shortly, but that report is not yet before us. I do not believe that any realistic decisions can be taken on the question of self-government until that report is before the Parliament. There needs to be certainty in the Australian Capital Territory about the financial arrangements before this question of self- government can be considered realistically. If it is to be considered in the context of the Minister's statement I think there will be even further concern than there might otherwise have been. The Minister said in his statement:

. . . I want to make it clear that the financial arrangements for the Australian Capital Territory under self-government would be generally modelled on the Commonwealth-State financial arrangements and principles of fiscal equalisation to ensure that citizens of the Australian Capital Territory are treated fairly and equitably compared with the wider Australian community.

I think people of the Australian Capital Territory will want to know not just that their taxation base is to be looked at in the context of fairness and equity vis-a-vis the wider Australian community; rather they will want to be aware that the very special factors that affect the citizens of the Territory because it is the national capital will be taken into account. There is no indication in the Minister's statement that those factors will be taken into account in any self-government situation to the extent to which they are taken into account now. The honourable member for Canberra will be aware that Canberra has very significant national capital buildings and open spaces and that its buses have to travel much greater distances between centres of population than is the case in any other capital cities in Australia. These factors make Canberra unique. There is no indication in the Minister's statement that those special factors that result from Canberra's position as the national capital will be taken into account. I think the more alarming statement from this Minister for citizens of the Australian Capital Territory is this:
Those financial arrangements would be built around a five-year transition period involving appropriate financial guarantees . . .

In other words, notwithstanding the permanence of the buildings, structures and design of the capital which would entrench special cost factors that might have to be met, the transitional arrangements to take those factors into account would be limited to five years. All I can say is that I think it is important that the Else-Mitchell document be got into this House as quickly as possible so that we are in a position to see what the judge says about the special position in which the Australian Capital Territory may now be and, on the basis of factual information, to examine the implications of the Minister's statement. The Minister's statement clearly envisages very considerable increased costs being handed on to the people of Canberra to bear in relation to this capital and its special design. I think the Minister's statement is the clearest statement that I have seen from any Minister that the people of Canberra will be called upon to pay a great deal more in the event of self-government. I think the five-year transition arrangements spell that out with great clarity. If honourable members think that they can add to the statement and clarify what the Minister has said, let them do it, but that is the implication of what he has said.

The other matter to which I wish to draw the attention of honourable members concerns the electoral arrangements. The electoral arrangements were clearly matters of great concern to the people of the Australian Capital Territory.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mrs Kelly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 4]

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
DIVIDEND RECOUPMENT TAX BILL 1983 [No. 2] ]
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate on the second reading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Amendment Bill 1983 [No. 4] and the cognate Bill, the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill 1983 [No. 2], I convey thanks to those who made contributions to it. There has been some fine political rhetoric from both sides of the House and, in the case of my colleagues, the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly), the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown) and the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), there has been some good reasoning as well. There is a glorious feeling of deja vu about this debate. We had it a few times before. As we know, there is overwhelming support for these Bills in this chamber, but a majority of the Australian Democrats, with Senator Harradine plus senators of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have been rejecting the will of the popularly elected Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This must be about the seventeenth time that I have heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the shadow Treasurer, make the same speech. I must confess that it does not get any better. I am reminded of the phrase 'empty kettles make the most sound' because his speech on this subject has been characterised by a great deal of noise-on a previous occasion I called it huffing and puffing-but very little reasoned argument to substantiate the points he was making. I have said before and I will say it again on this occasion: In my view there is an inverse ratio between the volume of noise made in some of these speeches and in the quality of the arguments contained in them. Whereas the Deputy Leader of the Opposition boomed at us, the speakers whom I have mentioned from this side were, I believe, very effective in putting forward reasons for these two Bills. I think the Deputy Leader's contribution can be summed up like this: Some of the biggest tax avoiders in this country are not his best friends but he wants to help them by opposing this legislation.

Our argument, which was put by the honourable members for Canberra, Hunter, Maribyrnong and Sydney, is that the bottom of the harbour companies which were sold were virtually liquidated, a quasi-liquidation. We are dealing with these quasi-liquidations in this legislation. It is inconceivable in our view that when the shareholders of those companies came to sell their shares they did not know that they were taking part in a scheme which was contrived not just to avoid tax but indeed to evade tax. The community we represent has every right to expect that we should apply the same tax provisions to these contrived schemes which would apply if those companies had been liquidated. In fact under these Bills we are not imposing all of the taxes that would have been applied to shareholders in the circumstances of those companies being liquidated. We are not asking for equivalent amounts of tax to be paid which would have been paid had the companies been normally liquidated. We are recouping only the current year personal tax. We are not going back to earlier years and catching accumulated revenue profits which should have been caught.

Some say that the vendor-shareholders are having retrospective tax applied to them. Both the Government and I reject that. My conviction is that section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, including the new Part IVA which was inserted about May 1981, has always contained provisions which should have sounded alarm bells to all of those who took part in schemes to avoid tax. I repeat: There have been provisions in the tax which should have spelt out the word 'beware' to anybody involved in schemes which were indeed evasion schemes and not just tax avoidance schemes. Those provisions were dormant only because of the particular composition of the High Court of Australia at a particular time. It was inconceivable, and so it should have been, that the will of the people of this country, as expressed through this Parliament, be ignored forever by the High Court. Indeed, the High Court is not now neglecting the will of the people in these matters. I repeat that anyone involving themselves in such schemes had a duty to themselves to recognise that they were taking a risk, that they were taking part in a scheme to avoid tax and that there have been provisions in the legislation to attack just those sorts of schemes. Tax advisers, lawyers and accountants, with any ethics and pride in the work they do, would have so advised their clients to be wary.

So with these events put in this perspective it is clear that no injustice is being applied to anyone. Under this legislation $270m is owing to the Australian people by those who took that risk with their eyes wide open, a risk which they should not get away with and which they will not get away with if this legislation becomes law. There is more in this legislation which is opposed by the majority of the Australian Democrats, by Senator Harradine as well as by senators of the Liberal and the National parties than just the recoupment of $ 270m, although that is the most important part of this legislation. These Bills also remove the innocence clause, sub-section 3(12) of the Liberal legislation, and by doing so make the Liberal legislation fairer. If this legislation goes through it will mean that these companies which are caught now will go to the bottom of the harbour, just as many hundreds of other companies were. The only difference is whether the tax avoidance promoters to whom the companies were sold went through the pretence of putting the companies through a post-sale tax avoidance scheme. Usually that was merely the luck of the draw. Some promoters used the technique of post-sale tax avoidance schemes while others did not. The vendors of these companies benefited just as much as the vendors of companies that were not put through a post-sale tax avoidance scheme.

It has consistently been the policy of the Australian Labor Party, both in opposition and in government, to get rid of sub-section 3(12) from the Liberal legislation. It was part of our election commitment on tax avoidance, and we have made two unsuccessful attempts to carry out that mandate given to us in the election by the Australian people. Sub-section 3(12) is said by some to be an innocence clause. It was clearly stated by the former Treasurer last year that the disability under the former Government's legislation did not turn on guilt or innocence but on the fact that benefits were derived from the evasion of company tax. Cases presently let out by sub-section 3(12) involved conferring a benefit on vendor-shareholders. That is why the provision defies logic. It selects a particular small group of bottom of the harbour schemes and exempts them from the legislation.

I also point out that this legislation not only removes that innocence clause but it also contains machinery measures to improve the administration of existing law. So arguments from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and others, about the naming of persons and about the stripping arrangements, have all been answered already and all came up in earlier debates on this legislation in this chamber and I need not turn to them now.

In summary, a vote against these two Bills is to deny the Australian people what is owed to them, $270m, and it is to deny administrators of the existing legislation proper provisions to carry out their duties. A vote for these Bills is a vote for fairness and for good administration in tax avoidance legislation.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., the proceedings are interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106A. The proceedings may be resumed at a later hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) expresses its grave concern over the pressures put on public hospitals throughout Australia under the so-called 'free public hospital' provisions of the Government's Medicare scheme, and because of the Health Minister's coercive measures against doctors practising in public hospitals; and
(2) calls on the Government to abandon these aspects of the scheme.

Our public hospitals all around Australia are in a state of crisis which is being made worse because of the Medicare agreement between the Federal and State governments. This Medicare agreement, signed between the Federal Health Minister (Dr Blewett) and State health Ministers, provided for the State governments to give free outpatient treatment to anybody who came along to an outpatient department and free public hospital beds to anybody who was not privately insured. That was the basis of the agreement. On an annual basis it is costing the Australian taxpayer an extra $700m or so for payments to the States to provide the so-called free services. Medicare, according to the Minister for Health and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) provides free hospital beds. Now we all know that they are not really free; that they are in fact paid for partly through the Medicare levy and also through general taxation.

I also want to say something about the so-called free hospital beds in the public hospitals as they affect insured patients. A person who is quite well off and is not insured privately for private hospital treatment pays absolutely nothing for a hospital bed in a public hospital. A person with the same level of income, the same sort of expenses, who takes out private insurance cover in order to have a choice of his own doctor, could go into the very same hospital bed and be charged $80 a day through his insurance, for the same privileges that are given free to a person on the same income, uninsured. Now that is one of the most unfair aspects of this scheme and it is something that everybody who takes out private insurance ought to understand. I think they should still take out private insurance because, if they are really very ill and want to change their doctor, they will have the opportunity to do so with that private insurance. If they are not privately insured, they take the doctor that the hospital gives them and they have not any right to change that doctor if they are unhappy about the service.

There are certain aspects of the agreement as they relate to Queensland which I think I should mention. In Queensland there has been a free hospital service for over 40 years. When Medicare came in Queenslanders were asked, indeed forced, to pay the one per cent additional levy on their taxable income for a free service which they were already getting through their State Government, through their State hospital system. Queensland, under these cost-sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States, is paid on average $29 per head of its population for hospital grants versus $50 a head for the other States. So the Queenslanders for a start were totally robbed by this Medicare situation but even if it were not for that, Medicare does not pay for free hospital beds; Queensland gets $6m a month from Medicare to run its hospital system and in fact it costs Queensland 10 times that; it costs $60m a month to run the hospital system. Much the same applies in the other States. In fact the money going from the Commonwealth to the States pays only a tenth, or perhaps slightly more in other States, of the amount it actually costs to run the hospitals and provide those so-called free services.

When this deal was done, the Commonwealth assumed that there would be about a 4 per cent increase in outpatient services and that there would be a drop in privately insured patients in the private part of the hospitals of 4 per cent or 5 per cent. That is what the Commonwealth said and, of course, the reimbursements from the Commonwealth to the States depended on that sort of calculation. The Commonwealth was saying: 'Listen, States, we think that you are going to have more outpatients and we also think you are going to have a drop in your insured private patients who would, of course, provide money to the public hospital system through the private insurance funds'.

I have been doing some scouting around the public hospitals and I am told that in the teaching hospitals in Sydney there has in fact been a 15 per cent increase in outpatients. In other words, because free treatment is provided to outpatients, regardless of means, there are longer queues, more people are being seen and some of those who had to rely on outpatients before, such as pensioners , are having to go back in the queue. But, of course, there is an additional expense in meeting a 15 per cent increase in outpatient services. Perhaps more seriously for the State hospital systems, there has been a 10 per cent-not a 4 per cent as estimated by the Commonwealth-decrease in insured inpatients. In other words, the number of people taking private hospital cover for private hospital insurance has dropped by 10 per cent. It means, simply stated, that the hospitals are getting far less money out of the private health insurance funds than they were told they would get by the Commonwealth Government.

I estimate, Madam Deputy Speaker, that it will probably cost the Commonwealth on an annual basis a hundred million dollars more than was estimated to provide the so-called free hospital services. I believe that if the Commonwealth Government were fair-dinkum about the health levy and the costing that it put out originally it would need to increase the levy from one per cent up to a more likely figure of 1 1/2 or 2 per cent to come anywhere near meeting the real costs or the additional costs of its scheme. Of course, if so-called free services are offered greater numbers of people want those services and therefore additional pressures are placed on public hospitals from new patients coming in. That is not really possible in most public hospitals because they were already pretty stretched under the previous funding arrangements.

But there is a further squeeze on the public hospitals because the Government has made it less satisfactory, from a cost point of view, for people to go into private hospitals. My information, again from round the Sydney area, is that there has been about a 30 per cent drop in occupancy rates in private hospitals and those people, if they are not going into the private hospitals, are trying to get into the public hospitals and are adding to the pressure on already stretched facilities. This matter is becoming extremely serious. I quoted the other day in this House from the Age on 1 May an article headed 'Chief Surgeon Quits Over Long Delays for Patients'. The article said:

The chief of orthopaedic surgery at the Royal Melbourne Hospital, Mr Kingsley Mills, has resigned because he says he can no longer take the frustration and worry of watching patient waiting lists grow.

Mr Mills said yesterday that about 900 patients, most with painful conditions, faced indefinite delays for orthopaedic surgery at the Royal Melbourne Hospital. The list was increasing and many of the patients, needing knee and hip replacements, could not afford private hospitals.

'There is a constant anxiety at the back of your mind about it. Our registrars are getting six or more calls a day from people on the waiting list hoping something can be done for them', Mr Mills said.
'I feel I have done everything in my power to improve the situation . . . I have reached a point where I really feel I can't go any further.'
Mr Mills said that because of the hospital budget cuts, orthopaedic surgeons were now largely concerned with emergency work while patients with painful, non- fatal conditions waited indefinitely.
There was also a news report in the Melbourne Herald of 1 May, again about the Royal Melbourne Hospital. It stated:
The Royal Melbourne Hospital is 'extremely concerned' about its finances.
'Any more financial cuts and we will have to say to the State Government you come and run the place', the hospital's director of medical services, Dr G. H. Dreher, said today.
'We simply cannot absorb more financial cuts, and there has to be a point where we say we can't run it at that level.'
Dr Dreher warned that the Royal Melbourne Hospital's board of management was concerned that the hospital was 'very close' to crisis.
'We are in a situation of having to restrict everything, including our specialties such as the heart and renal areas, to meet our budgetary restraints' , Dr Dreher said.
'If we go on too long with that our standards will drop.
'We need to have a minimum number of patients so that our specialists can keep their skills at the highest pitch.'
'By reducing the amount of drugs dispensed and chasing the patients away all you do is save money but drop the standards.
'All the financial strategies we've had are to try maintaining standards.
'But we are terrible afraid that if we are pushed down any more than this we are going to eat into the area of standards.

Behind those reports, Madam Deputy Speaker, there is a tragedy which has been reported with a three months waiting list for heart surgery cases. People have been dying before they have been able to get into the hospitals for heart surgery.
