I understand in New South Wales also there is a three months waiting list for heart surgery, and that is an impossible situation in a so-called civilised country like Australia. This squeeze was already there under the cost control measures of the State governments and the way they were organising themselves. There was a pressure on the major public hospitals and they were asked by their State Ministers to reduce their costs, in some cases very seriously. They are being further squeezed by the fact that the Federal Government has seriously underestimated the revenues available from private sources and also underestimated the increase in outpatients services, with a result that additional budget cuts are being forced on the State hospitals. I understand the State Ministers, most of them from the Australian Labor Party, are very concerned about this. They are preparing submissions to the Federal Government asking for more funds urgently under the Medicare arrangements to try to overcome some of these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what we have been saying all the time.

—That is exactly it. As the honourable member for McPherson says, we have been saying this throughout. I advise the House that the motion I put down today has been slightly amended but it was actually put down in May of last year , where we forecast, and even before that in the Medicare debate in September last year, that these things would happen. The Minister said that they would not happen, but we now see them tragically happening. If that were not enough, the Minister has added insult to injury by his attacks on the hospital doctors.

SPEECH.PARA: I had no latitude as to when the Government would bring this motion on although it is on the Notice Paper for General Business on Thursday. I regret that the Minister is overseas, but I have to say these things here and now. The present Minister for Health is the first Minister for Health in the history of Australia to bring on a doctors' strike. We warned the Minister in the Medicare debate last year that by trying to bring in direct Federal control of all the contracts of doctors in the public hospitals of Australia he was touching a very sensitive nerve. The doctors in these hospitals are very independent people. They are the sort of people who have trained for many, many years.

Surgeons, for example, spend six years in medical school; five years in some cases. They spend another seven years or so in training before they are able to practise fully as surgeons. They are people who are independent private, you might say, small businessmen. They are people who have to maintain their own skills. They are people who have to worry about the state of their eyesight, the steadiness of their hand. They are people whose working life is limited by their capacity to carry out their extraordinarily skilled task on which lives depend. These are very fiercely independent people, and this Minister for Health in his Bill last year in trying to control absolutely in some trade union fashion the incomes and the conditions of service that these doctors had negotiated with their hospitals, put them into such a state of mind that they actually went on strike, for the very first time in Australia's history, and this was a further burden on a hospital system which was already seriously overstrained.

I have raised this matter many times in the House already. The reasons given by the Minister were spurious. The Minister claimed that he was only wanting to control the costs of diagnostic specialists operating their private practices through the public hospitals. He said that that was his only intention. Yet we found out that in a speech to the Doctors Reform Society he had disclosed that at a State Ministers conference last year it had been decided to begin with the diagnostic services and to extend the control to other specialties in due course . The surgeons and other specialists believed that they had been cheated, that they had been given totally incorrect information.

I believe that from the beginning the Minister had the intention of controlling all medical specialties, their contracts, their fees and producing the state of mediocrity where the very best surgeon at the height of his powers would be able to charge no more, and no less, than the most recently graduated surgeon or the person who was not capable of carrying out extremely highly skilled operations. If that is the sort of health care that this Minister has in mind for Australia he ought to be open about it. The doctors believe that they now see that as his objective and that is why they have objected so strongly and that is why they went on strike for the very first time in Australia.

That strike, and there is a threat still over us because the matter has not been resolved, is now with the Penington Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. There is a threat still that there will be further disruptions. Those disruptions are caused by the actions of the Minister for Health. Those actions make the running of the hospital systems, which are already under extreme pressure with people dying on the waiting lists for heart surgery and people with painful orthopaedic conditions waiting up to two years for surgery, very difficult. The condition of all these people will be made worse if there is any return of that kind of industrial difficulty.

What do we have from the Health Minister, who is supposed to be concerned about bringing some calm into this situation? I have the most scandalous report from the Brisbane Sun of 29 April. It is really an unbelievable report but unfortunately I have to make this information available to the House because it gives some indication of the thinking behind these attacks on the doctors. The report is of the Health Ministers Conference in Melbourne recently, and states:
It was a big night for Dr Blewett.
After a day of discussions at a Health Ministers' conference in Melbourne, he was taking out the State ministers and directors general for a night on the town .
And what better place to choose than a theatre restaurant called-The Last Laugh .
It was certainly the night Dr Blewett was going to have the last laugh over Medicare.
On the bus journey back to the palatial Windsor Hotel, Dr Blewett's press secretary went around handing song sheets to each of the Ministers.

Now I have checked this out to see whether Dr Blewett was actually present on the bus and I am informed that whilst a school bus was provided to take the other Ministers back to the Windsor Dr Blewett indeed was taken back in a Government car. The report continues:
And then the bus load of the country's top health dignitaries was told to join in the sing-along to the tune of 'O' Christmas Tree, O' Christmas Tree'. This is the wording of the song:
O' AMA, O' AMA,
How ever green your bank notes,
From Vaucluse Heights to Toorak,
There's nothing like being a filthy rich quack.
O' AMA, O' AMA,
Neil Blewett says you're bastards,
With lots of money,
In tax lurks,
To keep up the payments,
On the Mercs.
And it goes on for four more verses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said that?

—This song sheet was handed out by a member of the Minister's staff, according to this newspaper report. I have checked with one of those present as to whether this happened. I checked whether Dr Blewett himself was personally there. He was not. The report goes on to say that the other Health Ministers seemed to think that it was in poor taste and it was mainly Dr Blewett's staff who did all the singing. Now that indicates, I am afraid, an underlying view of the medical profession and gives an insight, if not immediately and clearly shown by the Minister on this particular occasion, at least shown by the staff of the Minister's office, into the kind of discussions that must go on about this profession within the Minister's office. If, indeed, this is the attitude that is taken to a profession that we, our families and our children depend on for our health and which runs the hospitals throughout Australia under extremely difficult conditions and if the Federal Health Minister and his staff think and act in this way in relation to a highly honoured profession, heaven help Australia, and heaven help the future of its health. I think that the House ought to be shocked at this. I think that it is sufficient for the Prime Minister to call for a report from Dr Blewett as to whether this is the way his staff members treat the medical profession, the way they think about it or whether it is the way he thinks about it.
—Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed. Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), as Acting Minister, I welcome this opportunity to join in the debate on the free public hospital provisions of the Government's Medicare scheme. I want to begin by expressing my disappointment at the tone taken by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I think that the idea that the Government wanted to coerce doctors into mediocrity is an absurdity which is unworthy of the honourable member. It traduces the Government , quite unjustly, and it runs contrary to common sense. It was a measure of the paucity of the case that he had to offer that he had to rely for the bulk of his argument on the account in the Brisbane Sunday Telegraph of 29 April of high jinks that are alleged to have occurred in the bus after the Health Ministers Conference in Melbourne.
—Did they occur?

—I have no idea whether they occurred; it sounds like a bit of extracurricular activity and it has no policy significance whatever. It has nothing whatever to do with the general thrust of what this debate ought to be about. I am grateful anyway for the opportunity that is provided for me to point out the aims and the virtues of Medicare and to expose the weakness of the Opposition's position on health care policies. Members of the Opposition came into government in 1975 pledging to preserve Medibank but almost immediately repudiated that undertaking as they did to so many others. The previous Government had almost as many Health Ministers as it did health schemes. At the end of more than seven years of reactionary and contradictory health policies, its only achievement was to leave nearly two million people without access to health services. Two million people who could not afford private health cover were not covered by any form of government assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government sought to overcome this intolerable situation by introducing Medicare, a health scheme which provides basic medical and hospital treatment to all Australians regardless of their insurance status or their financial means. My colleagues and I believe that it is a fundamental human right that every person should be eligible for medical and hospital services based on his or her health needs. Medicare guarantees that right for every Australian. For all of the Opposition's cheap rhetoric, its gimcrack and opportunistic politicking and its attempts at cheap point-scoring, there is one unassailable fact which it must always recognise: The Government has been able to achieve in one year what it was not able to achieve in seven years-a simple, fair and affordable health scheme which covers all Australians. The Opposition took more positions than the Kamasutra describes in that seven-year period in trying to work out an appropriate health scheme for Australia. There was no security because when Medibank Mark 3, Mark 4 or Mark 5 came in, there was no guarantee how long it was going to last. This lack of certainty was one of the most appalling things in the previous Government.

What is the substance of the motion before us today? How will the introduction of Medicare create this so-called pressure on the public hospital system? Does the honourable member for Mackellar feel that a change in the health insurance arrangements will somehow increase morbidity and result in greater utilisation of hospitals? Perhaps he feels that Medicare will make doctors view their patients differently so that they admit patients to hospitals more often, or for longer periods. Perhaps he feels that Medicare will lead to a significant reduction in the number of public hospital beds available, or could it be, as indeed he stressed, that he sees Medicare leading to a substantial shift from the treatment of patients in private hospitals towards public hospitals?

As it happens none of these trends is likely. I will explain the facts about hospital utilisation in this country to expose the weakness of the logic in the motion. On the first point it is clearly nonsense to suggest that it is the availability of health insurance rather than the state of their health that determines whether patients become hospital cases. One could put a stronger case ; that chopping and changing policies lead to increasing anxiety and debility. On this basis the previous Government deserves the strongest censure because of its many changes to the health scheme over seven years.

It is also nonsense to suggest that people will go to hospital simply because a free service is offered; people are admitted to hospital on the basis of their condition. If there is no increase in the incidence of illness there is no reason to suppose that there will be any increased pressure on hospital facilities. It is true that there has been a general increase in the utilisation of hospitals over the past decade, but this has been a steady increase. It has been related more to population growth and to the aging of the population than to any other factor. It has been an increase quite independent of any changes in health insurance arrangements, including the introduction of Medibank in 1975. It is expected that the increase will continue in the future and continue to be related to population growth rather than the type of health scheme.

The second proposition was that the increased pressure would result from changing attitudes by doctors who will suddenly admit patients for appendicectomies or tonsillectomies where previously they would not have done so . After all, it is the doctors, not the patients, who admit people to hospital and determine their length of stay. If the Opposition believes that the increased pressure on hospitals will come from this source then it clearly has a lesser view of the medical profession than the Government has. It is quite insulting to most of the profession to suggest that they would admit patients for any reasons other than medical need or to prolong the stay of their patients simply because the accommodation is 'free'.

The Government does not believe that the medical profession would act irresponsibly by unnecessarily admitting patients or keeping them in hospital longer than needed. We do not believe that there is any real risk of the additional pressure being generated from this source. Perhaps the increased pressure could come from a reduction in the number of public hospital beds available. I am glad to report to the House that the introduction of Medicare on 1 February this year did not herald any massive reduction in the number of public hospital beds in Australia, nor am I aware of any plans to reduce it in the future. It should be recognised that by international comparison Australia has a high ratio of hospital beds to population, 6.2 beds per thousand of population, while the generally accepted international average is 4.5 beds per thousand population.

We also have an unusually high proportion of medical practitioners, one of the highest in the world, I think, second only to that of the United States. The United States has one doctor for every 480 people; we have one to 500; Canada has one to 540 and the United Kingdom has one to 600. We are also fortunate that as a nation we seem to be a good deal healthier than many countries with fewer hospital beds. I make the general observation that on average the occupancy rate of public hospitals throughout Australia in 1982-83 was around the two-thirds mark, although I accept that this has not been equitably distributed. For example, there are some disadvantaged areas where there are fewer hospitals and fewer beds pro rata and correspondingly higher pressure. I refer to the western suburbs of Melbourne-the area that I represent-and the western suburbs of Sydney .

Let me give the figures for the elective surgery waiting list at the Western General Hospital in Melbourne in the electorate of Gellibrand. In March 1983 there were 670 on the waiting list; in September 1983, 707; and in March 1984 after Medicare had been introduced the figure had fallen to 666. So in an area where there is great pressure, far above the national average, the figures are lower than when the Fraser Government went out of office. Overall there is spare capacity in the public hospital system, but it will require some redistribution of resources by the various State governments. If the beds are redistributed the increased pressure on public hospitals will come from a shift away from the private hospital system, but surely this would be a natural operation of the law of supply and demand which should be dear to the heart of the honourable member for MacKellar.

It is true that we are anticipating a change in the mix of patients being treated in public hospitals but treating more public patients in public hospitals does not automatically imply a greater utilisation overall of public hospitals. What it means is that there is a change in insurance status of those patients being treated within the public hospital system. The Federal and State governments were aware of this likely change in proportionality and made appropriate financial arrangements in the Medicare agreement to cover it. There is also provision within the agreement to vary the estimated shift between public and private patients should actual demand vary significantly from the original estimates. As yet no firm figures on the shift are available from the States. There are no early indications that our original estimates were wrong.

The Government was also conscious of the impact that Medicare would have on private health insurance and, through it, on the private hospital system. We took deliberate and careful action to ensure the viability of private health funds and, in so doing, to guarantee the continuity of the private hospital system. Whilst we regard basic health services as a fundamental right which must be freely available for all, we acknowledge the role that must exist for the private hospital system.

This Government will ensure that those who wish to exercise their right to be treated in a private hospital will not be denied proper access. People wish to retain private hospital insurance for a number of reasons. In recognising that fact the Government took steps in its Medicare planning to ensure that the cost of private health insurance was not beyond the reach of those who wanted it. The most notable of these steps was the substantial reduction in the cost of public hospital accommodation for patients choosing treatment as private patients in public hospitals; it went from about $130 a day to only $80. This allowed health funds to reduce significantly the rates for their basic hospital tables and ensured continued access to private health insurance for those who wanted it.

Now there are as yet no firm figures on the numbers of people who have retained their private health insurance but there is some indication that the health funds have not lost as many members as they had first estimated. The Launceston Examiner on 4 May reported that a major health fund in that State, St Lukes, had lost only 9 per cent of its members since the introduction of Medicare rather than the 22 per cent which was at first estimated. I think it is reasonably clear that the personal reasons which lead people to take out private health insurance have not significantly changed and that there will continue to be a strong demand for private hospital services in this country.

The honourable member for Mackellar claims that the Government's Medicare estimates were wrong, that we have seriously under-estimated the use of public hospital outpatients departments. He mentioned this on Tuesday in his speech on the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Amendment Bill 1984. He repeated today the phrase that he had been 'scouting around the public hospitals', but sometimes this impressionistic and anecdotal treatment may be wrong. He is able to point to some harsh cases, where people have been waiting for a long time for cardiac surgery. Has that happened overnight? Is it only a recent phenomenon?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not suggest that; it is getting worse.
—Of course you did not. It is a chronic situation because of the shortage of particular skills in particular disciplines, and that is something--
—Not orthopaedics.

—Certainly in the case of the cardiac area those delays are very long term. It is quite clear that the Opposition is using every tactic to try to obstruct the successful implementation of Medicare, one of the great triumphs of this Government and one of the great achievements of the Minister for Health. Opposition members simply will not accept that it is a well planned, well received social reform and they seem intent on trying to discredit it at every opportunity. Their plans have so far not succeeded, nor will they. At no time during any debates on Medicare has the Opposition made any constructive suggestion or offered any viable alternative to the scheme. The people of Australia deserve better health policies than those inflicted under the previous Government. Medicare will meet the people's needs. I have the utmost confidence in the public hospital system and its ability to maintain high quality services to the people of Australia. The Opposition's scare tactics bring it great discredit.
— The Minister's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate was called on by the Government and we on this side of the House are only too happy to oblige in any debate that concerns health care in this country and Medicare in particular. What we are talking about today, in particular, is the place of doctors and hospitals in the health system. I want to look first at that part of the debate about the coercive measures that are being used and have been used against doctors in this country. I think it first instructs us to look at what the Government was trying to do in those months leading up to Medicare and then in that recent dispute between the Government and the diagnostic specialists in public hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened, in fact, as we all know now, is that the Government backed down in the end in that dispute. It backed down because in many cases it was on fragile ground in its arguments and, of course, it also backed down to clear the decks for an early election. 'Let us have nothing contentious' says the Government. 'Let us put all the contentious things to one side, like the assets tests and disputes with doctors. Let us soften it up a bit and put it to one side, we will not have any of those decisions. Let us get the election out of the way soon'. So that is the other reason that the Government backed down, and it was not only a decision by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who seemed fairly firm that he was going to pursue it to the end. It was intervention by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in exactly the same way as he intervened with his Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) when it came to contentious issues about the assets test, which was abandoned and put to a committee.

We have got to look at why the diagnostic specialists were objecting. They were objecting because their future was being put in the hands of one man, a Minister in whom they had no confidence. They were being denied any appeal or any arbitration. The very principles that the Government is always espousing as being so essential in industrial disputes were being denied to the specialists in public hospitals. Why would they not object? A highly competitive, highly individual, highly professional group of people in the Australian community were being put down by the Minister into some amorphous classification where their very rights were being eroded. In fact, in some cases, they had no rights at all .

It is not as though no restraint was being shown in public hospitals. As far as I know the diagnostic specialists were sticking to the scheduled fee, almost without exception, throughout Australia and in all cases were working under contracts between themselves and the hospitals. The hospitals, to a large extent , of course, were controlled by the State governments, and it may be that to which this centralised and socialistic Government was objecting. It wanted a piece of the action, but we have to ask the question: Why not let continue the system of contracts between the doctors and the public hospitals? In particular, why not allow the Penington Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals to come forward with its recommendations before the Minister's philosophy was imposed on the specialists? In the event, the Minister backed down, after intervention by the Prime Minister and assistance by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). The Government has now agreed to wait until the Penington inquiry reports, and I will come back to the Penington inquiry in a moment.

One of the things that I think needs repeating during this debate on health care is the philosophy and the attitude of the Minister. During the Medicare debate and recently during the debate over specialists in public hospitals he compared the doctors to the Builders Labourers Federation. Apart from the fact that the doctors are savers and preventers and builders labourers are thugs and destroyers, that statement indicates the contempt that the Minister has for the private practitioners and for private enterprise in this country, and he should not be allowed to forget it. The Minister's attitude to health care is clearly expressed in the speech that he made to the Australian Hospital Association in Adelaide in 1982. He said:
The Party--
That is the Labor Party-

has put aside any primary emphasis on salaried or capitation systems in pragmatic recognition of the prevailing culture and attitudes in this society and in its effort to secure widespread community support for its program. Private fee-for-service medicine is deeply entrenched in Australian society,-
I am glad he recognised that at least. He goes on:

. . . strongly defended by the medical profession and favourably evaluated by the population at large. That is a fact of life and whatever changes we desire in that system will have to take place gradually and incrementally.

What is now clear to the profession and, I think, becoming much clearer to the great bulk of the Australian people, is that he has not put his philosophy to one side but is just approaching his objective from a different direction and the objective is the socialisation of medicine in this country. Let me turn for a moment to the Penington inquiry. On 24 January this year, just prior to the introduction of Medicare, the inquiry was announced by the Minister for Health. It is worth quoting from a part of the terms of reference. It reads:

The Committee shall inquire into and report on existing administrative and financial arrangement for providing medical services to private patients in public hospitals in the States and Territories, with particular reference to the provision of certain prescribed diagnostic services. In particular, the Committee will consider mechanisms for review or appeal in relation to arrangements determined by the Minister for Health.

The inquiry was set up to examine the role of diagnostic specialists in public hospitals. Having set up the inquiry, the Minister goes on to impose section 17 on the profession, regardless of the fact that the inquiry had been set up and was under way. It is very difficult to understand, and I would be very happy if someone on the Government side could explain, why the Government set up an inquiry and then ignored the fact that it had set it up. It will ignore the report that is yet to come in and will go ahead, in a very stupid and pigheaded fashion, to try to impose on the medical profession conditions which an inquiry has been set up to look into. It must have given the committee great confidence to be set up and then have the ground cut from under its feet. But as far as the Penington inquiry is concerned, of course, the conditions for diagnostic specialists are now back in its court, to a large extent, and we look forward to its report, I think are at the end of June.

Let me turn to the role of hospitals in the health care system. There is no doubt, despite what the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) said in his previous speech, that Medicare has been an assault, and is an assault, on the private hospital system in this country. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) cited figures from some public hospitals to show the strain they are under. But many private hospitals in this country are going out of business. The smaller country hospitals are under threat, and it is not only the smaller country hospitals. In my own area let me give examples of two out of three private hospitals. In one of them the daily average occupancy has dropped to 18 per cent, and of course no hospital, no business, can continue under such conditions. In another hospital in my own area the occupancy rate has dropped to 54 per cent-somewhat better than 18 per cent-but certainly hardly in the black. These private hospitals simply cannot survive under this system and the reason is that the balance of funding has been changed in favour of the public hospitals.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is bad, is it?

—Yes, it is bad, and if the Minister cannot understand that he should not be sitting on the front bench because what he is doing is putting pressure on all the public institutions while all the money and all the facilities that are in the private institutions are lying idle, and he should be able to understand that. We will reach a position where the Government will be forced to pour more and more money into public hospitals while at the same time half the private hospital facilities in this country will be lying idle. I have given two very good examples. I expect the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who will be speaking shortly, to give other examples.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no use getting up and blandly saying that there is no evidence that the private hospital system is being underused; it is happening all around this country while the public hospital system is under great pressure and, in some areas, in a state of crisis. We will see, to relieve that pressure on public hospitals, more and more public money going into them, great monuments to the Minister's ego, while the private hospital system continues to suffer. It would seem that there is a good case for not building any more public hospitals, certainly in certain areas, but contracting out to the private hospitals the public patients, which would be cheaper and more efficient and would use the facilities that are already in existence.

We have to ask ourselves what sort of a health system we want in this country. It is quite clear, from this side of the House, that we want a system that is based, firstly, on freedom of choice; secondly, on a system that restores the doctor-patient relationship; and, thirdly, a system in which private hospitals are encouraged to play a significant part. Let me deal briefly with our view on the freedom of choice. At the moment a one per cent levy is paid, whether people like it or not. How long will we be able to hold the levy at that rate? Why do we not allow people to make their own arrangements? They can pay the levy if they wish or they can go into some private insurance system. Why cannot we allow gap insurance instead of forcing bulk billing on this nation?

Our Government is always talking about the rights of the individual but when those rights-that is, the freedom of choice-conflict with some of its own philosophies about socialism then it is the rights of the individual that go out the window and a centralist-socialist philosophy that predominates. We want to see the restoration of doctors to their rightful place in the health system, the restoration of that close relationship between doctors and patients and the removal of the intrusion of the Government into that relationship. We should stop threatening doctors and encourage them instead to play their part. We have to ask, in view of the honourable member for Mackellar's statement about the song that certainly the Minister for Health's staff were singing in a bus, why the Minister hates private doctors. In every utterance and every philosophy of the health system of this country that is becoming more and more clear. But it is not just the specialists he is after, it is the medical profession as well.

Private hospitals must be encouraged. We must stop duplicating the resources that are scattered around this country. Private hospitals are going broke or standing half empty while we are being asked to contribute more and more to the public hospital system. We do not want to go down the United Kingdom path. That has failed, and in fact one of the biggest growth industries in the United Kingdom right now is putting money back into private health care because the public system has failed, and that is the dead-end track that we are going down. I stand here unashamedly putting the case forward for private enterprise in our health care system, and this Minister and this Government have set out to destroy that system. I am here to defend the system, to speak in favour of a better health system and to improve the future and the right of choice for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the Acting Minister for Health (Mr Barry Jones) in rejecting this motion. I join with him also in expressing disappointment at the speech of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) . It was at least in part a rehash of a speech which he made on Tuesday, and I suggest to him that the additional material certainly did not improve it. It was a speech that was characterised by a mean misrepresentation of the excellent work of this Government and the excellent work of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). It was a speech which was characterised by a lack of concern for the disadvantaged people in our community, the 1.8 million people who even in January of this year after the disadvantaged health care card was introduced were still not covered.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up a number of matters that were raised during the debate by the honourable member for Mackellar and the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White). The honourable member for Mackellar raised the question of the negotiation of the agreement with the States. He referred to that process the other night as haggling with the States. In fact they were proper discussions and a satisfactory agreement was reached. The honourable member referred in particular to Queensland, and the proof of the pudding is in the eating, because Queensland agreed. The Premier of Queensland, Premier Bjelke-Petersen, signed that agreement, and why should he not have signed it? He knew-and the honourable member for Mackellar also knows, although he will not admit it-that Queensland is better off under Medicare. Queensland received additional funding because it was in a special situation because of its free hospital system introduced by a Labor Government, in Queensland many years ago. Queensland is better off under Medicare than under the Liberal health scheme, its predecessor. The Premier of Queensland signed that agreement because he knew that, and he certainly knows when he is on a winner. He is one person in this country who certainly does, and he went ahead and he signed that agreement.

The honourable member for Mackellar also raised, quite correctly, the basis of the agreement, the expected 4 per cent drop in revenue which was based on an expected 4 per cent growth in outpatient services and an expected 4 per cent drop in the number of private patients in public hospitals. During this debate he suggested different figures. He has obtained these figures on the basis of scouting around hospitals in Sydney and other places, but I would point out-the Acting Minister pointed out in the debate that anecdotal type evidence is one thing and proper statistical evidence another-that the scheme has been operating for less than four months. For heaven's sake let it settle down. If we are to have figures let us have figures collected on a proper objective basis and over a proper period. I concede to the honourable member for MacKellar that maybe the patterns will be different from those anticipated. Maybe they will. But let us have proper figures collected over a proper period and give Medicare a chance to settle down.

The honourable member for MacKellar also expressed great concern for privately insured patients in public hospitals, pointing out that they are required to pay , or at least their funds pay on their behalf, $80 a day. He did not say that the present Government has reduced this charge down from $120 a day, and there are a number of other things he did not say in his comparison of the Medicare patient and the-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still $80 different.

—Right, but the honourable member should give credit too where it is due . In his comparison of the private patient and the Medicare patient there are number of things he did not say. Certainly the Medicare patient enjoys a free hospital bed but as the honourable member said later during his speech, in fact it is not 'free'; there is no such thing as a free hospital bed because somebody pays in the process. In fact the Medicare patient has, of course, paid for it in his Medicare levy.

SPEECH.PARA: The private patient, as I mentioned before, joins a fund by choice and his fund pays on his behalf $80 a day; it is down from $120. Of course, the additional service that he gets in that process is his choice of doctor. Now if he wishes to choose his doctor he then chooses to join a fund and gets an additional benefit. It is only reasonable that he should be expected to pay for it. The attack which the honourable member has made on free beds I have dealt with in part, but I should point out that many of the things that he said are illustrative of the great philosophical difference between those on the Opposition side of the House and we in the Government.

Of course there is no such thing as a free hospital bed. Somebody has to pay sooner or later. But whether we allocate health care on the basis of need for that care, or on the basis of ability to pay for that care, appears to me to be the great difference between those in the Opposition and those in the Government . We believe that health care should be allocated on the basis of need for that care. Those on the Opposition side clearly believe that it should be allocated on the basis of the ability of the patient to pay. We believe the system that pays for care by a levy related to income, in other words capacity to pay through income and a levy based on that income, is a much fairer system.

The honourable member for MacKellar referred to pressures that he believes will be applied to public hospitals because of these free services and he refers also to pressure which he believes will be applied to public hospitals as a result of a reduced occupancy rate in private hospitals.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: MADAM DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is now 1.45 p.m. In accordance with standing order 109 as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr John Brown) agreed to:
That the time for the discussion of Notice No. 1 General Business be extended until 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. As I was just saying, one can test those assertions in an historical sense by looking at what happened to occupancy rates and bed days over the period of the original Medibank and in the years subsequent to it. I think that kind of historical perspective is also quite useful because there has been a great deal of misinformation about the original Medibank scheme, as distinct from Medicare.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are that in 1975 there was no significant shift towards public hospitals. The prophets of doom did not see the end of the private health insurance companies as they predicted. There was indeed a shift within the public hospital sector between private and public but not a significant increase in the utilisation of public hospitals. The major growth under Medibank was the diagnostic specialties over which the government is seeking to implement some measure of control through section 17, to which I hope to refer shortly.

It is a matter of people's tastes really dictating whether or not they want private hospital insurance. In the Medibank period people's taste did not alter significantly and nor is it expected to do so under Medicare. The change in health insurance arrangements does not really lead to increased utilisation of hospital services at least as evidenced by the figures during that time which, as the Acting Minister mentioned, showed a steady increase related to population , but a steady increase despite those repeated changes, almost annual changes, to health insurance arrangements since 1975. The peak year for bed days in public hospitals was in 1978-79, well after the Liberals had destroyed the original Medibank and of course during one of the many Fraser health schemes.

The private hospital statistics are even more revealing. There was a drop of only 100,000 bed days, not a significant drop, at the introduction of Medibank. There was a continuation of this decline under the Fraser health policies and in fact private hospital bed days reached their low point in 1979-80, again under one of the Fraser health schemes; but the main point is that the number of bed days has remained reasonably constant, indicating a fairly stable demand for private hospitals despite successive changes to health schemes. The implication is that if private hospital demand is reasonably constant then there should not be any additional pressures on public hospitals.

The honourable member for McPherson and the honourable member for Mackellar made some reference to section 17, and I want to put the record straight there too. I think it should be clearly understood that section 17 of the Health Insurance Act refers to diagnostic specialists only in public hospitals-not all specialists. Therefore, there is absolutely no reason why other specialists would consider leaving the public hospital system. If one wants to defend section 17 one has only to look at a whole range of reports talking about the need to control specialist areas. I refer to the high cost of the high technology services and those with little patient contact, those services that are doctor generated rather than patient initiated. Honourable members ought to read the reports that have been calling for this control for years.

One would have expected also during the course of this debate at least some recognition of the concessions that have been made by the Government to meet the reasonable concerns of the medical profession. The Government has amended the original guidelines, it has set up the Penington Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals and it has amended the Act to allow parliamentary scrutiny. The Government has reached a compromise position with the doctors; they are working together on a submission to go to the Penington inquiry. They are having their first meeting tomorrow in Sydney. Penington will formalise the conditions under which doctors operate private practice in public hospitals and will provide a sound basis on which doctors will be in a position to base their hospital practice. Much of the Opposition's argument is that there will be an increase of public patients in public hospitals. Doctors have never indicated that they would not treat public patients; rather they have said they would withdraw from private practice in public hospitals.

If the recent dispute has shown anything at all it has shown that doctors are responsive to public opinion. If the public requires treatment by doctors in public hospitals we have faith in the medical profession to provide that treatment. People in the Opposition might want chaos and strife. They think that they can get a bit of political advantage out of doctors' strikes, but we certainly do not and we do not think that the bulk of the medical profession does either.

This is a motion of a dedicated privateer, the leader of the Thredbo summit session on privatisation. This man wants to privatise Medibank Private, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and Trans Australia Airlines and sell Telecom and, as a long term goal, he believes that schools and airports and hospitals should be privatised. He ignores the needs of the disadvantaged and the needs of that 20 per cent of the population who need free care because they cannot pay for it. The disadvantaged health care card, under the former Government, was a failure. Do honourable members remember the 1.8 million people who had no cover back in January? This motion ignores any proper criterion for treatment, and the only proper criterion for treatment is the health needs of the patient. For heaven's sake, hospitals are not motels; they are places for sick people. People do not go along and book themselves into a hospital. They have to be referred and admitted, and the criterion on which people are referred and admitted is, of course, their health needs and so it should be. It should not be their ability to pay.

The motion also ignores the removal of pressure from the public hospital systems in that bad debts no longer have to be chased. In that sense, far from imposing a pressure in the terms that the motion suggests, Medicare has removed pressure from public hospitals and now, at last, we have a universal publicly funded and very popular health scheme supported by 57 per cent of the population . In fact, the levy was supported by 42 per cent of people who voted for Opposition candidates, and honourable members opposite should not forget that. People have wanted the scheme for many years. It is a scheme which has been promised by the Labor Party since 1969, and I am proud that it is in place less than 11 months after this Government was elected. It is one policy that has been adhered to by the Labor Party over all those years and has been so solidly supported by the population following the Nimmo report, the report of the Commonwealth Committee of Inquiry into Health Insurance. It is one of the truly great achievements of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has elapsed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this motion so ably put by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I think we should not be under any illusions. We are talking about Medicare and Medicare is nothing more and nothing less than the nationalisation of health. It seems that this Government has learnt nothing from the overseas experience, the experience in Britain in particular, and I wonder if there is anyone in this House who has not met an English doctor who left Britain for one reason and one reason only, and that was to get away from its national health service.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt, and it is already starting to appear, that there will be long delays for non-emergency surgery, and these delays will increase. Under this nationalisation of health we are seeing bulk billing. We have seen the Government trying to force bulk billing on doctors. And what does bulk billing do? It destroys the doctor-patient relationship. We are also told that it probably will promote over-servicing, but the Government has a great solution to that; we will have a computer surveillance system. I am sure that the Acting Minister for Health (Mr Barry Jones), who is also Minister for Science and Technology, would love this as it will be a new sunrise industry. He might even feel that he has picked a winner this time, too.

I think the Minister missed the point completely by not reading the motion. He was talking about the number of beds in hospitals still being utilised at the same sort of rate, but the point he missed was that the motion related to public wards, not to hospitals in toto. I think the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) has already instanced many examples of where private hospitals are now losing their numbers, and we are seeing the pressure coming on to public wards.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free) seems to miss a point too when he was saying that we should let this system have a go until we have the statistics . I would say to him quite plainly. If something is going off the track, do we wait until we get statistics to tell us it is wrong before we do anything to try to correct it? He was also, I think, quite mistaken when he said something about section 17 not covering all diagnostic specialists. It certainly does. I think it is a very timely debate brought on by the honourable member for Mackellar to see how Medicare, after three months of operation is progressing.

I turn now to some of the problems in the State of Victoria. Just prior to Medicare, the State Labor Government forced a 1.5 per cent cut in the funding to all hospitals, and on top of it it forced the hospitals to revert to a 38-hour week. Honourable members can imagine what the combination of cutting the working hours of staff and the funds has done to the Victorian hospitals. So, what have we already emerging under Medicare? I think it could be summed up very simply as a situation where we now have unlimited access to public beds, to public wards, and we still have hospitals working with limited funds. I do not think it takes much to work out what problems this will create. There is no doubt that it is increasing demand for public wards which still have the same limited funds. I think the motion is very timely when it says that we express our grave concern over the pressures put on public hospitals throughout Australia under the so- called free public hospital provisions of the Government's Medicare scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you have a free public hospital?

—The honourable member should ask the honourable member for Macquarie; he might know what 'free' means. And what are the results of these pressures? We have a problem already growing in the areas of elective or chronic surgery, surgery that is necessary but not an emergency measure. I refer to surgery related to varicose veins or hip joints replacement, surgery that to the people who have it relieves a lot of pain, but, I guess people can say, is not an emergency measure.

SPEECH.PARA: I can give an example of quite a reasonable size hospital in my electorate that has already run out of funds for elective surgery. For non-urgent surgery there is now a complete shut-down. There will be no elective surgery for the rest of the financial year because the hospital has run out of funds.

At another hospital in my electorate, the State Government has limited the funds for the provision of free glasses for pensioners, so we have cut out the free glasses for pensioners in this hospital, but at the same time the State Government has brought in another scheme for subsidised dentures for pensioners. It seems strange that pensioners can have false teeth but cannot get free spectacles. In other words, pensioners are allowed to eat but they are not allowed to see.

In another hospital in Wannon, a smaller one, patients are continuing to have private cover but they are going into the public wards because they know they will get their own doctor because there is only one doctor in the town. So what are they doing? They are keeping that 35 days of private cover up their sleeve, just in case they should have to be transferred to a bigger hospital. One can imagine the pressure this is putting on that small private hospital. As I have said, I think the whole point could be summed up by saying that under the new Medicare proposal we have unlimited access to public wards and limited funds to try to keep them running.

Mr Speaker, as my time is running out I will just very quickly touch on what I think is the greatest bit of propaganda I have ever seen. I would call it the great con of 1984. I am referring, of course, to this letter which is signed ' Bob Hawke'. The letter states:
To my fellow Australians.
We have all suffered from a health insurance system which is both too expensive and too complicated. So much so that for two million Australians health insurance was simply out of the question.

I think we ought to lay this one to rest once and for all. There is a very good reason why these two million were not insured. Many of them would not have been, not because they could not afford it but, with the free hospitals in Queensland, why bother? We had many young people who believed they were fit and well and healthy and did not need insurance. I think under the previous system there was no doubt that anyone would ever be refused health care. This letter goes on to say that Medicare is not only a cheaper and simpler system but it is also fairer . I defy the Government to prove that it will be cheaper in the long run. I think I would just label this letter as the great con of 1984 and I think the Government will rue the day that it allowed this letter to be issued in the name of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).
