—I address my question to the Minister for Defence. Were the A4 aircraft of the Royal New Zealand Air Force used in the fighter defence of Australia in Operation Pitch Black 84-1 last week together with elements of the United States Air Force the same as the A4s of the Fleet Air Arm of the Royal Australian Navy which are about to be scrapped? Can the Minister be sure that the Mirage aircraft now in operation, subject to some operational difficulties, will not suffer some similar grounding requirement if there should be an outbreak of any sort of hostility which would require a fighter defence and that A4s might not again be required? In the light of these circumstances, will he review his decision to scrap the A4s and the Trackers of the Fleet Air Arm, even though they might have to operate from ground bases, so that at least we can be dependent on aircraft of the Royal Australian Air Force or the Royal Australian Navy instead of on elements of the Royal New Zealand Air Force and the United States Air Force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite strange to ask whether or not the elements of an exercise constitute one form of the forces involved or another. Exercise Pitch Black is an annual exercise which is conducted to test defence. This exercise simulates a defence situation in Darwin. It is and has been the practice of the Royal Australian Air Force under successive governments, in respect of problems which affect safety, for aircraft to be grounded during the period under which an examination of the aircraft takes place to ensure the safety of those who fly them and other personnel. I hope that the right honourable gentleman is not suggesting that that practice should cease. I will not give any guarantees that aircraft will not be grounded in the future for safety reasons.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts relating to Australia's defence capabilities and to our future air defence are that we are currently initiating a program whereby the FA18 aircraft is about to come into service with the Royal Australian Air Force. I have been advised that it is considered that the Mirage aircraft will be satisfactory and will meet the requirements of the Royal Australian Air Force for air defence, given our strategic situation, until such time as the FA18 is in service. It is important-I think that even the Opposition would subscribe to this fact-that, given the strategic situation, we devote the resources that are available to us to the introduction of the FA18 as quickly and as efficiently as possible and to the training and the provision of support services which are needed. If the right honourable gentleman is suggesting that we should delay the introduction of the FA18 I suggest that he is a fool and the Opposition's defence policies are completely incompetent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware of the recent campaign conducted by the Australian Union of Students highlighting issues in tertiary education? Will the Minister inform the House of the Government's policy in relation to tertiary education participation , educational opportunity and living allowances for students?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I acknowledge his great interest in this matter and, particularly, his interest in the Bendigo College of Advanced Education. I acknowledge that the principal of the Bendigo CAE has acknowledged--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I seek your guidance on standing order No. 144 which states that questions should not ask Ministers to announce the Government's policy.
—Order! The initial part of the honourable member for Bendigo's question dealt with another matter.

—To put the honourable member for Wentworth's mind at rest, I will not be announcing any new policies. I will simply be outlining the policies which this Government has been consistently following since its election. I begin by pointing out that what this Government inherited in relation to higher education was a situation nothing short of a crisis. We saw, during the period of the Fraser Government, a dramatic decline in the enrolments of young people going from schools to universities and CAEs. In 1976, something like 10 per cent of 17 year olds to 19 year olds participated in higher education and, by 1982, this figure had fallen to something like 8.6 per cent. That was a very dramatic fall and a serious decline. We should have been encouraging even greater participation of young people in higher education given the fact that even at the older levels we were not comparing favourably with other countries around the world. During that time we saw that not only had the value of the tertiary education assistance scheme fallen but also that the number of people eligible for it had fallen from two-thirds of students to less than half of the students who were enrolled in universities and colleges. We saw capital expenditure halved in real terms between 1976 and 1983. We also saw recurrent expenditure held to levels which were seriously affecting the operation of universities and colleges.

ANSWER.PARA: In our last Budget we embarked upon a policy to turn around that process and to provide greater opportunities for young people in universities and colleges, to boost both capital and recurrent expenditure and, most importantly, to provide, immediately, for 3,000 new places in universities and colleges. We recognised that in order to ensure a greater participation in universities and colleges we first had to ensure that a greater number of students finished their secondary schooling; hence, the attention that has been applied to the participation and equity program to ensure that more students at secondary schools remain until their final years.

It is true that we were not able to go as far as we wanted in the area of TEAS. The assistance increased by 5 per cent and the income test was eased. That is a question which will be again addressed in the next Budget. Honourable members are probably aware that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs will shortly table the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. Naturally the Government will be giving attention to the recommendations in the Commission's report. It will be doing that in the light of the constraints which we have imposed upon ourselves in the lead-up to the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In view of the experience of the Northern Territory land rights legislation, why does the Minister not agree with the Opposition, miners, the National Farmers Federation, Senator Walsh and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie that the principle of Aboriginal control in relation to mining on Aboriginal land should be reviewed? Furthermore, how does the Minister reconcile his principle of Aboriginal control over mining on Aboriginal land with stated government policy that mineral rights are to remain vested in the Crown?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question because it enables me to inform him that it has always been the policy of this Government that mineral rights vest in the Crown. That is the position in respect of the land rights legislation of the Northern Territory. The Aboriginal people receive mining equivalent royalties, which means that the Commonwealth forgoes the royalties due to the Commonwealth. They go to Aboriginal communities. However, there has never been any concession by this Government or any previous government that there has been any change in that policy. That is one of the grave misunderstandings that runs through the community as a result of the propaganda that is put around by groups which, fundamentally, are opposed to Aboriginal land rights.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is fascinating and interesting-I do not say this in any way derogately of the honourable gentleman-that the Leader of the Opposition, who voted for this legislation, can ask me a question in this House which shows that he too has become a victim of the propaganda campaigns of those who say, basically, that they are opposed to Aboriginal land rights, per se. The honourable gentleman mentioned the National Farmers Federation. The National Farmers Federation makes no secret of the fact that it is opposed to Aboriginal land rights. It says the matter of heritage legislation should be a responsibility of the States exclusively despite the fact that the High Court of Australia said that that is not the law. The honourable gentleman wants me to have regard to an organisation which says: 'Although the High Court said this we want you to do something which is not the law of Australia'. He referred to the attitude of the Australian Mining Industry Council and of some other leaders of the mining industry. I am sorry; I cannot accept this latest theological doctrine which says that miners have divine rights.

I would advise the Leader of the Opposition, whose sincerity in asking this question I have no doubt about, that one of the real issues for which Malcolm Fraser could claim credit was his stand in respect of South Africa and his commitment to legislation which is on the statute books. I think that legislation goes to the credit of the Fraser Government. I advise the honourable gentlemen opposite that the Fraser Government established a basis which I think will give him real credit in history. I believe it will be to the discredit of honourable gentlemen opposite if they yield to the lunatic right-wing fringe groups around Australia who are, at the moment, attacking Asians, supporting the Government of South Africa, and engaging in an unprincipled attack on the rights of the most disadvantaged section of this community, the Australian Aboriginal people. I commend to the Leader of the Opposition, and to those who support him on his side, that he move his Party back to the position in respect of Aboriginal land rights where there was a very large measure of consensus on both sides of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of an article which appeared on the front page of the Age on 23 April titled 'Australia misled US over roos, say papers'? Can the Minister explain the circumstances surrounding this Press report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Ballarat for the question; he has a lot of kangaroos in his electorate. An article did appear in the Age, which was an extremely misleading one.
—When was that?
—On 23 April.
—Who wrote it?

—It was written by Bronwyn Cran. Does the honourable member want a question and answer session or will he let me go on? The article was extremely misleading. She is the environment reporter for the Age. She did not contact my office. When asked why, she said: 'You have had your say. Anyhow I am opposed to killing kangaroos, any kangaroos'. What the House has to be concerned at is a trend among some journalists not to find out the facts but to push their own particular views. This article was based on some disinformation provided-
—Have you counted all the roos yet, Barry?

—Not yet. The information in that article claimed that the previous Government had misled the United States of America about the real numbers of the Australian kangaroo population from 1980 and many other things. This reference, to the former Leader of the National Party of Australia, in particular, was based on an article written by Mrs Marian Newman, of fond memory, who is a leading anti-kangaroo culling lobbyist in the United States. The United States Government has sent us the text of a letter written to Mrs Newman. It reads as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: We were very disappointed with your recent Press release concerning the fish and wildlife service's withdrawal of its proposal to delist the red, eastern gray, and western gray kangaroos: It contained so many erroneous statements and distortions of fact that we feel a response is necessary. Some of the more obvious of these are the following:

Your statement that the Australian Government is seeking to eradicate the kangaroos by opening markets for skins and meat of the animals is simply untrue. Australia, as you well know, needs to control kangaroo numbers to prevent undue killing by ranchers. To accuse that Government of seeking to eradicate its national symbol is nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I am defending your previous Leader's performance. The telex continued :

ANSWER.PARA: You claim that the Australian Government gave the US an estimate of 60 million kangaroos: Actually the Australian Government gave, in its 1982 petition, an estimate of about 18 million with approximately 50 percent of the country surveyed: We interpreted-
that is, the United States Government-

this to mean that there might be over 32 million kangaroos all told. The Australian Government, however, promptly provided us with the latest population estimate of 19.2 million continent-wide when that figure became available in 1983.

You charge that the Australian Government duped the United States on the kangaroo issue, and has demonstrated extraordinary deceit. As far as we are concerned, nothing could be farther from the truth. The Australian Government has been completely open in its dealings with us-
That is, the previous Government, and this Government-

and has been very willing to provide any information we requested. In fact, it was the Australian Government's honesty in providing the latest data on declines in numbers that led to the withdrawal of our delisting proposal. The Australian Government has never tried to dupe the US, and it has not been deceitful in any way.

Your statement that the US rejected the Australian petition to remove the kangaroos from the threatened list is also incorrect. The US accepted the petition, published a proposed rule to act upon it, and was prepared to issue a final rule to implement it when it received word of the unforeseen occurrence of a decline in kangaroo numbers due to drought. The proposed rule was therefore withdrawn, but the petition was certainly not rejected.

There are a number of other examples of distorted views and facts presented in your Press release, but the above should suffice to demonstrate why we are concerned. Such a document can only stir up antagonisms and resentment, and will not assist your cause. It is decidedly not in the best interest of kangaroo conservation.
In another program later, Dr Peter Rawlinson--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will finish. Honourable members should contain their excitement. Dr Peter Rawlinson repeated this misinformation and, with the aid of the American Government, I want now to refute publicly the lies and distortions being told about this Government and its kangaroo management program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE: MIRAGE AIRCRAFT

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Defence. I refer to the fact that three Mirage aircraft have crashed in the last few weeks, the fact that all Mirage aircraft are now grounded and the report in the Australian of 5 April which said:

QUESTION.PARA: The support problem has become so desperate senior RAAF officers comment privately they would have difficulty maintaining any sort of war for more than a long weekend.

In view of the foregoing, I ask the Minister: Is it true that the 1983-84 flying hours for Mirage squadrons has dropped to 12,890 hours? Is it true that the Royal Australian Air Force requirement to meet all its commitments, including fleet support for 1984-84, is in excess of 17,000 hours? Is it not a fact that RAAF officers are expressing concern at the lack of flying time for the categorisation of their Mirage pilots?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member to come to the conclusion of his question. The question he is asking is more a question on notice than a question without notice. I will give him the opportunity to round off.
—What is the position regarding Mirage spares? When will the squadrons become fully operational again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable gentlemen opposite have finished their smart remarks, firstly, I should indicate that the Chief of the Air Staff is extremely concerned about suggestions which have been made that he, as the person responsible for the Royal Australian Air Force, would in any way permit pilots to fly aircraft which were in an unsafe state or in any way less safe than was required for the safety of operations of those persons concerned. I also point out that over a period of years there have been regular losses of Mirage aircraft, the greatest number being in 1976.

ANSWER.PARA: Currently, Mirage aircraft are in fact grounded because two have recently been abandoned because of a failure of the safety warning apparatus to indicate that landing gear was locked into position and that it was safe for the pilot to undertake a landing. It is standard procedure that where the pilot is unable to be certain that the aircraft can be landed safely-especially in built up areas but also when the pilot's life or the lives of others may be endangered-the plane is to be abandoned and the pilot is to eject in order to ensure his own safety and the safety of others. The honourable gentleman draws attention to the number of hours available for flying by RAAF Mirage personnel. I point out to the House that in 1982-83 the number of hours available for flying these aircraft was substantially reduced by the then Government and the then Minister who is now the Leader of the National Party of Australia. In fact, a reduction of 30 hours per pilot took place that year. The number of flying hours for the RAAF was substantially increased in the last Budget and stands at a higher rate than was the case in the previous year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The question referred to the Mirage squadrons, and not the RAAF.
—There is no point of order.

—In 1982-83, 13,082 hours were available in the Mirage aircraft and the allocation in the current Budget-we are not completely through the year-is 13,280 hours. That represents an increase for each pilot of 15 hours in actual flying time per year over the very low level to which the previous Government allowed those hours to sink. With regard to the availability of aircraft, I am assured that the Mirage aircraft are capable of and will remain capable of providing air defence for Australia until such time as the FA18 aircraft come into service. There has been a change in the scheduled refits of the aircraft. That change was brought about by the previous Government's decision to reduce the refurbishment program planned and to allow a run down of the aircraft.

ANSWER.PARA: There are equipment gaps in a number of areas in the Defence Force and substantially that is because the previous Government deferred decision making until such time as it became too late to replace equipment in time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—We had another example of the honourable member's tardiness and neglect last year when the first vessel of the minesweeper fleet was tied up because it had reached the end of its life, and no decision was in train for its replacement at the time the former Government went out of office. When honourable members are in opposition they are good at telling people what should be done but the facts are that they gutted the defence program and this particular former Minister was responsible for a substantial reduction in the defence vote only two years ago. He stands condemned not only because of his failure to carry out his undertakings but also his failure to be man enough now to stand up and admit what he did while he was in office as the Minister for Defence. There will continue to be gaps in our defence preparedness until such time as we can catch up with the long lead time items on which the previous Government procrastinated and over which it put off decisions for years. Those replacements cannot be acquired in short times. There are repeated examples of where the previous Government made no replacement decisions on items of equipment which are now going out of service. Those decisions should have been made several years ago. When members of the Opposition were in government they neglected defence and they now try by cheap and shoddy means to blame others for their own neglect in order to acquire some short term political points. They are absolutely without conscience and their defence record ever since this nation was formed has been one and the same. They talk and they talk but when it comes to a defence emergency the nation has to throw them out of office.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his answer to the House on Tuesday concerning the industrial dispute at the new Parliament House site. Can the Minister inform the House whether there have been any further developments in the matter?

—There have been developments in this dispute. The House will recall that a meeting was to be held this morning of members of the three unions which initiated the dispute and whose members were employed on the Parliament House site. That meeting was held this morning and I am pleased to say that the members decided on a return to work at the site next Tuesday. The Government and I welcome these developments which will allow Commissioner Brown to hand down his decision on the site allowance. As the House will recall, he has heard the argument and was waiting on a return to work before handing down his decision. I hope that we now have the basis for a settlement of this dispute, that the decision of Commissioner Brown will be accepted by the employees on the Parliament House site and that we can get this important national project going once again.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Defence. In light of his commendable and apparently new decision to take decisions, can he advise the House what decision he has taken to offset the delays in service postings in the current financial year which have affected service efficiency and morale?

—There has not been a cancellation of service postings, as the honourable gentleman suggests. There are some delays, largely because that section of the Budget has been overspent. That situation has occurred in a number of recent years and obviously it is necessary for sections of the Defence Force to comply with their Budget allocations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. Is the Minister aware of media reports indicating dissatisfaction amongst industry representatives over their exclusion from the so called working party to examine the export of live sheep from Australia? I further ask: What are the terms of reference for this group, why was it established, who will participate and why were they chosen?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the media reports. I say at the outset that the working group is a very honest attempt by the Government to arrive at an agreement about the facts and the possible resolution of this issue. As members of the House will realise, this issue has been bubbling along for some 10 years. The Government does not believe that expedient action or reactions are appropriate in the circumstances given the longevity of this issue. In answer to the honourable member, the terms of reference are firstly to examine the factors which have contributed to the decline in employment opportunities in the meat processing industry and, secondly, to examine the effect that the live sheep trade has on employment in ancillary transport, feed lot, wharfside operations and abattoir employment.

ANSWER.PARA: The working party will discuss these matters in the context of the Government's overall structural adjustment policy and the problems of displaced workers with the aim of determining a permanent solution to the dispute which reflects the interests of all groups involved in the live sheep trade. The working party will consist of representatives of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Industry and Commerce and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the Government Committee on Industrial Relations and the Government Primary Industry Sub-committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —No sheep?

—No, no sheep. The composition of the working party reflects its basic purpose, which is to bring the industrial and political wings of the labour movement together clearly to identify and resolve the areas of agreement and disagreement between government and unions on the facts of the live sheep export trade. As I said at the start, the establishment of the working party is an attempt to put consideration of this long-running dispute where it belongs, and that is clearly in the industrial relations area. The working party should start its deliberations next week. The honourable member for Melbourne may even have a hand in it.

—Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware that the draft balance sheet of PT Indomilk for the year ended 31 December 1983 shows a further net operating loss of $3.2m on top of losses of $2m in 1982 and $2.5m in 1981? Given the fact that the amount owed to Australian dairy farmers by PT Indomilk is now $14m, and recalling the inexplicable decision of Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd to relinquish management control of PT Indomilk to the Indonesian partners, does the Minister still hold the view which he expressed to this Parliament on 5 April this year; namely, that PT Indomilk can trade out of its difficulties? Alternatively, is the liquidation of the company now inevitable? If so, did the Minister mislead this House on 5 April or was he badly advised on that occasion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know who is advising the honourable member for Darling Downs on this issue, but as he probably knows the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is examining the whole question. The Australian Dairy Corporation and I will give evidence to it tomorrow. I would hope by that process that at last the facts of this matter will come out and be very clearly laid before the Parliament and the nation in terms of the background to this issue, the reasons that the problem has arisen and the actions of the previous Government with respect to this whole question. I am not going to go into the detail of this issue, except to say that the advice of the previous Government was that the Australian Dairy Corporation and ADI should exercise their best commercial judgment in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts and figures as related to the House by the honourable member are probably as stated. I am not aware of the exact dollar amounts, but I take it on trust that he has the same figures that I can easily recall. The issue is well appreciated by the industry itself. The Australian Dairy Industry Conference has moved resolutions about the ADI Board. The ADC has responded to these resolutions. It is a matter that the industry is vitally and properly concerned about and it is an issue that it is investigating.

In my statement on 5 April I said that I had been advised up until quite recent times that there was every prospect that PT Indomilk would trade out of its difficulties. I refer the honourable member to the report of Coopers and Lybrand that gave qualified advice to the ADI to that effect. I was simply relating to the House that advice that had been passed on to me by the ADC. This issue is extremely complex and I understand the honourable member's interest in it. But I think after tomorrow we may have a clearer explanation of the processes that got us to the stage we are at. It is still a matter for the industry to resolve. It is not for the Government to take any peremptory decision in this matter. It is an issue that the Government is fully aware of but, as I said, it is largely an issue for the industry to resolve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Transport been drawn to the fact that the Senate this morning rejected government legislation seeking to introduce some flexibility into the tendering system which applies to Commonwealth funded road projects? Is it a fact that this legislation was introduced at the specific request of the States to introduce economies and efficiencies into road construction programs? What implications will this action have for the States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the effective and hardworking honourable member for Grey for his question because it is an important question for people who live in the country. Sitting on the right hand side of the chamber to me we have those members who masquerade as representatives of country Australia. Let me assure the House that it is a masquerade. The Senate's action this morning in removing from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill those two clauses that would have enabled the Federal Minister for Transport, on application from a State Minister for Roads, to provide an exemption from the calling of tenders for work on arterial or national roads under the Bicentennial Roads Act or the Roads Grants Act means--
—It got you off the hook.
—I know the honourable member for Gwydir does not care about people in the country. He is part of the masquerade.
—Order! I ask the Minister to continue with his answer and not to provoke interjections.

—It means that the Federal Minister for Transport will not have the power not to call tenders in situations where it could be proven, as I was outlining, to the satisfaction of the Federal Minister that substantial numbers of employees of public road authorities, be they State or local government, would suffer retrenchment, or that there would be substantial inefficiency as a result of the calling of tenders, or that technical or safety factors warranted such a decision. I am talking about work which normally is the responsibility of public utilities, such as shifting a railway bridge or reconstructing a railway bridge. Because that is not the case, the future and employment of those employees is now at risk thanks to the National Party and to those senators who seek to represent the States.

ANSWER.PARA: I advise the House that the amendments to the two Acts I referred to earlier were unanimously supported by all State and Territory governments. In fact, the two strongest proponents of the changes were the governments of Queensland and Tasmania. In respect of Tasmania, this morning I received a telex from the Tasmanian Minister for Main Roads. It is worth noting that the Queensland senators and the Tasmanian senators voted against this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the Labor Party senators.

—Just to make it clearer, the Opposition senators from Queensland and Tasmania voted against this legislation. The telex sent to me this morning by Mr Braid, the Minister for Main Roads in Tasmania, says:

ANSWER.PARA: I wish to advise that Tasmania supports the relaxation of tendering procedures provided for in the Bills, and the following is the content of a telegram I forwarded to all Tasmanian senators, urging their support for the amendments:

'In the interests of the Tasmanian civil construction industry and the Tasmanian Government's efforts to encourage development of that industry, you are urged to support the Commonwealth Government's relaxation of tendering procedures as proposed in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1984 and the Roads Grants Amendment Bill 1984'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another Tory split!

—The Prime Minister says that it is another split. What is the policy of the Opposition? When these Bills were dealt with in the Senate initially the Opposition removed altogether the relevant clause of the legislation.
—In view of all the money you took away from bush roads you ought to be ashamed to speak in this place.

—The right honourable member would not know much about bush roads at Darling Point. Initially the Opposition in the Senate removed clause 5 of the Bill. Subsequently, having had another think about it, it decided to have the Bill recommitted, have a portion of the conditions re-inserted but still adhere with its opposition to the expressed requests of the State governments right around Australia, particularly Queensland and Tasmania. Again this indicates the division, the lack of direction and the difficulty which the Opposition is having in trying to come to some concerted view about policy. In this case the National Party, which claims to represent country people in Australia, is selling out the people of the country, the employees of the various departments of main roads in each State and the local government work force. Let me say in conclusion that so often in a time of emergency in the countryside, be it bushfire or flood, it is the people in the local authority work force who are called upon, along with their equipment, to assist in those natural disasters. Members of the Opposition have done the people of this country and the road workers in this country a great disservice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie seeks to make a personal explanation. Is it on the ground that he has been misrepresented or is it for another purpose?
—It is on the ground of misrepresentation of those who are unable to answer for themselves. It arises out of an error in Hansard.
—If the honourable member wishes to correct an error I will grant him that indulgence.

—On behalf of all the meleagris Gallopavo of this country I draw your attention, Mr Speaker, to the grave injustice that was done to these birds- if that is not a sexist term-on page 2163 of Hansard. While I am not generally--
—The honourable member will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—I refer to an interview conducted on radio station 6PR in Perth between Chris Gillam, a reporter, and the retail operations manager of Charlie Carter Stores, Mr John Gjergjevica. The interview was conducted as a result of a speech I made in the adjournment debate on Monday night. During that interview Mr Gjergjevica claimed that I had declined to visit one of his supermarkets for a variety of reasons, including lack of time. To put the record straight, I wish to refer to a letter I wrote to Charlie Carters which in part states:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for the invitation to visit your store. I have seen a scanner supermarket in Victoria and am well acquainted with their operations. If I can arrange a visit to Wembley, I will get in touch with you.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The misleading expectations being created by the Government regarding taxation cuts in the forthcoming Budget.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As much as anyone can be certain of anything from this Government, one can be certain of one thing-that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is determined to have an early election close on the heels of a Budget that contains a tax cut. I notice from the response of Government members already that that is the strategy. Between now and August the Australian public will be told again and again that their kind, benign, friendly Prime Minister will give them a great big tax cut and that as a result of that great big tax cut we will all be so much better off. The dogs are already barking about the amount. The amount that gets most of the coverage and is most regularly referred to is about $1,000m. One can imagine the Prime Minister-Santa Claus Hawke- running around the country saying: 'Look how generous I have been. I have given you a tax cut of $1,000m. Look what that means. Look what that means to the average Australian family'. He will be trying to create this great big expectation that everybody will be a lot better off as a result of the tax cut. He will be saying to the trade union movement: 'Because of my generosity you will all be rewarded for supporting the prices and incomes accord'. He will try to persuade everybody that they are so much better off.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one thing wrong with that description and that scenario, only one fatal flaw. Unfortunately, the Prime Minister's tax cut in the coming Budget will be a totally phoney tax cut. At the weekend the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Peacock) told us all that the tax cut that was coming up in the Budget would be a phoney tax cut. It is not only because the Government has swept a whole lot of undesirable tax proposals under the carpet in the hope that if it wins the next election it will then be able to implement those changes and it is not only because of the effect of inflation on a progressive taxation scale which will mean that people in the same real situation will pay a higher level of taxation; it is also because of a large number of taxation decisions that have been taken by this Government and their full year effect in 1984-85.

I have prepared a table which I will table and make public. That table shows some very interesting things. It is headed 'Tax Rises due to Government decisions'. One very interesting exclusion at the top states 'Direct taxes on individuals (excluding anti-avoidance)'. Of course, the Government has not done anything in that area because the whole area has been totally covered. The table shows that in 1983-84 the direct decisions of this Government in the personal tax area removed no less than $700m from the pockets of Australian taxpayers. In other words, by its deliberate decisions in the area of direct taxation on individuals, it lifted taxes by $700m. In the indirect area it lifted taxes by $ 1,100m, making a total of $1,800m in 1983-84.

Even more significantly than that, if we project those decisions into 1984-85, next financial year, the financial year in respect of which the Prime Minister and all of his colleagues will be running around saying 'As a result of our munificence you will all be a great deal better off', personal taxation will rise by $2.6 billion and direct and indirect taxation will rise by no less than the staggering sum of $3.5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you substantiate that?

—The figure is here in the table. The source of these figures is none other than the Budget Papers themselves. No doubt my friend the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will have a few things to say about the source. I caution him because the source is his own Budget documentation. This shows that just to break even in the next Budget he will have to give a $3.5 billion tax cut. Pre-emptively looking at this forthcoming Budget, I say to the House, and particularly to the wage and salary earners of Australia who between now and that inevitable election at the end of the year will be treated, day after day, week after week, by the Prime Minister to these stories of how generous he has been in giving them a tax cut, that unless he gives a tax cut of $3.5 billion in this forthcoming Budget nobody will be better off; we will all be a great deal worse off.

SPEECH.PARA: The words of the Leader of the Opposition at Thredbo last weekend were very true when he said at one of his Press conferences that the tax cut being offered by this Government is a totally phoney tax cut. That is to say absolutely nothing about the effect of fiscal drag on personal tax collections next year. It is to say nothing about the inevitable discretionary increases in indirect taxation that will take place in the Budget. It is to say nothing about the Government's intention if it is successful in the election to increase the Medicare levy. It says nothing about other taxation increases that this Government has in mind. It says that on the basis of decisions that this Government has already taken in the May economic statement last year and in the Budget last year, tax next year will go up by $3.5 billion. If the Prime Minister gives us a tax cut of $1 billion we will not be $1 billion better off; we will still be $2.5 billion behind. Those figures have been calculated on the basis of the Government's own decision. Their source is the Federal Budget documentation from last August. I naturally look forward with very great interest to the Treasurer's response.

This demonstrates the way in which this Government, in the area of tax cuts as in so many other areas, is building for itself a record of deceit and deception. Not only has this Government been willing to misrepresent the attitude of this side of the House on subjects such as tax avoidance but also, on top of that, it has been prepared and will continue, week after week, month after month, to try to kid the Australian people that they will get a $l billion tax cut in the Budget. I bet that when the Budget is brought down the Treasurer will not tell anyone in his Party or in this Parliament that in 1984-85 the cost of the abolition by the Hawke Government of the tax rebate for health care that was introduced by the Fraser Government will be no less than $575m.

I bet the Government will not tell the home owners of Australia, the people who are paying interest on their home loans, that the cost of the Government's abolition of the interest rebate was $395m. I bet that it does not say that the effect of the superannuation changes on a seven-year basis will amount to about $300 billion. In other words, the taxpayers will not be given any of this information. They will be told again and again: 'Gee, you are lucky, you are getting $l billion from this Santa Claus Treasurer and this Santa Claus Prime Minister and you all should be so terribly grateful about it'. Of course, the taxpayers will not be told that the effect on consumers of services offered by Telecom Australia and Australia Post in 1984-85 will be about $101m as a result of decisions taken by the Hawke Labor Government.

The Government will not tell the taxpayers that they will pay $354m in increased excise on petrol, diesel and aviation fuel. It will not tell them that the indexation of excise rates will cost them $236m. It will not tell them that the cost of the Medicare levy alone is $l,050m, that health costs will increase by $1,050m. Of course, all of the additional tax has been put on in order to fool the Australian people into believing that they have a much cheaper health care system.

This Government will endeavour to convince us that if it adds $3.5 billion to the community's tax bill and takes away $l billion the community will be in front. I do not think anybody on this side of the House or any of the Australian public listening on Budget night will be fooled about it. Undoubtedly, just as we will hear a great deal from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer from now until the Budget and after the Budget about the taxation cuts and the Government 's generosity in the Budget, I can assure honourable gentlemen opposite that they will hear a great deal from us about the tax increase of $3.5 billion under the Hawke Labor Government. The tax slugs, not only on personal taxpayers but also through indirect taxation--
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on both sides of the House are impeding the speaker.

—What I am saying makes very great sense. This Government, in just over a year of office, has earned for itself a well-deserved description from the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers' Association. Mr Risstrom said that we have seen the most dramatic increase in personal taxation since World War II. He records that a typical family man with basic medical insurance, a mortgage of $ 30,000 at an interest rate of 13.5 per cent and a dependent wife pays $2,684 in tax on an income of $17,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Again and again one finds increases occurring across the board. Over the months in front of us we are going to hear a lot from the Prime Minister about how good , clever and generous he has been in giving us $1,000m worth of tax cuts. It is by any measure a phoney tax cut, a non-tax cut which goes less than one-third of the way towards wiping out the tax increases that have been put upon the Australian taxpayers by the present Treasurer and the present Prime Minister. I invite the Treasurer in his response to tell me where this table is wrong. I invite him to repudiate his own figures. I invite him to deny that as a result of his decisions and the decisions of the Prime Minister in the personal tax and indirect taxation area he will put no less than $3.5 billion more upon the backs of the Australian taxpayers next year. Yet in the face of that he will undoubtedly have the gall, and his colleagues will have the gall, on Budget night and thereafter and in the coming election campaign to go around Australia and say: 'You ought to vote for us. We have held the prices and incomes accord. We have cut taxes because a $1,000m tax cut cancels out the $3.5 billion tax rise.' That is a proposition and a distortion that the Australian people will not wear. They will know that this is part of the elaborate deception, camouflage and deceit to try to induce them into giving this Government a second term of office in a totally unnecessary, unjustified and premature election that is going to take place in a little over 18 months after the Government was elected. The Government is unquestionably rushing to the polls in order to avoid the consequences of governing with all of the difficulties that are undoubtedly going to mount in 1985.

Part of the package of deceit by this Prime Minister will be to try to persuade us that if we increase taxes by $3,500m and then reduce them by $1,000m miraculously, Houdini-Hawke-like, we will all be a great deal better off. The truth of the matter is that we will not be any better off. We will all be a lot worse off. We are worse off now. We will get worse off in 1984-85 and the Opposition will tell the Australian people that we will be even worse off if they re-elect the Hawke Government at the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the Treasurer, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition indicted that he would request leave to table a paper. Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing is certain, and that is that the Liberals have no shame. We will never find a Liberal with any shame, least of all the former discredited Treasurer, the man who presided over the highest taxing government in Australian history. Indeed the degree of doublespeak on his part is simply unbelievable. Just a few weeks ago he was saying that he would give no tax cut if he were Treasurer, he would rather hold down the Budget deficit. This is from the man who in 1982, through his own fiscal irresponsibility in handing out a tax cut which by all standards was fiscally irresponsible to save his miserable political hide and that of his colleagues, blew out the Budget deficit in prospect for 1983-84 to $9.6 billion. Indeed, in the 1982-83 Budget he blew the Budget from a planned $1.6 billion to $4.4 billion because he and Malcolm Fraser believed they could dupe the public by hiding their high tax record with a tax cut which they thought would save their skins. They gave their tax cuts and they were defeated in the poll anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth remembering, when one looks over the record of the former Treasurer and at the increases in personal income tax alone in his period of stewardship of the Treasury, that in 1978-79 personal taxation increased by 5.6 per cent. In 1979-80 it increased by 17.5 per cent. In 1980-81 it increased by 16.6 per cent. In 1981-82 it increased by a massive 21 per cent and, of course, in 1982-83 the Opposition then went to the tax cuts to try to save itself and as a result we were landed with this shocking deficit position which we have today. So there is the record for anybody to look at in terms of the approach to taxation of the former Government. It was the highest taxing government in the Federal history of this country. Everybody understands that. Let us not be duped by the credentials of the former Treasurer. Indeed the Australian Labor Party in Opposition said that given a position which we thought was going to apply in 1983-84, we would look at tax cuts, which is what we said in the election campaign. But we found, when we came to office, that instead of having a deficit in prospect of $6 billion, it was $9.6 billion. Of course, it would have been highly irresponsible to have considered a tax cut in 1983-84 in terms of national economic management. One has to ask oneself why there was such a rapid fiscal deterioration between those two years. The answer simply is because of the economic mismanagement and incompetence of the former Treasurer and the former Prime Minister and, of course, because of their massive unprincipled tax cut of 1982-83 to try to save themselves.

I will just make a couple of observations about the figures which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the shadow Treasurer, produced, which very quickly demolishes the phoney case he has built up. He quoted Mr Risstrom from the Australian Taxpayers Association, who I have discredited in this House on a number of occasions and who, indeed, the former Treasurer has discredited on a number of occasions. After holding the Taxpayers Association spokesman, Mr Risstrom, to derision for years he now embraces him, the man who has admitted now on two occasions that he has had his numbers wrong, that his computers have broken down, that he has misjudged it or that it has come out badly.

Let me make this point, which is the same point I made in respect of the charges made by Mr Risstrom, and that is that the Opposition cannot do this phoney accounting number without recognising the facts. According to the statement of the honourable member for Bennelong a few minutes ago he includes in one of the charges $1,050m for health insurance, for Medicare. He is saying: 'Why, the Medicare levy cost $1,050m'. What he does not say is: 'You do not pay $10 to $12 a week any more to a private health insurance fund'. Why does he not say this? He does not say it because he wants to deceive anybody in the Parliament and he wants to deceive everybody who is listening on the radio and the public in general. When I challenged Mr Risstrom about this I said: 'Look, you have made this claim about taxation. You have put the Medicare levy on one side because we are changing from a privately funded basis of health insurance to a publicly funded one but you have not made any offsetting savings in respect of the $10 to $12 a week each Australian family was paying for private medical health insurance'. He said: 'I am not doing that, I am only a tax man. I am not a health insurance man'. I said: 'Well, I don't care if you are a tax man. You cannot make the claim that the Government has increased taxation when in fact we have substituted a cost which families were paying privately. Whether you pay it out of your pocket after tax to a health insurance fund or whether you pay it through the tax system, it has to be offset in terms of any calculation'.

The honourable member for Bennelong, to discredit himself further, came into the Parliament today and did the very same thing. He spoke about the $1,000m of the calculation that he has, which is the Medicare levy. He did not mention the fact that Australians no longer have to pay a private health insurance of $10 to $12 a week as they did before. Another phoney number he mentioned is the housing rebate-$395m. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was heard in peace so he should show some courtesy. In respect of housing rebates, the former Government was not concerned about getting young Australian families into housing. People were living in caravans with their in-laws, in back rooms and in garages. The previous Government was not concerned about putting a roof over those people's heads; it was concerned about trying to win a few more votes by taking again the sleazy road to power. In the 1982-83 Budget it offered to all those people who already had mortgages and who had had them for years-people whose equity in properties had risen dramatically as the inflationary impact on prices in the Howard and Fraser years of high inflation affected house prices around Australia as their mortgage costs had gone down relative to the overall value of their properties-as a sop, as a very poor electoral handout, an interest rate subsidy on existing mortgages which people, particularly people on middle and high incomes, had had for years.

What justice was there in directing Commonwealth assistance to people on middle and high incomes for existing mortgages on houses which they owned and which they were paying off comfortably, and had been doing so for years? What this Government did was abolish those rebates and hand out the funds to young Australians for their first home, under the first home owners scheme. As part of his deception the honourable member for Bennelong never even mentioned a few minutes ago that the $395m which he charged the Government with taking away from the taxpayer this year was handed out in the first home owners scheme, which has seen thousands of young Australians, married couples and single people, put their own roofs over their heads for the first time. This year we have seen the housing industry building new homes at a record rate of somewhere between 135, 000 and 150,000 homes. That is almost an Australian record. Why is that? It is because this Government wanted to target Commonwealth financial assistance to young families in need, and it did so. The former Treasurer has not had the common decency to mention that while we did take away the rebate, and we are proud of it, we gave that money back to first home owners. What is the point in his coming here with this piece of jingoism, this phoney calculation, without mentioning offsetting factors in respect of health insurance or housing rebates and the rest?

The honourable member for Bennelong mentioned, amongst other things, the indexation of excises. As a former Treasurer, he knows that in this country we cannot afford to have the real value of excises declining. Most excises are adjusted only in a discretionary way once every few years. Because we have in this country, particularly under the Liberals, a propensity to have more and more elections, we find that governments have not been game to adjust the excises for cigarettes, liquor or any other category of product covered by the excises. The result is that the high inflation which the former Treasurer was able to manage ripped away at the real value of the excise base of the Commonwealth.

The outlays of the Commonwealth never diminished. They have grown, because as we have moved into recessions we have picked up the high levels of unemployment for which we have had to pay and we have had the losses in revenue from those who were formerly employed and from whom the Commonwealth is no longer reaping income tax receipts. So with growing outlays what government can afford responsibly to have the taxation base of the Commonwealth decline? We were not prepared and, I will say again, we are definitely not prepared to have the excise base of the Commonwealth eroded because, as the former Treasurer knows, if excise goes down direct taxation through income tax goes up. Treasurers and governments have to make the revenue, and the honourable member knows that. It is no good his bleating about matters affecting the pay packets of ordinary taxpayers when he knows the direct income tax burden will rise if other categories of tax receipts fall. By adjusting excises for inflation each half year, as this Government has done since the last Budget-every six months they are adjusted for inflation-the real value of the tax does not change. Hence, again, that is another phoney entry in that list of phoney entries in that compilation which the former Treasurer tabled in the House a few moments ago.

I think I have dealt adequately with all of the phoney elements in the former Treasurer's supposed case, this attack on the Government. Let me get to the principal matter. I say to honourable members opposite: Yes, the Government will provide tax cuts in the next Budget. It will do so for very sound reasons related to the progress and well-being of the economy. The first is that because of the operation of the Government's prices and incomes accord and the effect of the Medicare deduction upon the consumer price index, we will see, for the first time in a decade, the back broken of the high levels of inflation in this country. That is something which the former Government was incapable of doing. It could not restrain inflation into recovery. We will be breaking the back of inflation while at the same time we have an economic recovery, with growth occurring very strongly through the year. That is something the former Government could never do.

Of course, there is a cost involved, and the cost is that wages will not be adjusted as they would otherwise have been had that Medicare deduction on the consumer price index not operated. In compensatory terms, to the degree that the Government believes that budgetary flexibility will permit it, we will look at tax cuts to compensate wage and salary earners in the Budget as a result of that Medicare deduction. Of course, with that money being funded back into the taxpayers' pockets it will add considerably to consumption in 1984-85 or to the capacity for an increase in disposable incomes, which will lift consumption. One of the pegs upon which growth in the economy will be placed in 1984-85 is a very strong increase in consumption, which will put the Australian economy back on the road to a full recovery; one which can then be the basis of higher levels of private investment and continually higher levels of employment growth and the amelioration of unemployment. That is why we are looking at giving tax cuts in the next Budget.

There is no point in the former Treasurer talking about early elections and the rest. Members of the Opposition are the early election specialists. For sound reasons, we are looking to promote consumption and at the same time to break the back of Australian inflation, which the former Treasurer could never do. So let us not talk about any records of deceit, because the former Treasurer has a record of deceit which is unsurpassed in this Parliament. He went to a national election deceiving the nation about the size of the Budget deficit in prospect at a time when economic strategies were being framed upon that deficit. We reject absolutely the charges made by the former Treasurer. I regard his compilation on taxes as trash, as rubbish. I have already addressed all of the offsetting factors relating to that. If that is the best he can do, he will be in Opposition for a long time in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. The discussion has concluded .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the House. Over the past few days, powerful emotions have been unleashed in this country and in this Parliament over the issue of immigration. We in this place have a particular responsibility to ensure that what we do and say on this matter is judicious, calm and constructive. There is a risk that if the debate on immigration loses touch with facts and departs from a civilised approach, racism and racial intolerance could be promoted to the detriment of our national unity and our basic values. I know I speak for this Government, for the Australian Labor Party and for the overwhelming majority of Australians in rejecting racial intolerance and in calling for a measured and humane discussion of these issues. One of Australia's greatest achievements has been its acceptance of people from widely diverse nationalities around the world. The enrichment of our national life by new settlers since World War II, predominantly of European stock-has been palpable. Over the past decade, we have buried the white Australia policy for ever. We have shown our capacity to accept people from Asian cultures, many of whom have sought a new life in Australia following the tragedy of the wars in Indo-China in which Australia itself participated. Surely no member of this Parliament would wish to allow that achievement to be called into question now by prejudice and intolerance.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Australian stated in its editorial of 9 May 1984 in discussing the need for informed debate on immigration:
Unless it is carried on with moderation and respect for other points of view we shall come to no sensible conclusion and Australia will become an ugly place to live in.

It is therefore imperative that our debate be based on a clear understanding of the facts and that the facts be presented honestly and without a view to political point scoring. Senator Chipp, whose views on this matter I respect, pointed yesterday to the dangers of ignoring and distorting the facts and their causes in a speech which I commend to all honourable members. My purpose here today is to place in perspective the facts and implications of the Government's immigration policy.

On coming to office, the Labor Government took the view that at a time of high unemployment, unprecedented in the post-war era, we should reduce the total migration intake. We decided in particular to curtail drastically recruiting for the Australian workforce. I believe that that decision was correct. As the same time, we acknowledged the aspirations of new settlers in our community to reunite with their families by allowing an increased component for family reunion. We also accepted our responsibilities to the international community and our moral obligation as a participant in the Vietnam war to continue the bipartisan humanitarian policy of accepting refugees, particularly from Indo- China.

It is worth pointing out, as I said in this place on 8 May, that the Australian Labor Party in opposition wholeheartedly supported the Fraser Government's efforts in offering Indo-Chinese refugees a new life in this country, notwithstanding our Party's opposition to the war itself. Inevitably, Australia' s bipartisan acceptance of Asian refugees has carried with it bipartisan acceptance of their right to participate equitably in the family reunion program . As Senator Chipp has said, it is inconceivable that we could accept refugees in the late 1970's and refuse their families in the 1980's. This Government is not going to designate any group of Australians as second class citizens. We are simply not going to tell people who are here legitimately in this country that they have second class rights, that they are not allowed to exercise their rights under the family reunion program.

When the intake of Indo-Chinese refugees was at its highest under the previous Government in the period 1979 to 1981, we as an Opposition responsibly and constructively sought to make no political capital out of that fact. There is some irony in the fact that now, when the absolute number of Indo-Chinese refugees-and indeed the total number of Asians-coming into Australia is dropping , we find ourselves being subjected to criticism from some quarters for allegedly contributing to the 'Asianisation' of Australia.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has in this place and in statements to the media indicated that he is not opposed to the present number of Asians coming into Australia. Indeed, he said on Nationwide on 8 May that the 'right number' of Asians was now coming in. He has however, expressed concern about the 'mix' or the 'balance', as he put it, of the present migrant intake and has called for an increase in European migration.

The fact is that the proportion of settlers-excluding refugees-coming to Australia from Europe, the United Kingdom and Ireland is still higher than from any other area. In the nine months to 31 March 1984, migration visas issued to people from that area constituted some 45 per cent of the total number granted. This high proportion of visas issued has occurred despite a diminution of migrant applications from that region and repudiates claims of anti-British bias or anti-European bias in our migration program. In the same nine months, 39.5 per cent of total migrant applications came from Britain and Europe compared to 44.4 per cent for 1982-83, 63.1 per cent in 1981-82 and 66.6 per cent in 1980-81 .

European migration posts have been recently asked by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) to offer explanations for the diminution in interest in migration to Australia from Europe. In the case of Britain, for example, migration applications have declined dramatically-from over 130,000 in 1980-81 to some 13,000 in the first nine months of this financial year. The post in London attributes particular importance in this decline to publicity given in Britain to the recession in Australia, the unemployment situation in 1982 and, especially, unemployment among British migrants. It may well be that as the improving economic circumstances here become more widely known in Europe this situation will turn around. One can imagine, Mr Speaker, the impact in Britain of reports of steel workers, recruited for the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd under the former Government's employer nominations program, being sacked within nine months of their arrival in this country. Nothing could be better calculated to have a longterm negative impact on migration from Britain.

At the same time, while the absolute number of Asians now coming to Australia is declining because of the lower target which the Government has set for refugees, their percentage share of the intake is increasing. This partly reflects the decline in interest from Europe to which I have referred.

More relevantly, since the Opposition has raised the issue of alleged distortions in the 'balance' or 'mix' of the migration program, the percentage increase of Asian migration also reflects the fact that the Opposition during its final year in government reduced the total migration intake at a much faster rate than the refugee intake. In that year, it reduced its migration intake by 21 per cent from 118,000 to 93,000. Yet at the same time, it reduced the Asian refugee intake by only 12 per cent, from 14,557 to 12,758. We did not then, nor do we now, criticise it for that decision. By contrast, under the Labor Government, the reduction in the overall migration program has been closely paralleled by that in the Asian refugee intake.

The point that I wish to emphasise is that in government the Opposition had no particular regard for the so-called 'balance' or 'mix' it is now promoting as a policy objective. Not only that, the number of Asian refugees included in the overall intake during the period that the Opposition was in government is now being strongly reflected in the family reunion program. There are ample grounds, therefore, for suggesting that the Opposition's stand on this issue smacks of hypocrisy.

For my own part, as I said on Nationwide on 8 May, I do not believe that one can honestly say that there is an immutably right figure for any migrant group within the overall intake. Rather the approach of the Labor Government reflects the application of economic criteria in determining the total intake and of economic and humanitarian factors in breaking down this total among different categories of migrants. This Government does not consider that a balance or mix in our migration program determined on racial grounds can have any place in our society. It categorically rejects the discriminatory concept of quotas, which is implicit in what the Leader of the Opposition has said in recent days about increasing the number of European migrants. It also categorically rejects any proposals to introduce covert discrimination through differential standards in selection criteria.

We, of course, acknowledge the need to ensure that our migration program does not threaten the stability and fabric of Australian society. But in working towards this end the Government considers that not only is the size and composition of our intake important, but also the programs within our community to promote the integration of migrants into our society from initial concentrations of ethnic groups, and the broader promotion of racial tolerance in our country.

In the past few days, the Leader of the Opposition has supported his criticism of the Government's immigration policy by reference to statistics which he described as official government statistics. The basis for his claims has caused some puzzlement to the Government because my colleague the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has received no request from the Opposition for up to date immigration information. Inquiries have now revealed that some figures were in fact obtained by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) directly from a junior officer in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Department has now had those figures re-checked because they do not square with other statistics available to the Government. Our figures-figures confirmed and released yesterday by the Minister-show that overall migration applications from Europe are in decline. The Opposition's figures purported to show that family reunion applications from Europe were increasing against this trend.

It emerges that the Opposition's figures are in fact wrong and that even these figures have been used in a statistically unsound manner. My colleague the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has today written to the honourable member for Mitchell pointing out this error and giving him revised figures which confirm the Government's consistent advice that the trend of family reunion applications to migrate to Australia from traditional sources in Europe is in fact declining.

The Secretary to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Mr McKinnon, has also provided the Minister with statistical and other material which clarifies the factual basis on family reunion and the trend in Australia's immigration program. Furthermore, it sets out in some detail the highly dubious fashion in which these incorrect statistics were used by the Opposition. Mr McKinnon said:
Migrant application statistics

You asked me to explain the apparent conflict in applications for family reunion in European posts as used by Mr Cadman in the Adjournment Debate on 7 May 1984 with the advice given to you related to the decline in interest from traditional countries of migration.

Mr Cadman's office approached the Department direct by telephone. The figures supplied are derived from the Migration Program Management System. They comprise recorded applications for family migration by class, by country of last residence for 1982-83 and the first half of financial year 1983-84. Mr Cadman then doubled the half-year figures to produce an annual rate which he compared with the 1982-83 figures.
On the basis of this comparison, he concluded that there was an increase in family migration applications in the United Kingdom and Europe.
A number of qualifications need to be made:
1. The figures are wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are your figures.
—The honourable member will have every opportunity to try to get his way out of this one and he has no chance. Mr McKinnon said:

SPEECH.PARA: The data included in MPMS, which is still being developed, are notoriously unreliable. They depend upon input from a number of posts using a number of classification methods. When supplying such figures, a caveat is normally included which draws attention to their limitations, but on this occasion the caveat was not included.

A complete re-run of the figures, including recourse to the basic data, has been undertaken. The revised results are attached. You will note that they considerably alter the picture portrayed by Mr Cadman.

2. The figures are seasonal and should not be treated by doubling a half-year figure. Applications in European posts are seasonal. An example using U.K. figures for total number of persons covered by applications shows:
July-December 1980 46,504 January-June 1981 77,854 July-December 1981 43, 883 January-June 1982 60,317 July-December 1982 29,357 January-June 1983 22,766
Thus a doubling of the figures for July-December in any category runs the risk of grossly under or over-estimating the annual rate.

3. The series is not consistent. A higher proportion of persons applying in European posts have been applying under family reunion as the opportunities for skilled migration, which does not depend upon sponsorship, have declined. As the occupational Demand Schedule has narrowed, persons who would normally have applied otherwise are now applying under family reunion.

Furthermore, the increase in the scope of family reunion to include Category C only commenced in the first half of 1982 and the influence of this widened eligibility would have been felt increasingly through the period used by Mr Cadman.

4. The data are not complete. One of the other indications of declining interest in migration is the number of persons put into processing who do not respond to an invitation to interview. For example, the current response rate in the Athens post is as low as 50%, which indicates that about half of the people being sponsored by relatives in Australia are not interested in migration. Although the non-response rates for other European posts are not as high, they are still significant and well above the equivalent rates for Asian posts.

I should point out that the figures for applications relate to actual arrivals approximately one year later. Thus, even if family reunion interest were to be regenerating in traditional migration countries (which is contrary to the advice from virtually all our posts), this would not be reflected in current arrivals figures.

The current figures on the balance of source countries for arrivals would reflect the applications in 1982/83 at the latest, before any changes in immigration policy of the current Government became operative.

In any case, I should point out that the only changes made since the change of Government affect the family reunion Category C. This represented less than one quarter of all family reunion arrivals in 1982/83. Thus the changes introduced in the Points Assessment System will change marginally the proportion from different sources in future arrivals.

I would like to give you my unqualified assurance that no policy or operational instructions have been promulgated which would inhibit migration from traditional source countries. You would be aware that special efforts have been made to lift the number of Category C family reunion migrants once the shortfall became evident. Furthermore, with the declining overall level of applications in these countries, we have been able to improve significantly our processing times for family reunion migrants particularly from those countries.

For example, for the United Kingdom the average time between receipt of the application (M47) to the approval letter is now approximately 3 1/2 months, compared to 9-11 months two years ago. It is now one of the shortest periods anywhere in the world.
I believe that Mr Cadman should be informed of the adjusted figures and the limitations on the use of the figures in measuring interest in family reunion.'
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a number of supporting tables, provided to the Minister by Mr McKinnon.
Leave granted.
