TALK.START.PARA: —I just refer honourable members to the point that is so clearly made on page 3 of the first table, which is alluded to in the letter from Mr McKinnon . Honourable members will recall that Mr Cadman, and then the Leader of the Opposition, grabbing upon it, took the figures for the United Kingdom for 1982- 83 and then doubled the half-year figure for 1983-84 to get a picture, he said, of the increase in the number of applications. The figures that he used, incorrect as I have explained they were, were not derived in a straightforward way by going to the Minister and saying: 'What are the most reliable figures?' He rang up a junior person in the Department. What were the figures that he used ? The figures for 1982-83 were 5,340 and the figure was 3,054 for July to December 1983-84. So he had 5,340 for the year 1982-83 and doubled the half-year figure for 1983-84 of 3,054 and said: 'That is more than the figure for 1982-83' . So he, and then the Leader of the Opposition, came in and said: 'Look, there is an increase in the number of applications. What are you doing about it?' What are the facts as shown by page 3 of table 1? The correct figures for 1982-83 are not the 5,340 used by the Opposition but in fact 6,254. What are the half-year figures for 1983-84? It is not the 3,054 used by the other side but 2,541. So I have pointed out, on the basis of Mr McKinnon's statement, why it is totally improper in any conceptual terms to double the half-year figure.

SPEECH.PARA: For the sake of illustration I will use the Cadman Opposition technique and see where we come out. The figure for 1982-83 is 6,254. The half-year figure for 1983-84 is in fact 2,541. So, using the illicit Cadman Opposition technique, if we double 2,541, we come up with 5,082 against the previous year's figure of 6, 254. So with the correct figures, even if we use what is an illicit technique, we still get the opposite picture of the one pointed out by Mr Cadman and on which the Opposition based its whole miserable attack.

I make the further point that the Opposition made no effort to consult the Minister before obtaining the figures. Having obtained them, it made no attempt to discuss the matter with the Minister, notwithstanding the Government's citation of other statistics which argued a contrary trend. Given the sensitivity of these issues, one might have expected a little extra care to be shown, a little more time to be spent, a little more effort to be invested, before bipartisanship and national consensus were put at risk by public political attacks based on false premises. Put simply, the Opposition's case is based upon inaccurate statistics, improperly used. It has at its heart the false allegation that the Government has somehow sought to deter migration from Europe . Mr McKinnon's statement refutes that allegation-if it ever needed to be refuted-when he says, and I repeat:
I would like to give you my unqualified assurance that no policy or operational instructions have been promulgated which would inhibit migration from traditional source countries.

For several days now, the Opposition has vilified my colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, who has steadfastly and honestly set out the facts to this House regarding the trend in Australia's migration flow. He has been completely vindicated by the information released today. The Government has throughout emphasised the importance of a bipartisan position on this crucial issue. For its part, the Opposition has paid lip service to the concept of bipartisanship but claims that it no longer exists as a result of Government policies. It is not enough for the Opposition to assert that it seeks bipartisanship and then by its behaviour to undermine it. The Opposition's behaviour in this place in recent days has diminished the dignity, decorum and reason which ought to surround this issue. As the Sydney Morning Herald said this morning:

The Opposition's claim that the Government has departed from bipartisan immigration policy by running a 'pro-Asian and anti-British' policy is nonsense . . . it is the Opposition and not the Government that is seeking to depart from bipartisan policy . . . it seems that Mr Peacock does not want a constructive debate. The Opposition just wants to make a quick killing.

It is not too late to restore decency and common sense to discussion of this issue. At this point, Mr Speaker, I repeat the call which I made to the Leader of the Opposition in the House on 8 May to put an end to this debate as a party political dispute and in particular to dampen down the racial overtones which it can so easily assume. I said that it would be to the great service of this country and all its citizens, and to our relations with countries in this area, if we did not allow this very dangerous issue to be raised and to become something that is in the forefront of political debate.

As Senator Chipp said in the statement to which I referred earlier, the rhetoric which is surrounding the debate does not match the facts and the danger is that the consequences of the rhetoric will be to fan those underground elements of racism and prejudice. A bipartisan policy in this area is of crucial national importance. Splitting the debate along political and partisan lines would only serve to cause wholly undesirable divisions within our society.

Is there anyone in this place who wants to see discrimination reintroduced into our immigration policies, with all the tragic social damage and conflict which that would bring to this great country? Does anyone here want to see Australia turn its back on those in our region who have known anguish and human suffering? Do we want to see Australia lose its reputation as a tolerant, open-hearted country which can hold its head high in the world? I know where the Government stands on this matter. I would like to believe that the Opposition stands with us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I note with interest the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He has spoken at length and covered many areas of the debate which is of fundamental interest not just to members of this House but to the Australian public at large. At the outset, let me reaffirm the Opposition's right and indeed duty to question any policy, any action or any intention of the Government. There were indications during this week that the Government would have had it otherwise. Be that as it may, I reaffirm that right -a right from which we will not resile.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition raised this issue on Monday. It had been running in the community for a lengthy time prior to that. From the time we raised it until now , we had no response from the Government to our specific questions. We have had no response until now to the specific matters raised but we have had a torrent of vilification of the basest nature from honourable members opposite. For three full sitting days the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) did not respond to our direct questions. The Minister failed to address or answer the questions and the uncertainty bred by his own inability to respond to specific questions, and he fanned the debate. The fact that he still sits mute and that it is the Prime Minister who in reality has taken over the handling of the immigration portfolio is a damning indictment of the Minister.

Before we go any further, the Prime Minister should recognise that he has a public duty to put a member of the Government in charge of this portfolio who has the ability and the sensitivity to handle it. All the fine sentiments that have been expressed throughout the Prime Minister's statement-I put to one side the statistics that I will deal with in a moment-do not allow the cloud of sentiment to fog the fact that the man who is handling this portfolio has done it in an abusive, abrasive and insensitive manner and has not had the ability to articulate the case for the Government. He was a major contributing factor to this debate being fanned in the community even before the matter was raised in this Parliament. I again call upon the Prime Minister to act now to replace the Minister.

I reiterate that the Opposition's record in the field of immigration and ethnic affairs is impeccable. We have nothing to answer for. The previous Fraser Government responded to pressures unknown in our region. I know that only too well. As Foreign Minister, with respective immigration Ministers, I had to sell that case to the electorate. I know the sensitivities in the community. We achieved the largest per capita intake of Indo-Chinese refugees in the world. That was something to be proud of. The fact is that coalition governments, which have been in charge of Federal government for most of the time since the Second World War, have maintained in immigration an enlightened record of both humanity and decency, and we retain that attitude now during our period in Opposition. Throughout those lengthy periods in government we took the Australian community along with us, each step of the way. We understood the sensitivity of the matter , we sought to take the community with us and we did.

TALK.START.PARA: —With help from the Labor Party.

—Indeed, we did have some help from honourable members opposite. I said earlier this week that in the latter period of the Fraser Government we welcomed the bipartisan support which developed for our immigration program. I pay particular tribute to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who was then Opposition spokesman on immigration. So let us keep the record straight in this area. We have nothing to answer for, either in our conduct in government or indeed in opposition. Let me indicate why we have nothing to answer for with regard to any matter we have raised in recent days and why we will be prepared to continue to ask questions and to make statements. It is because the acceptance of bipartisanship simply on the terms laid down by one side strikes at the very root of democracy. Unless we are satisfied that we can support a case put forward by the Government, we are duty bound to question the policies of that Government. Let not one cubit of rhetoric intrude to override that fundamental element. Bipartisanship in many more fields of governmental activity would probably be welcomed by both sides of the House. It can be accepted, no matter who is in power, only if the case is one that both sides find acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the Prime Minister's case today rested on an attack on our claim that the intake balance has been upset. He has produced new sets of figures. On behalf of the Opposition I want the House to examine these figures which show that the proportion of settlers coming to Australia from Europe, the United Kingdom and Ireland is still higher than from any other area. He said that in the nine months to 31 March 1984, migration visas issued to people from that area constituted some 45 per cent of the total number granted. But this is not the issue and these figures do not answer the questions we have asked.

The issue of concern as we have stated time and again, is the balance and the mix. In fact, the figures from the Prime Minister today are less relevant than those circulated by the Minister yesterday. The Minister's figures on all migration to Australia excluding refugees show that there has been a major shift in the source of migrants. In 1982-83, according to the Minister's figures, 38.1 per cent of visas were issued to people from the United Kingdom and Ireland. In 1983-84, up to 31 March 1984, the figure was 25.6 per cent. In the same period of time the percentage of visas issued to Europeans dropped from 23.2 per cent to 19.6 per cent and those from Asia rose from 19 per cent to 32 per cent. Of course, this has come about, as we accept, for a number of reasons.

First, there has been an increase in the number of family reunion visas given to Asians. This will be a long term trend that no one should continue to question. We have never questioned the propriety and correctness of continuing to do this. We categorically reject any attempt to create first and second class citizens by discriminating against specific groups' rights to bring in their families. Secondly, and significantly, there has been a massive drop in the number of migrants coming to Australia in the category of labour and business migration. These migrants traditionally have come from the United Kingdom, Ireland and Europe. This category has been cut dramatically by the Minister and cut without consultation with the Opposition with which the Government is supposed to be in full support, and without consultation with interested community groups such as the council that we questioned the Minister on yesterday which has simply been disbanded. The membership of that council's term expired without even a note of thanks from the Minister for services rendered, let alone a discussion as to what the council may contribute to the migration debate and the migration mix in future. There is also, of course, the unilateral decision to cut assistance to the Big Brother Movement without any consultation prior to the determination being taken by the Minister. The decision was taken solely on the advice of his Department without the advisings of community groups which have helped so long in the field of immigration.

As I have said time and again immigration policy has to take account of two groups in particular: Those who want to come to Australia and those who are already here. The community consultative mechanism in this area is of extraordinary importance. That too has been swept aside. The reason that the category I referred to has been cut is because of consultation with but one group in the community, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. As a consequence of trade union pressure, that category has diminished. This has contributed to undermining the bipartisan nature of our migration policy and community acceptance of it. It could be so easily restored by actions of this Government, not by actions on our side. For the traditional balance of our migration policy to be pursued in a bipartisan manner many require the Government to improve on its record in those areas. The pursuit of short term and sectional policies by the Labor Government is what is threatening community acceptance.

Thirdly, the cut in immigration, in independent migration and in a special eligibility category relating to self-supporting retirees has cut again the number of UK and European migrants coming to this country. That has further undermined the traditional balance. I wish now to return to remarks made about the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). I want to say how the Prime Minister, in his statement, misrepresents the honourable member for Mitchell. Firstly, at page 9 of his statement the Prime Minister criticises the honourable member. Why? He criticises him for believing information provided by the Department. Is he serious?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not officially provided.

—I have seen that information and it was provided on the letterhead of the Department. Secondly, the Prime Minister tries to denigrate the honourable member by saying that the Minister released information yesterday on overall applications from Europe. As the Prime Minister knows, the honourable member's request for information and the information supplied related purely to family reunion. That was the request and that was the response. It was not related to total migration. Why try to mislead the House on this issue? Thirdly, the Prime Minister made this claim:

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition's figures purported to show that family reunion applications from Europe were increasing against this trend.

He was referring to the trend in total applications. This was not the case. The honourable member for Mitchell was simply saying that the Government's information disproved the Minister's claim, made in this House-is in the record of the Hansard of 7 March-that family reunion applications from Europe and the United Kingdom were falling due to declining interest. Fourthly, the Prime Minister, at page 4 of his statement, says:
. . . The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has received no request from the Opposition for up-to-date immigration statistics.

I refer the Prime Minister and his Minister not just to telephone calls or letters, but also to the actions in the Parliament which, I am sure, the Minister follows assiduously. I refer him to page 25 of the Senate Hansard for the Estimates Committee B meeting of 30 April. As we know, transcripts of Estimates committees are mandatory reading for any Minister who is administering his portfolio efficiently. At Estimates committee meetings no junior officers speak for the Minister; senior officers designated by the Minister do so. On page 25 of the report of that Estimates Committee Senator Walters, a Liberal senator from Tasmania, asked the Government representative from the Minister's Department, Mr L. Woodward, whose rank is a Deputy Secretary, the following question:

Could you give me the number of applications and the number of approved migrants for the United Kingdom and Ireland, for each country separately in Europe and Asia, and in North America and South America?
Mr Woodward replied:
We have the information, but it would take a fair time to extract it for the countries that you have mentioned.

Senator Walters to date has received nothing. Let me say for the record, in relation to that question, that as Leader of the Opposition I specifically asked the Opposition shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to have an honourable senator obtain these figures at the Estimates committee hearing. Furthermore, is it not interesting to note, bearing in mind the alleged bipartisan spirit that the Government would wish to embrace and the readiness with which it alleges it would consult with us, that we asked for this information on 30 April and have still not received it, but the Government asked for the information and received it in 48 hours. So much for the co-operation retrospectively offered now. I will use the Prime Minister's own phrase so far as this is concerned. I will use a phrase in regard to that behaviour which I think is fairly apt from our point of view. At page 8 of the statement-I will use the words as if they were my own-the Prime Minister said:

Given the sensitivity of these issues, one might have expected a little extra care to be shown, a little more time to be spent, a little more effort to be invested, before bipartisanship and national consensus were put at risk.

Let him take back his words. Even when the Prime Minister seeks to rely on Mr McKinnon's letter to rebut the figures produced by the honourable member for Mitchell he is on shaky ground. Mr McKinnon, in his letter, acknowledges that the Department's data base for applications to emigrate to Australia are ' notoriously unreliable'. Yet I assume that his revised figures, or as he calls them 'a re-run of the figures' are based on the same data that is described as notoriously unreliable-the data that was the basis of the figures given to the honourable member for Mitchell.

Mr McKinnon also alleged that the figures were seasonal and that the honourable member's doubling of the six-month figures to December to get an indication of the likely figure for the full year was invalid. In relying on this, the Prime Minister is also wrong. As Mr McKinnon's figures show, in two out of the three years cited in his letter, applications from people in the United Kingdom to emigrate to Australia were higher in the second half of the financial year than in the first half. Only in the 1982-83 financial year was the figure lower in the second half than in the first half. As Mr McKinnon himself admitted in his letter-let me add that everyone on this side of the House has enormous regard for Mr McKinnon; this is no criticism of him or his officers-a doubling of the figures runs the risk of not just over-estimating but also of grossly under- estimating. I suggest to the House that the honourable member's doubling of the six-month figures in that year to achieve an estimate for the 12 months of the number of applications from people wishing to emigrate can, therefore, be assumed to be as valid as any figures produced before this Parliament.

The Prime Minister stated today that his Government does not consider-I want the House to hear this-that a balance or a mix in our immigration program, determined on racial grounds, can have any place in our society. He then went on to acknowledge the need to ensure that our migration program does not threaten the stability and the fabric of Australian society. I invite honourable members to read what he said at page 8 so they can put these two statements together. I am approaching this in the most restrained way, having become used to the cloud of sentiment, the smokescreen that overrides the facts, the misleading argument, the duplicity of argument, and the contrast, paragraph by paragraph; when one has time to analyse prime ministerial statements of recent days. At page 4 of the statement the Prime Minister said:
This Government does not consider that a balance or mix in our migration program determined on racial grounds can have any place in our society.
That is a fine statement. In the next paragraph he said:

We of course acknowledge the need to ensure that our migration program does not threaten the stability and fabric of Australian society. But in working towards this end the Government considers that not only is the size and composition of our intake important--
He has put it down before. Earlier he said that the composition was not important; we had no need to worry about the composition, the balance, the mix--
but also the programs within our community to permit the integration of migrants into our society . . .

That is a point with which I concur. It is our contention that a balance, a mix and a proper composition in our migration program is essential to ensure the stability and the fabric of Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition is misleading the House in making this interpretation.

—There is no point of order. The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. I remind the House that the Prime Minister was heard in silence. The Leader of the Opposition is entitled to the same courtesy.

—I refer to comments I made in the House on Tuesday, 8 May and which I briefly touched upon earlier in this address. A successful immigration program takes into account two factors in particular. They are: Those people wanting to come to Australia and those people who are already in Australia, for we have to recognise, as I think the majority of Australians do and try to adhere to- extremists do not; we will have no truck with them-the fragility of the concept of community acceptance. Do not override it; do not throw it out. Honourable members opposite seem to put it to one side. The fragility of the concept of community acceptance is fundamental to the continuation of our migration program . All we have fought for for many years will be put at risk if the Government continues in the way it is at present. Creating an imbalance is reflected in community concern. This Minister and this Government have done just that.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that I have heard too much sentimentality and have witnessed too much hand wringing by the Prime Minister who thinks he can override facts. He thinks that by simply appealing to the heart everyone's heart and mind will automatically respond. Some of us take the time to analyse what he is really about. If he were to come in here with a statement that was not so easily torn apart on a factual basis, we could be moved by the sentiment, but the cloud of sentiment must not fob the facts. Let me repeat: All honourable members on this side of the House dissociate themselves from racist groups. There is not a member here who will not totally reject such groups. There is not a member here who does not have the right to say that there has been a change in the balance of the migrant intake. Honourable members have a right and a duty to raise that matter while the Minister continues to administer his portfolio in this way.

As I come to the conclusion of the statement, let me say that there is not one thing that we have alleged from which I would resile. When I search my mind I rest with ease on what we have said. The Prime Minister's statement is misleading. As I have said, one can share the cloud of sentiment, but the figures do not diminish in any way the Opposition's claim, nor do they even sit squarely with the Minister's figures issued yesterday. It is just not enough for the Government to appeal for bipartisanship and by its own behaviour seek to undermine it. Those opposite have no monopoly on human understanding, decency or compassion. It seems that over the past few days to question is to be smeared. Evidently to ask is to allege. They are the oldest techniques of smearing in the book. We affirm our actions, we affirm our questions and all my analysis of the Prime Minister's statement today leads me to affirm our stance. We will not be deterred from pursuing this matter in a measured, balanced and proper way until we have the same response from the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do indeed, by the Prime Minister.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during his speech made several references to me and to matters pertaining to the production of figures by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I wish to address my remarks to those matters. I wish first to outline for the House the process by which those figures were obtained. Following the statement on 7 March by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in regard to immigration I requested my secretary to phone the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on my behalf requesting up to date figures on applicants for family reunion, which she did. The Department subsequently supplied those figures in the form with which honourable members are familiar. The figures were provided to me and I tabled the document yesterday so that everybody could be aware of it and of the figures that I had obtained. The letter from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was signed by Mr Phillip Richards, Immigration Policy Branch, Central Office of the Department. It did not come from the regional office but from the Central Office, the Canberra office of the Department. The response was addressed to Joan Andrews, who is my secretary, at my office address.

SPEECH.PARA: The figures were supplied on 5 April and received in my office on 16 April. Attached to the letter were tables supplying the information which I sought. The information is headed: 'Applications for family migration by category by country of last residence (cases)'. I have noticed that the Minister's figures have always been supplied to me and to the House in a similar form, with the tables attached to a covering letter. I take very great umbrage at the Prime Minister hinting that I have taken the figures supplied to me and in some way dealt with them in an unfair way, that I may have changed the figures, that the figures were unofficial and were not in a recognised form. I think that a request made by a member of Parliament to a department on that basis should be responded to and I am happy with the way in which the Department responded to my simple request. I take umbrage at the attitude of the Prime Minister and at the inference that he has made against me in the House today. He indicated that I had gone to a junior officer in some furtive way, drawn from him figures that would suit an argument of the Opposition or my own personal attitudes and, if the figures did not suit my cause, changed the figures and presented them to the House. That is untrue and I resent the implication.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman is now debating the matter.
—The Prime Minister, I believe, has offended the record that I have set up in this House for truth and honesty. I will seek to match his own record for truth and honesty in this House.
—The honourable gentleman is now debating the matter. Has he finished his personal explanation?
—No, I have not, Madam Deputy Speaker. There are other matters relating to the Prime Minister's statement that I wish to cover.
—The honourable member is permitted within his personal explanation only to explain how he personally has been misrepresented.

—Yes, indeed. My remarks are restricted to that area. I will continue in that vein and in that vein alone. When I received the figures I adjusted them in that I added family reunion by categories A, B and C together. For the financial year 1983-84 I had only the half year figures, which I doubled to supply a full year comparison. When I presented the figures in the House on Monday night, I explained very carefully precisely what I had done. Anyone can read that speech and confirm for himself that I did that. Again yesterday I explained to the House by way of personal explanation precisely the process that I used. In fact, at the head of the table that I produced are the words: 'Table detailing the number of applicants of family migration by country of last residence. Note: Figures supplied by Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, figures for 1983-84 achieved by doubling half year to December 1983 ( latest figure)'.
—Even the Prime Minister could understand that.

—I am sure that the Prime Minister is capable of understanding that. The Prime Minister has in this instance again misrepresented me and again sought to besmirch my reputation in this House by the words he used in the chamber today. I will go further. I will now deal with the figures themselves and whether or not they are reliable and were obtained in a way--
—Order! I think the honourable gentleman has established for his own benefit and the benefit of the House the way in which he has been misrepresented.
—Indeed not, Madam Deputy Speaker.
—He is now seeking the indulgence of the Chair to go further into the debate.

—No, I am not. I am going to continue my personal explanation. The Prime Minister's speech, I believe, attacked my integrity. He covered three matters. I have dealt with two. I wish to go on to deal with the other matter affecting me that the Prime Minister raised. The Prime Minister has said that these figures are notoriously unreliable and that I should have used the Minister's office to confirm them. I think that is an unreasonable statement to make to any member of parliament. The request was made properly by a member of my staff on my behalf. The figures were produced by the Department and sent to my office. In fact, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in his letter to me, undated but received today, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out that the figures which your office obtained--
he referred not to me but to my office--
and you used in the House are wrong.

The Minister knows that the Prime Minister was not accurate in his comments in the House today and his letter indicates that. The Prime Minister then went further and spoke about the unreliability of the figures. He said that I should have been aware of their unreliability. What is there to indicate that the current figures are any more reliable? The Prime Minister made the comment: ' These figures are notoriously unreliable'. In fact he has condemned the figures produced today, as well as the figures produced properly for me, as being ' notoriously unreliable'. I ask the House: Are the Prime Minister's figures reliable? What guarantee have we--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the personal explanation?
—Will the honourable gentleman please return to his personal explanation, otherwise I will have to ask him to resume his seat.
—I am dealing with the reliability of the figures.
—The honourable gentleman may not go through the Prime Minister's speech figure by figure. He must prove to the House how he has been personally misrepresented.

—The Prime Minister claims that the figures he produced are more reliable than the ones I received. I ask: Are his figures reliable or are figures produced after a major political controversy more likely to be reliable or unreliable? I made the assumption on the figures produced for me by the Department that regular assessments are made to produce statistics for the use of the Department. Three months after the end of a half year seems a reasonable time to obtain figures from the Department. My figures were produced in April and the Prime Minister's figures were produced in May. It seems that either the Department is incompetent or it does not keep statistics as there is a difference between the two months in the figures supplied to me and those supplied to the Prime Minister. The figures should be regular and easily accessible to members of parliament.
—Order! The Chair cannot continue to hear the personal explanation. The honourable member is debating the entire issue of the Prime Minister's statement. I ask him to resume his seat.
—No, I am not.
—I ask the honourable member to resume his seat.
—No. I have not concluded my comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the report of the Committee entitled 'Payments to Athletes and Teams who did not participate in the 1980 Moscow Olympics', together with the minutes of proceedings, the transcript of evidence and documents authorised for publication .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the House. Madam Deputy Speaker, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, I present the Committee's report on payments to athletes and teams who did not participate in the 1980 Moscow Olympics. Unfortunately limited numbers of copies are available. More copies should be available within three weeks. The inquiry was brought about by statements in the Press by Raelene Boyle in late November last year which suggested that she had received a 'Federal Government pay-off' in 1980 for her withdrawal from the Australian team for the Moscow Olympics. In the ensuing controversy it was reported that some six athletes who had withdrawn from the Australian Olympic team had received payments of $6,000 each and much larger sums had been paid in respect of seven teams who had also withdrawn. In fact, in a statement at the time, Miss Boyle said she felt that the Government was saying :

SPEECH.PARA: . . . here you are kid, take this money and shut up. It was only a small career and who cares anyway?

That was what Miss Boyle thought of the Federal Government's attitude to her at the time. The Committee's concern was aroused by the highly unusual nature of the payments, the apparent secrecy with which they had been made, which carried the hint of impropriety, and by the contradictory explanations of the parties involved-that is, the athletes and the various Ministers. At the time of Ms Boyle's statement the Committee was in the stages of concluding an inquiry into Commonwealth Government assistance for sport and recreation. The Committee decided to extend the terms of reference of that inquiry, which dealt with the efficiency and effectiveness of Commonwealth sport and recreation programs, to include payments to athletes and teams who did not participate in the 1980 Moscow Olympics. The Committee's report on the earlier terms of reference, 'The Way We P(l)ay: Commonwealth Assistance for Sport and Recreation', was tabled in this House on 8 December 1983.

The Committee, in pursuing its second term of reference in relation to payments to athletes, decided to ascertain: The nature and purpose of the payments; whether the payments were properly and lawfully made; whether they were made through the appropriate channels; and whether the recipients were equitably treated. The objectives of the inquiry reflected the Committee's concern, expressed in previous inquiries, about standards of government financial management and public accountability. In dealing with public controversy concerning a highly specific item of government expenditure, the inquiry represented a divergence from previous Expenditure Committee inquiries. The Committee would like to signal to the House its intention to take up for prompt inquiry and report, in the future, instances of specific apparent breaches of proper financial procedures by government departments and authorities.

It was not the object of this inquiry, however, to pass judgment on the merits of the payments to athletes and teams, or on the propriety of the government of the day in making them, or of the recipients-that is, the athletes-in accepting them. Such matters were, in the Committee's view, not the proper preserve of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. They were decisions that could properly be made by government. The object of the Committee's inquiry was to examine matters of proper administration and equity of treatment of the athletes.

The Committee took evidence at public hearings in Canberra on 28 November and 7 December 1983 and in subsequent correspondence with Commonwealth departments. I would like to record the Committee's appreciation of the assistance of officers of a number of departments, especially the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism and the Department of Finance, who responded expertly and thoroughly, at short notice, to the Committee's requests for information. As Chairman of the Committee, I would like to thank also my fellow Committee members and the staff of the Committee secretariat, particularly the Secretary of the Committee, Mrs Sue Harlow, the Secretary of the Sub-committee, Mr David Worthy, and Mrs Betty Williams for her secretarial support.

Between June and December 1980 over $524,000 was paid to sporting organisations and individual athletes with respect to individuals and teams who chose not to compete in the 1980 summer Olympics in Moscow. Over $448,000 was paid in respect of seven teams for the purpose of meeting the cost of alternative high level international competition by the seven teams which withdrew from the Australian Olympic team. Payments totalling $36,000 were made to six athletes competing in individual sports who withdrew also from the Australian team. It was intended that these individual athletes would be financially assisted to compete in alternative high level competition. However, these arrangements proved not feasible and the Government finally decided to make 'flat rate ex gratia payments' in the words of the former Minister, of $6000 to each athlete to be used for alternative international competition or to further the athlete's careers in sport.

The payments to athletes and teams were made by the Government as compensation to persons who withdrew as a consequence of Government policy decisions, either in support of the Government's actions or as a result of the ensuing public controversy. Shortly after its decision in January 1980 to support a boycott of the 1980 Moscow Olympics, the Government publicly announced that it was prepared to compensate athletes and teams who chose not to compete in the Games in Moscow . Payments made with respect to one team which withdrew received considerable publicity at the time. However, there appears to have been no public announcement of the subsequent payments to individual athletes. Although the Government had the authority to make such payments, the Committee found that, with respect to payments to athletes, appropriate accounting procedures were not always followed, the payments were not made through the most suitable channels and the treatment of competitors in team sports was inequitable. On the other hand, the eligibility tests applied to payments for teams were far too lax.

Specifically, the payments to individual athletes were not properly authorised because of an oversight in the appropriation legislation. A decision to not require individual recipients to vouch for the monies received was inadvisable. Payments to individual athletes should have been made in consultation with and through the relevant national sporting organisations. Eligibility for payment should have extended to competitors in team sports, and the eligibility tests which were applied to the assessment of payments to individual athletes should have been applied to the assessment of payments for teams. The lapses in accounting practices resulted in part from shortcomings in a number of financial regulations and their interpretive guidelines. The Committee was pleased to note that, after the inquiry had brought to light the shortcomings, the Department of Finance took prompt action to effect appropriate changes to regulations and their guidelines.

The shortcomings in the execution of the payments could be attributed, to a degree, to the unusual if not unique circumstances of the case and the pressure on officers to expedite the payments as quickly as possible. The Committee did not wish to dwell on these historic events and has recommended to the Government a number of guidelines for compensation of sportspeople which, the Committee believes, should be incorporated in a broader statement of Commonwealth policy towards international sporting ties and events affected by government foreign policy actions. I hope that the Committee's findings and recommendations, if taken up, will serve to ensure that, in future, Australia's elite athletes, involved as sometimes they unavoidably are in the international political arena, will receive more justice than they sometimes have received at the hands of governments.

However, we should not single out governments for the less than fair treatment of our sporting heroes. As events of recent weeks have shown, Australia's athletes have suffered too often at the hands of their own sporting organisations. I believe the decision of the Australian Amateur Swimming Union to exclude Michelle Ford from Australia's Olympic swimming team was deplorable. That decision would have been less deplorable if hers had been a special case. Unfortunately, as is indicated by evidence given to the Expenditure Committee last year during its inquiry into Commonwealth assistance for sport and recreation, the Australian Amateur Swimming Union appears to be especially heedless of the claims of and unresponsive to the needs of its own athletes. Mr Forbes Carlile, one of Australia's foremost swimming coaches, in evidence to the Committee, said:

The Amateur Swimming Union of Australia is considered by many, by acts of commission [instance the Commonwealth Games mismanagement] and omission . . . to be infamous for incompetence and backwardness.
In July 1983 Michelle's mother, Mrs Jan Ford, gave evidence to the Committee. One might say that this is ironic in regard to what has happened recently. Mrs Ford said:

Clearly the bottleneck offered by the ASU of A to progressive ideas presented by the coaches . . . has as much of a chance of reaching government bureaucracy as 'hell freezing over'. Progressive ideas are not implemented in the present structure of the Swimming Union within 10 years or so, particularly if there seems to be a possibility of disturbing the status quo and the position of officers elected by narrow entry and demanding a very long period of time- serving.

I would like to see the Government's early endorsement of the recommendation of the Committee's previous report that Commonwealth financial assistance to sporting organisations should be conditional upon those organisations instituting a democratic decision-making process.

I think that the recent decision of the Amateur Swimming Union showed that that organisation has an extremely undemocratic process of government, and it should be widened to include representation by sportspeople who are actually involved in swimming. A number of other sporting organisations could come in for the same criticism. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Leader of the House (Mr Young) for his co- operation. I support the remarks that were made by my colleague the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), who is Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. I think it is necessary to add that some of the remarks that the Chairman made in his speech were not specifically related to the report that has been brought down. I know that he would not want to misrepresent the bipartisan nature of the Committee's work; neither would any of the members of the Committee. I think it ought to be said that the remarks he made at the conclusion of his speech about the Australian Amateur Swimming Union, Michelle Ford and a range of other things were not matters directly related to the report and ought not to be seen as confusing the sentiments of the report that had been brought down. I just want to make that clear to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983 [No. 4]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clauses 1 to 10-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter of considerable concern on these clauses which in general deal with the recovery of additional amounts of tax from persons who were shareholders in companies previously dealt with by the Fraser Government's unpaid company tax legislation. In fact, this objective represents a classic example of government double-dipping. I think that the Government has completely overlooked the fact that the previous Government under the then Treasurer Howard went to the trouble of introducing the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982 which gave a very clear definition of the taxes that were proposed to be collected. The following definition appears on page 2 of the Act:

SPEECH.PARA: 'company tax' means ordinary company tax or undistributed profits tax;

Undistributed profits tax is a penalty, if one likes, applicable in respect of all proprietary limited companies. Let us face it, by far the largest percentage of companies that went to the bottom of the harbour were in this category; very few, if any, public companies were involved. The facts are that any company trading as a private company that fails to make a distribution of a certain percentage of its after-tax profits to its shareholders in whose hands it would be taxed attracts a penalty tax known as undistributed profits tax. This having been done, the funds can be kept within the company structure. There might be all sorts of reasons why directors of companies make that decision. But having made it-and this is happening today somewhere in Australia-no other tax burden is put upon the shareholders. The company picks up a 50 per cent surcharge for failing to have made a distribution.

I gather from the second reading speech of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) and other sources that the Government is arguing that it has missed out on the tax that shareholders would have otherwise paid when companies went to the bottom of the harbour and, in fact, made no distribution of profits. When I looked at the amount of tax that some of my constituents were paying on the profits that were recorded in their books of account, I found that they were up for 50 per cent more than what appeared to be the profit. I contacted the office of the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Western Australia and, of course, had pointed out to me that the previous legislation allowed the Commissioner to collect both ordinary company tax and undistributed profit tax. In fact, that was what was happening. So, in fact, the Tax Commissioner has applied the normal penalty that would apply if those companies were still operating and happened to take their decision not to distribute their dividends which it is now claimed, by these devices, they failed to distribute.

All sorts of suggestions have been made about the liquidation of these companies. Most, of course, have not been liquidated. They just ceased to exist because they were stripped of their assets and given directors who were very hard to find. But, to the best of my knowledge, no conscious effort has been taken by any State commission in fact to wrap up and liquidate the many hundreds of thousands of these companies. Therefore, I say that they are still applicable to the rules that apply that the proper tax is being collected under the previous legislation by way of the undistributed profits tax.

I do not know whether the Government is contemplating in the near future bringing in some other retrospective legislation which says that in the normal course of taxation practice, the Government will collect a fee which is 50 per cent or otherwise of the burden on all companies which fail to distribute on the due date. I put it to the Committee that the Commissioner of Taxation will impose such a tax that if a company even reports, having failed to make a distribution on the due date. Even if the distribution is made the day after, the Commissioner will impose that tax. Companies are paying that penalty under the legislation brought forward by the previous Government. Therefore, this piece of legislation clearly is totally unnecessary and amounts to double- dipping. It can be classified only as some sort of punishment of people who have been involved in these schemes. If that is what the Government's intention is, let the Minister say: 'We are going to give these people a hiding for the temerity of taking the advice of their accountants and lawyers'. We know that the Government appears to support the practice of another Minister who did that.

The real facts are that at the moment people are being levied a certain amount of money by the Commissioner of Taxation. They are paying the normal penalty applicable for failing to distribute their profits. So why is it necessary to bring in another piece of legislation?

The Minister has mentioned a figure of $270m, nearly all of which will be collected by taxing the dividends that people are deemed to have received but which they did not receive. Is the Minister going to tell us: 'Fine, I will go down that track but I will contact the various deputy commissioners and tell them they must refund people 50 per cent of the undistributed profits tax that they have already paid'? If one deems a distribution, surely to goodness one is not also going to deem an undistributed profits tax which people are paying at present.

I beg the Government to consider what the Opposition is on about. The Government should get away from the paranoia it has of members of the Opposition being people entirely committed to assisting those who have otherwise acted improperly in respect of matters that come before the Taxation Commissioner. It should realise that the necessary legislation to collect the money that it says it is seeking has been brought down and it should wake up to the fact that this piece of legislation is not necessary. It is an unnecessary burden particularly to a person who has received the type of dividend that the Government is going to deem in this legislation may have had no tax liability anyway if he had had personal losses in some other part of his business career which, of course, is to be ignored also. If that is the case, why cannot the Minister admit that this is a piece of window-dressing that has been brought in to satisfy the union movement that the Government was going to do something and, of course, to satisfy its own ego that there was something left to be done. If the Government does that, it will recognise that this piece of legislation is not in any way necessary. The money that the Government seeks to raise, the $270m, is being picked up already under the previous legislation because the definition of company tax is ordinary company tax and undistributed profits tax.

I can give the Committee no better reason for my personal opposition and the opposition of the parties on this side of the chamber. We do not agree with the Government double-dipping. The Government tells us that it does not like pensioners double-dipping but apparently on this occasion, as with its cherry- picking legislation, it is directing its attention in the wrong place. Of course , it has yet to come to the conclusion that the losers in the cherry-picking schemes were the people who did not get their superannuation entitlements, not government revenue. I do not think that the Minister can answer my question. If he cannot do so, I ask him to support the Opposition in opposing this piece of the legislation.
Question put:
That clauses 1 to 10 be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House seeks to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 and the Representation Act 1983. The amendments proposed result from a further review of electoral legislation. The amendments are in the main of a minor or machinery nature. There are, however, a number of proposed changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which honourable members might note.

The Bill provides for the consecutive renumbering of provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. A reprint of the Act incorporating the renumbering will be published as soon as possible after this Bill comes into effect.

The franchise of Service personnel on overseas service at the commencement of the 1983 amendments is also preserved. Under section 39A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act as it stood prior to the 1983 amendments, Service personnel overseas and persons accompanying Defence Force units in an official capacity were eligible to vote even if unenrolled. Consistent with the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act 1983 repealed this section and substituted a new provision, new section 39A, which broadly speaking allows persons going overseas to retain their enrolments if they notify their divisional returning officer in the month prior to their departure.

However, the 1983 amendments did not preserve the franchise of those Service personnel and persons accompanying them in an official capacity who were already overseas. To avoid a situation where some 1,500 servicemen are disenfranchised, clause 6 of the Bill provides that they have until the issue of the writ for the next general election to apply for registraion as eligible overseas electors as if they were about to depart for their postings. Once the Service personnel are registered, their spouses and dependants will also be able to register as overseas electors. Clause 6 does not cover Service personnel who have been posted since the commencement of the 1983 amendments.

Still on the question of overseas electors, doubts have been expressed whether the provisions of section 39A enable an enrolled person who is going overseas to register as an eligible overseas elector if, at the time of his departure, he is intending to return to the place of living for which he is enrolled. The proposed amendment will remedy this situation.

The format of the Senate ballot paper is also to be changed. Currently the Act provides that in the printing of Senate ballot papers the letters A, B, et cetera be printed before the squares opposite the names of grouped candidates. This requirement is reflected in the Senate ballot paper which appears as Form E in Schedule 1 of the Act. The Government has accepted an interim recommendation from the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that the present statutory requirement of printing letters before the squares should be repealed. If in the Committee's final report some form of lettering to identify groups is recommended for Senate ballot papers, this and any other recommendations regarding format can be given effect to by regulations made under the Act.

Section 42 of the Act provides for a claim for enrolment or transfer of enrolment to be lodged with any divisional returning officer, but does not provide for such claims to be lodged at the central office or State head offices of the Australian Electoral Commission. This may disadvantage some electors in a close of roll situation. The proposed amendments will enable a claim to be lodged with an Australain Electoral Officer in addition to the divisional returning officer.

A new section 58W is proposed to provide for separate registers of candidates for each Senate election, general election for the House of Representatives, and for each by-election. New provisions are also to be inserted requiring candidates seeking registration to do so before the close of nominations. Similarly, parties and candidates desiring to receive public funding in respect of their campaign expenditure will have to register for that purpose respectively by the issue of the writ and by the close of nominations.

There are a number of proposed amendments which deal with the preliminary scrutiny of postal votes. The amendments will expressly permit divisional returning officers to do this in stages as the votes are received and to this extent they will reflect current practice. Divisional returning officers will be required to give notice of any such scrutiny on the day before. This will enable scrutineers to attend.

In the past the substantive provisions regulating absent voting have been contained in the Electoral and Referendum Regulations. The Government has decided that it is more appropriate that they should be dealt with in the Commonwealth Electoral Act itself. The Bill contains a number of amendments to this end.

The Bill amends the Act in a number of respects to allow the scrutiny of Senate ballot papers to be conducted at a central point in each State or Territory rather than in divisional offices. The introduction of the 'fractional transfer' Senate scrutiny system last year will greatly increase the number of counts required at a typical Senate election. If a centralised scrutiny is not adopted, the need for communication between divisional offices and State head offices of the Electoral Commission as part of every count would greatly lengthen the time required to conduct a Senate scrutiny.

The proposed amendment of section 135 (26) is intended to make it clear that the transfer of all surplus votes of an elected candidate constitutes a single, separate transfer of votes. This clarification becomes important where the transfer of a particular elected candidate's surplus elects two candidates. If the distribution of a surplus were regarded as a series of separate transfers, the order of election, in the case of two candidates, would be dependent on which of them first received his share of the surplus. However, if the distribution of all the elected candidates' surplus is regarded as a single transfer, the order of election of the two candidates depends on which of them has the larger surplus over quota. This latter process of determining the order of election is not as arbitrary as the former process.

Section 135 also provides that at a Senate scrutiny where, in a transfer of votes, the number of continuing candidates is equal to the number of remaining unfilled vacancies, those continuing candidates shall be elected. The section, however, requires an unnecessary transfer of votes to be carried out before these continuing candidates can be elected. The amendment of sub-section 135 (16 ) is designed to remedy this situation.

The current legislative requirement in respect of disclosure of gifts also requires amendment. The effect of the existing provisions is that candidates are required to disclose gifts, even of an entirely personal nature. The proposed new paragraph 153J (5) (b) excludes such gifts from the disclosure requirements.

The final Commonwealth Electoral Act amendment to which I draw attention of honourable members is proposed new section 216B. Over the years the electoral administration has had a real administrative burden arising from the need to retain original claim cards in respect of new enrolments and transfer of enrolment. The new section will enable these claim cards to be destroyed where a record of their particulars is kept on microfilm, microfiche or another approved permanent form. The new section further provides for these records to be admissible in evidence in any proceeding and to be prima facie evidence of any such particulars.

As I have already said, the amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Act are of a minor nature. They are designed to correct a number of drafting anomalies which have been detected since its passage, and will have no substantive effect on its operation. The two amendments proposed to the Representation Act are in the same category. The amendment to sub-section 5 (7) is designed to correct an anomaly. At present, the formula for determining which of the successful candidates at the next Senate election will take their places on 1 July 1985 and which will take their places on the date of the first meeting of the next House of Representatives would be incapable of operation if the date of the first meeting were to fall after 1 July 1985. The amendment resolves this problem.

The introduction of this Bill demonstrates the Government's ongoing commitment to sensible reform of our electoral laws. The changes involved here are not controversial and deserve the support of all honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Steele Hall) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill is to change the structure, functions, and powers of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. Concurrently I will be introducing four further bills that together with the Australian Meat and Live- stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1984 will result in the restructuring of the administration of the live-stock and meat industry.

These Bills constitute an integrated package of measures designed to produce an organisational structure that will improve the industry's ability to work co- operatively to develop policies to resolve its problems. This legislation will also clarify the functions and powers of the AMLC, with particular attention to increasing its accountability to the Parliament and to those in the industry whose levy payments provide the source of its finance. In addition to the restructuring of the AMLC, these Bills provide for the establishment of a new Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council and an Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee. There are also consequential changes to the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Act 1964 and the Live-stock Export Charge Act 1977. This package does not include proposed arrangements for restructuring future administration of meat and livestock research and development. The final details of this measure are the subject of further development and discussion with industry. I expect to bring a Bill on this matter before the House during the 1984 Budget sittings.

Honourable members will be aware that the livestock and meat industries have been through a prolonged economic recession. Whilst the capacity of producers to respond to the economic changes that continually buffet them has been well demonstrated, there is no adequate mechanism to enable the respective industry organisations representing processors, exporters, livestock agents, public abattoirs and other groups to join with producers to develop a co-ordinated approach to the analysis and discussion of industry problems for the formulation of new industry policies.

For example, the industry has been discussing over a number of years such important initiatives as single meat inspection, objective product description, AMLC sole trading and industry stabilisation or rationalisation measures. There has been slow, inconclusive and often divisive debate on such issues. The industry's poorly structured policy and decision-making processes have prevented clear advice reaching Government on required actions that would have the full support of the industry.

The AMLC-primarily a market development, promotion and export control body-has attempted to fill this void through its producer and processor consultative groups. This approach has tended to heighten industry divisions and draw the Corporation unnecessarily into agro-political industry debates, although many of the industry's problems cover matters that lie totally outside the Corporation's charter. In its search for an effective leadership structure the production sector of the industry has pressed for industry problems to be addressed by the Corporation. There has been a general lack of understanding that the Corporation 's ability to exercise industry leadership is restricted not only by the States' constitutional responsibilities for the regulation of domestic meat marketing but also because matters concerning, for example, animal health, welfare and hygiene, research, abattoir construction and legislation are the responsibilities of other bodies. This situation is clearly unsatisfactory and in presenting these Bills the Government is fulfilling its election commitment to introduce new administrative arrangements to reform the policy and operational arms of the Australian meat and livestock industry.

The details of these Bills have been developed from the continuous consultations I have had with leaders of the key industry organisations since the Government first came to office. The final package was negotiated with the industry last August, whilst in October the Government endorsed the principles underlying the new arrangements, and empowered me to establish an Industry Selection Committee and Industry Policy Council on an interim basis pending the introduction of this legislation. In future the Industry Policy Council will be responsible for the examination of all broad industry policy issues, and this will require a shift in the industry's present expectation for industry leadership on all issues from the Corporation.

The proposed functions for the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation will remove its responsibility for general policy advice and require it to be more directly concerned with, and confined to, commercial activities associated with market development, the promotion of meat and livestock sales, and finally the regulation of export trading. The more commercial role of the AMLC will require a different approach to the selection of its board. The interim industry selection committee is already at work to choose members of the new Board on the basis of their professional qualifications and work experience in the fields of cattle production, sheep production, livestock exporting, meatworks operation, meat exporting, product promotion, finance, international commodity marketing, business management and industrial relations.

To select highly competent people in these specialised fields is a demanding exercise. Board members will, in future, be recruited from a wider spectrum of Australian business sources. They will not be selected, as in the past, on the basis of their industry 'representation' but for their expertise and direct ability to contribute to a professional team. Whilst this formula guarantees producers a place on the Board, it recognises that a wider balance of commercial experience is essential if the Board is effectively to perform its commercial role.

I now turn to specific clauses and provisions in the Australian Meat and Live- stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1984. Under clause 4 of the Bill honourable members will note that the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation will no longer have a broad policy-advising function. The removal of this responsibility is a deliberate move on the part of the Government to ensure that the Industry Policy Council becomes the primary focus on policy development activity. The Corporation, however, will be expected to develop policies as required on areas concerned with its commercial functions and to contribute to policy development for the industry as a whole by means of the AMLC Chairman's membership of the Policy Council.

In order to help foster better consultation clause 7 of the Bill gives the Corporation power to arrange consultations, as necessary, with relevant industry groups, on matters concerned with its operational responsibilities, and to be responsible for the costs of meetings that it arranges. It is not intended to retain the present formal consultative groups which have not achieved as much as had been expected, but to give this operational corporation the greater flexibility it requires to develop a more direct and meaningful consultative process with producer and processor/trader organisations according to its actual operational needs. Such meetings can be expected to be irregular, possibly shorter and more directly concerned with technical matters. Industry organisations can be expected to give more attention in the future to the consultative an analytical needs of the Industry Policy Council, which is also expected to require considerable assistane from industry in its examination of industry problems.

A number of other modifications to the powers of the Australian Meat and Live- stock Corporation are included in the Bill. They are designed to upgrade the Corporation's commercial powers and place the day to day responsibility for commercial decisions within these heads of power more squarely on the Corporation Board. The Bill provides for the removal of the restriction that the Corporation can only trade in livestock and meat that it owns. This will enhance the Corporation's flexibility and allow it, as an agent, to co-ordinate trading activities by competing Australian exporters in the exercising of its overseas trading powers.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation will now have increased power to engage in sole trading to a particular market where, in the opinion of the Corporation, such action would be beneficial in developing the market for Australian meat or livestock.

Honourable members will note that, under the Bill, the Corporation is required to develop criteria for deciding to exercise this additional power and such criteria will require ministerial approval only as a part of the five-year corporate plan, not for specific actions as a sole trader. Consistent with this principle it is proposed that the Corporation will no longer be required to secure specific ministerial approval in exercising its power to act as a sole trader to a market where a monopoly import situation exists. Criteria for such action are well defined in the existing provisions of the legislation. I am hopeful that the broadening of the Corporation's trading powers that I have outlined will move the focus of the industry debate away from the limits of those powers to a conscious examination of the trading policies that best serve the commercial interests of the industry. I would expect that the meat and livestock industry would play a big part in setting the industry's policies in this area.

The financial powers of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation have also been expanded under the Bill in line with the more commercial role expected of the Corporation. The scope for the raising of moneys by the Corporation, which will require the approval of the Minister for Primary Industry, will be widened to the issuing of securities. A provision has been made in the Bill for the making of regulations to enable the Corporation to charge fees for the licensing of exporters and to recoup the costs of the services it provides to industry, in keeping with the user pays principle. Under clause 25 of the Bill the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation is to assume responsibility for meeting the costs associated with the Policy Council's industry conferences. The Corporation is also to be responsible for all costs and expenses of the Industry Selection Committee. The rationale for this is that the Corporation, funded as it is from industry levy and export charge contributions, is the convenient point from which these other industry endeavours can be funded and so avoid the need to establish separate industry funding arrangements.

Honourable members will recall that I earlier outlined that Corporation members will be chosen on the basis of their professional qualifications and work experience. Under the Bill, the Corporation is to consist of 11 members, namely a chairman, a government representative, the Managing Director of the Corporation and eight other members. The part time Chairman and the government representative are to be appointed by the Minister for Primary Industry. The Managing Director is to be appointed by the Corporation and will become an ex- officio voting member of the Board. The eight other members with the special professional skills and experiene that I have already outlined will be selected for my appointment by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee.

The Bill contains a number of requirements of the Corporation to increase its accountability to the industry and to Parliament through the Minister. The main provision to make the Corporation more accountable to industry members who are affected by its activities, and who contribute to its annual income through payment of slaughter and livestock export levies, is the requirement for the Corporation to convene an annual general meeting of industry members who meet particular eligibility requirements. Voting entitlements of livestock producers will be determined by livestock ownership.

The Bill allows wide-ranging powers for the AGM. The AGM can comment on or query any aspect of the Corporation's annual report or general activities. The AGM can vote on resolutions with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council to be notified of the outcome. Under the Bill the Corporation is required to put as a motion to the AGM any planned variation to levies or charges. The AGM will also have the power to endorse or decline any proposed increases in levies to fund the Corporation. Finally the AGM under clause 22 will have the power to cause the removal of the Corporation's Chairman or Board.

The Bill defines the actions required of the Minister for Primary Industry in the event that the AGM passes a vote of no confidence in the Chairman, or Board. Their appointments are to be terminated within one month of the AGM. Such a vote would only be carried if 75 per cent of the votes of persons registered in each of the livestock producer and processor-exporter categories are cast at the AGM in support of the motion, either in person or by proxy. Other arrangements to ensure the Corporation carries out its responsibilities in a business-like manner and provide the bases for its relationship with the Minister are included in clause 22 of this Bill. Under clause 22 the Corporation is required to prepare a five-year corporate plan to apply from a date no later than 1 July 1985. The corporate plan is to set out the objectives, key programs and priorities of the Corporation to provide the framework for the Corporation's administration of its functions and powers for the five-year period.

Complementary to the five-year plan is the requirement under clause 22 for an annual operational plan to set out the Corporation's objectives and programs for the relevant 12-month period ahead. Honourable members will note that under the Bill there are requirements for both the five-year corporate plan and the annual operational plan to be submitted for approval by the Minister for Primary Industry. These obligations provide an accountability arrangement which focuses the Minister's and the Corporation's attention on the strategies of the AMLC and the basic directions and policy approaches it will be following. Approval of both the corporate and the annual operational plan provides the Minster with overall supervision of the Corporation's activity, but enables the Corporation to get on with its functions without constant reference to the Minister for detailed approval of each major activity.

The development of the annual operational plan and the five-year corporate plan are of particular importance as they will provide an opportunity for better definition of the Corporation's functions and strategies within the broader functions allowed under the Bill. Hopefully this will remove some of the confusion of the past. I would anticipate that the highlights of the Corporation 's corporate plans would be made widely known within industry. However, the Corporation may wish to keep some elements confidential for trading purposes. I commend the Bill to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr McVeigh) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY POLICY COUNCIL BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Bill which is complementary to the Australian Meat and Live- stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1984 is to provide for the establishment of an Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council. Honourable members will recall that I earlier outlined the broad role of the Australian Meat and Live- stock Industry Policy Council in my second reading speech on the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Amendment Bill 1984.

The objects of establishing the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council are: To facilitate the participation of the industry in the development and formulation of industry policies; to provide a forum for consensus-building between its different sectoral interests; to provide opportunities through its working groups for all interested parties to work together on factual examination of industry problems; and to present practical proposals to government for its solution.

A main task of this Council will be to provide a forum for resolving industry differences and, with the assistance of an independent chairman and a small professional secretariat, to develop industry consensus on the action necessary to deal with its problems. Its establishment with statutory status is necessary to provide a binding charter and to help me ensure its accountability.

I now turn to specific clauses and provisions in the Australian Meat and Live- stock Industry Policy Council Bill 1984. Of the 14 members of the Council four will be selected from the leaders of the cattle and sheep industry commodity councils and four from the meat processors, exporters and meatworks representative organisations.
