It is an institution that has been part of the Australian scene since 1911. I take this opportunity to say that in the five years that I was Treasurer I naturally had a lot to do with the Commonwealth Bank and with the management of it. In that time I formed an exceptionally high opinion of the quality of the people who work in the Commonwealth Bank. They were in every sense the equals of their private sector competitors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this mean you are not going to sell it off?

—I will come to that little piece of Hawke mischief in a minute. But those people who work there were and are of very high quality. I counted it a privilege in the time that I was Treasurer to be associated with people such as Sir Ronald Elliott, who was the managing director of the Commonwealth Bank for a large part of the time that I was Treasurer, and more recently Mr Vern Christie, and, of course, a very eminent Australian in the person of Professor Crisp who was, of course, appointed as Chairman of the Commonwealth Bank Board by the Whitlam Government and was readily and with great enthusiasm reappointed by the Fraser Government. I regard and still regard Fin Crisp as a person who has made an enormous contribution not only to the business of banking in Australia through his chairmanship of the Commonwealth Bank but also to many other spheres . He is a person who draws very considerable respect in the Australian community from many different sides of politics.

SPEECH.PARA: Thus I come to this debate as a staunch advocate of the Commonwealth Bank and as somebody who believes that it has played a very important role in the development of the Australian banking system. I am therefore very happy to say on behalf of the Opposition that we support this Bill. We can have a little bit of bipartisanship on this particular subject as to most of the comments that I will make. I think the decisions of the Government to inject some more capital into the bank, to remove the present exemption from company income tax of the Savings Bank, and generally to put the bank rather more at arm's length-although it has been pretty much at arm's length from governments for many years-are very sensible moves. As I said at the beginning, they are ones that we are very ready to support.

The Commonwealth Bank has played an enormous part over the years in providing housing finance for millions of Australians. The Commonwealth Bank is the major single housing lender. It is still basically the cheapest source of finance for a large number of Australians. Under governments of both political persuasions the Commonwealth Bank has played a very significant role in underpinning the mass provision of housing finance for hundreds of thousands of Australian families. I take this opportunity, because we are talking about a great Australian bank and about banks, to say one or two things about banking policy and about the question of foreign banks.

I start my section of these remarks by saying that I very warmly welcome the conversion that has come over the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and many other members of the Australian Labor Party on the question of foreign banks. I can say without reservation and quite seriously and deliberately that the Government will have nothing but support and praise from the Opposition if it proceeds down the path of freeing up the Australian banking system. The fact that I am now in opposition has in no way altered the view that I had in government about the need to open up the Australian financial system. I am very pleased that the Labor Party appears to have changed its attitude on this.

On the occasions when the Australian Labor Party in government has taken decisions which are consistent with a more flexible and deregulatory approach to the financial system, I have taken the opportunity of giving unstinting support. Honourable members may recall that I gave very prompt support to the decision of the Government to float the Australian dollar because I believed that the decision was the right one. I think that it was a courageous decision in the circumstances and the Government deserved the support of a responsible Opposition on that occasion. I give an assurance to the House that that attitude will continue in this area. If the Government continues on the path of sensible deregulation of the financial system there will not be any political point scoring or nit picking from me on that subject. The goal, the prize, of a more open and competitive Australian financial system playing an increasing role in making Australia a major financial centre is far too important to have a brake put on it by political point scoring in this place. It certainly will not come from me.

I really am pleased that the Labor Party, now that it is in government, appears to have changed its spots on this subject. I welcome that very warmly because it is only a year ago that my colleague the Treasurer, when he was the Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters, had a slightly different view. He might not like to be reminded of this now as he waxes eloquent before financial gathering. Some of the things he said might make him blush now. About a year ago, in relations to a decision to admit about 10 foreign banks, which I announced on behalf of the former Government, he committed the Labor Party to vote against it. He accused me of representing the interests of foreigners to the detriment of the little Australian and seeking to disadvantage large sections of the Australian community. It was not the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous); it was not the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand); it was the honourable member for Blaxland, who was then the Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters. He is now the Treasurer.

I am delighted that the responsibilities of the office have changed his view. What has happened is that his view has moved over towards the view that I expressed when in government, a view which I continue to express in opposition. Let me say that in the biblical refrain there is more rejoicing about the repentance of one sinner than about the 100 or more righteous. I am delighted that the present Treasurer has embraced the philosophy of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I know that it is a bit uncomfortable for some honourable members who sit behind him-they really worry and squirm a bit every time there is some bipartisanship between the Treasurer and the shadow Treasurer in this place on the subject of financial deregulation-but it is to the good of the country that we have agreement on some of these matters. Frankly, it would have been better if a little bit more bipartisanship had been shown by the Labor Party when we were on the other side. I am in a very charitable mood tonight-I think that this is an occasion for charity-and I do not want to say anything unkind because I am being quite complimentary towards the Government. I do want to support this measure because we all support it.

The comment by the Treasurer about my not liking the little Australians was not the end of it. He made another interesting comment. I think that this is a comment that would find a ready reception in the hearts of some who still sit behind him. He said that increased pressure for deregulation-that was a terrible thought then; he really hated deregulation in January last year-would place further upward pressure on interest rates which would become unstable along with money supply and exchange rates. Once again he has thrown all that aside because what he did was float the dollar and get rid of exchange controls. There has not been too much instability. I welcome his conversion. I think it is absolutely marvellous. All I can say is that the views that the Treasurer is now expressing on most of these matters are views that I certainly support and welcome. I am very pleased that he has seen the light and he has changed his mind.

When the report of the Campbell Committee was tabled in this Parliament in November 1981 I have to say that, on occasions, I felt that I was the only person who supported it. I am very pleased that the Treasurer and a number of others in the Australian Labor Party have now come around. There will be further progress. The Treasurer will not have any trouble, obstinacy or obstructions from us; he can be sure of that. I can also promise him this: The more he looks as though he is getting a bit of stick from his own ranks the more support he will get from me. I will certainly go on doing that and I will give him as much support as I possibly can. I really am absolutely delighted that it has happened .
When the Government makes what I hope is an inevitable decision to license a significant number of foreign banks, I hope that there not only will be a reasonable number-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you do it?

—We announced it in January last year. There was a bit of an interruption in March which made it difficult for us to implement the decision. The honourable member for Petrie cannot really score a point on that. We did make the announcement to admit 10 banks. It is 14 months since the Government came to office. Letting in foreign banks is not a matter of partisan political dispute. The Government has our support on that issue now. Presumably it will be tidied up at the Labor Party national conference in July. When the decision is finally taken-
—That remains to be seen.

—The honourable member for La Trobe says: 'That remains to be seen'. This is very interesting. I think I will have to give an honourable member opposite on the front bench my proxy. Would an honourable member opposite take my proxy at the national conference to give the present Treasurer a little bit of support on this subject? I certainly hope so. When the Government finally makes its decision and when the Prime Minister and the Treasurer finally get the numbers-I know they will from the nodding of honourable members opposite who really have the right idea in the Labor Party on this-I hope they do two things: Firstly I hope that they allow in a sufficient number of new participants. I think the Australian banking system can do with a number of new participants. Secondly, I hope that the Government is not too restrictive on the level of foreign ownership. Because the report of the Martin Committee on the Review of the Australian Financial System stated that a maximum of 50 per cent would be appropriate, I know that that has probably created a number of political barriers and political obstacles given the historic hostility of the Labor Party in Australia to foreign banks. I understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense it would have been preferable if the Martin report had been a little more generous on that subject because I suppose it is a bit difficult for a Labor Treasurer to go any further than Martin. Judging by the interjection of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) I do not think he is very keen on the Treasurer going anywhere near Martin. Be that as it may, unless the Government is prepared to allow, in many cases, majority foreign participation in new banks, the real benefits of overseas participation will not be obtained.

I make this plea to the Government: Let us have a reasonable number of foreign banks. Let us not be too restrictive about the level of foreign ownership. When the Government decides to do it the balance of the response from members of the Opposition will certainly be supportive. If the Government decides, as it should , particularly in the present climate, to deregulate interest rates totally, it will also have the support of the Opposition on that issue. I would have thought that students of the financial system, particularly the work that has been done by the Campbell report, would have learned over the last few year that, far from interest rate controls helping the underprivileged, interest rate controls have disadvantaged them.

I do not think that is better demonstrated than by an examination of the profile of housing loans taken out by people in, say, the western suburbs of Sydney in the latter years of the 1970s. People who were not good credit risks, that is, the people who did not have much money, who were real battlers, could not get money from banks and building societies because this scarcity of funds rationed them out. They were driven into the arms of high interest rate lenders. That is a fact of life. So far from interest rate controls helping poor people, they have created a situation in which low interest rates paid to the less sophisticated investor have subsidised low interest loans to middle and high income earners.

Frankly, that is hardly an equitable situation. It is a proposition that I know many people on both sides of politics find very hard to accept. The automatic reaction is that if we have interest rate controls we are really looking after people and holding everything down. The reality is that the financial system is now so diverse, flexible and volatile that if we sit on one part of it it bursts out somewhere else. The cash management trusts which burgeoned in the 1970s demonstrated that very clearly. Cash management trusts were the ordinary guy's way of becoming part of the short term money market. Why should not the ordinary person become part of the short term money market? That also is a difficult political issue, which was the subject of intense political opportunism by the former Opposition. But once again, if the Government wants to move on that subject it will not have any nonsense from me. I would be very happy to give it support and to offer my proxy at that national conference if the Treasurer and the Prime Minister are trying to drum up a few more numbers on that subject. They will certainly have our help on that.

There is just one other thing I would like to say. Having spent almost 20 minutes expressing bipartisan support for the policies of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, I am very sorry to say that I will now have to say something critical of the Government on this subject. I will disappoint some of my friends in the Labor Party and say something about a few of the things the Prime Minister has been saying lately, particularly at Question Time, about our economic policy. I am delighted that the Prime Minister has been paying very close attention to our economic policy. I am very pleased that the has felt it necessary to talk about our economic policy at such length in Question Time. The only thing that disappoints me is that he has so totally misrepresented sections of the economic policy dealing with the disposal of assets.

Everybody knows that the Prime Minister has tried to create unnecessary fear, alarm, concern and panic throughout Australia regarding some of those proposals. It is nowhere better illustrated than by the Commonwealth Bank. Do honourable members know what the Prime Minister said on 4 May in answer to a question from the Deputy Government Whip, the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham)? He said that the Opposition was talking about the dismantling of the basic economic infrastructure of this country. Nothing could be further from the truth . Nothing could be a more dishonest misrepresentation of what the Opposition is about in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you say on 12 April?
—I am glad that the honourable member has the right parts marked. Let me read the section that is relevant to the Commonwealth Bank. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition will undertake an examination of the role, structure and level of Government ownership and control of all other enterprises . . .
I named the Commonwealth Bank. I went on to say, as undoubtedly honourable members have read:
This examination will include an assessment of the desirability and feasibility of the disposal of the whole or part of the Government's interest in such enterprises.

What is so revolutionary and dramatic about that? Does that in any way imply, as the Prime Minister has said it does, that we will flog things off in a careless and indifferent fashion? I will give the Prime Minister credit, as I have for the last 20 minutes, for showing courage and taking the right decisions in this area, but when he embarks upon this kind of misleading nonsense he brings no credit to himself or to his Government. He talked about the $1.4 billion available for housing, and about the 42,000 housing loans. He talked about all these things as though in some way they were under threat, as though in some way the Liberal and National Parties, when they are re-elected to the Government of this country, will take them away. It is totally dishonest of the Prime Minister to do that. It is quite wrong and misleading of him.

If that is a sample of the kind of election campaign tactics we will have from this Prime Minister the level of debate will degenerate pretty badly by the time we get to election day. In no way will a Liberal and National Party government put at risk the deposits of people who have their money in the Commonwealth Bank . In no way will we dismantle a great Australian institution. In no way are the charges of the Prime Minister on this subject accurate. In fact, it is very interesting that one of the objectives of the Bill we are now debating is described in the explanatory memorandum in language which is very similar to the language in our policy. Perhaps the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Robert Brown), the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and all the others who are interested in this subject have not noticed that. This is what their explanatory memorandum-it is not the Liberals' policy-said:
These changes were decided upon following a major review of the financial structure and organisation of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation.

That is the Hawke amendment. Our policy said that we would undertake an examination of the role, structure and level of government ownership and control . There is a lot of similarity between those words, but do I come in to this place and say that the Government is about dismantling the Commonwealth Bank and flogging it off? Of course I do not. I come into this place and give the Government a measure of responsible support. Government members ought to take apart those sections of the economic policy on which their argument is soundly based. They ought not to run around Australia making misleading statements about depositers' funds. That is a very irresponsible thing for a Prime Minister to do . He ought, on that subject, to be thoroughly ashamed of himself because he has embarked upon a process of total misinformation.

There have been many occasions in the past on which people have talked about change in part of the ownership of the Commonwealth Bank. Would honourable members opposite seriously suggest that if a future government of either our persuasion or theirs decided to sell 20 per cent of the equity in the Commonwealth Bank to Australian shareholders that would be flogging off the Commonwealth Bank?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—They would regard selling something to Australians as flogging off an asset of the Australian people? That is an incredible proposition. In other words, if a government dares to sell anything to ordinary little Australians, those people whom the present Treasurer was so ready to defend about 13 months ago--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to honourable members that it would be a shame to spoil the bipartisanship.

—Do not interrupt them, Madam Deputy Speaker, I am enjoying it. All honourable members opposite have to do is agree and we will have total bipartisanship. I have spent 80 per cent of my speech agreeing with them. If they agree with me for the last 20 per cent the whole thing will be complete. If we were to sell 20 per cent of that bank, not to dreaded multinational companies , not even to large Australian companies, but to ordinary Australian shareholders, that would represent, in the view of the Prime Minister, flogging it off. That is not necessarily our policy. I and my colleagues have made it perfectly clear that we will be making detailed policy statements in this area as time proceeds. We will put at rest the nonsense, the deceit and the misleading statements that have been made by the Prime Minister on this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: As an example I quote the sort of thing that might occur with some of these undertakings. Are Government members seriously suggesting that if 20 per cent of Aussat Pty Ltd were to be sold to the Australian public, that would be flogging if off? If they are, they are disagreeing with their Treasurer, because he argued before the Cabinet about six months ago that more than 20 per cent of Aussat should be sold off to the Australian public. So do not come to me and say that selling 20 per cent to the Australian public represents flogging off the asset. I know darn well that he wanted 49 per cent to be sold to the Australian public. I bet he would not thank honourable members on the other side for saying that that represented flogging off assets. That is just an example of how mischievous and misleading the Government is. What a great pity it is that on an issue where it would be possible to get a real level of bipartisanship, the person who stopped that happening was the Prime Minister. I know there are differences of opinion within the Labor Party, but both major parties have been moving much closer towards common ground because the Government has been putting aside some of the attitudes that it had when it was in opposition. But unfortunately it is all spoilt because the Prime Minister has got to have his cheap political trick. He has got to be able to stir up a bit of fear and concern amongst people. He has got to talk about deposits being at risk and he has to refer to the large number of housing loans by the Commonwealth Bank as if in some way they would be at risk under this policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like your former Prime Minister.

—I have never heard anything that is more ridiculous. The Minister for Territories and Local Government can interrupt as much as he likes. I know darn well that his views on the financial system have well and truly been rolled. I know that he thought about deregulation when he was the housing spokesman for the Opposition. My God, deregulation was a terrible state and a terrible proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one other thing I would like to say on this measure, and that is on the general question of deregulation. I know that on occasions there are some who say that deregulation is just some trendy fad and that people should not get too carried away with the benefits of it. I do not know whether honourable members opposite are fully aware of what has happened to employment in Australia over the last year. There has been a rise in the number of people employed; I am not denying that. There has not been much of a reduction in the total number of unemployed, but we will debate that on another occasion. But it is very interesting that the first of two areas where there has been a very significant rise in the number of people unemployed is in the government sector. I will restrain myself by not saying anything about that.

The other area where there has been a rise has been the financial services sector. Over the last year there has been a rise of about 25,000 in the number of people employed in the financial services sector. That is a direct result of the new competition, the variety and the deregulation that have occurred under both governments in that area, and it gives the lie to those in the community who say that there are no visible benefits in it. At a time when manufacturing employment is lower than what it was a year ago, at a time when mining employment is still down, when retail employment is staggered and when in other portions of the private sector employment growth has been stagnant or negative, we find that in the financial services sector there is a rise of 25,000 people employed in a year. That is practical proof of the practical human benefits of deregulation. It is a fact that those on both sides of the House who support the cause of deregulation ought to say more about it, and it is something that gives the lie to a lot of the nonsense that has been spoken against deregulation by many people in the left wing of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this legislation with a great deal of pleasure as I had the privilege of serving in the Commonwealth Banking Corporation for 12 years during the early part of my career. During those 12 years I got to know the workings of the Commonwealth Bank very well and to know the dedication of the staff. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) made some comments that we should not raise bogy men about what the Liberals may do if they ever unfortunately come back to power. Perhaps we should look back into history to see what they did when they returned to power after they had been out for some time and what the Menzies Government did to a number of government instrumentalities, such as the Commonwealth Oil Refineries, which it sold to BP Australia Ltd; and the AWA group, and Commonwealth Engineering Pty Ltd which Menzies sold off.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember in my history lessons with the Commonwealth Bank that early in its time the Commonwealth Bank used to finance motor vehicles. The Menzies Government thought that this was not very fair because those great supporters of the Liberal Party, the finance companies, were finding it very hard to compete with the Commonwealth Bank. So it decided that the Commonwealth Bank could only finance station wagons. Due to the good judgment of the Australian people, station wagons became the biggest selling vehicles in Australia because they were financed by the Commonwealth Bank.

The amendments in the legislation bring forward a number of vital changes because over a period the Commonwealth Bank has been criticised by many sectors that it has not been competitive. The Commonwealth Bank has been accused of inefficiency compared with its private bank competitors. Members of the Government, including me, reject that proposition. Since its creation in 1911 by the Commonwealth Banks Act, the Bank has not only had to compete with private banks, but also has had to withstand attacks from conservative State and Federal governments. The Commonwealth Bank has always played a vital role in the development of Australia. It has been consistently the largest lender of housing loans as well as being a major provider of funds for local government. This, in particular, is very important to most members of this House. Without the assistance of the Commonwealth Bank, many local authorities would have found it very difficult to fulfil their works programs and it is a role that the Commonwealth Bank has done for the betterment of this country.

For too long whenever the Commonwealth Bank has performed well its opponents have used the criticism that it has an unfair advantage over its opposition. Amendments contained in this Bill address some of the previous criticisms and bring the Commonwealth Bank corporate structure more in line with business practices in Australia. The first of the amendments changes the name of the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia to that of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Secondly, the Commonwealth Savings Bank is now a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank, rather than a separate bank. These changes are rational, bring about a very sound corporate structure and enable the Bank to be proficient in the way it operates its business.

Other changes include the provision of $20m of the reserves of the Commonwealth Savings Bank at 30 June 1984 to become the share capital of the Savings Bank. This capital is to be vested with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The Government has also provided for an additional injection of $15m to the capital of the Bank and a further transfer of $75m from the reserves of the Commonwealth Development Bank to the Commonwealth Bank as additional capital. These are very necessary changes and will give the Commonwealth Bank a large degree of liquidity and enable it to expand its operations in the future. Also in future the proportion of net profits that are to be paid by the Commonwealth Bank to the Commonwealth will be determined by the Treasurer, but shall not exceed 45 per cent compared with the current 50 per cent mandatory transfer of funds to the Commonwealth. The amendments also allow a more flexible management and board structure of the Commonwealth Bank so that past rigidity of Bank managements will no longer inhibit the operation of the Bank's senior executives.

Finally, the amendment to remove the present exemption from company tax of the Commonwealth Savings Bank, Development Bank and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation as a whole, is a very vital change. Previously, only the Commonwealth Trading Bank has been subject to company tax. It is pleasing in this legislation to see that the whole corporate structure of the Commonwealth Bank will be subject to taxation. In my years of service with the Bank, the most common criticism levelled at the Commonwealth Bank by its opponents was that because it was not subject to company tax it had an unfair advantage over its private enterprise competitors. Some people even went as far as to say that if the Commonwealth Bank had been subject to taxation it would not have been able to exist in the corporate market.

The proposition that was put by those people is one that I have always totally rejected. I have always found the Commonwealth Bank to be a very efficient organisation. I can remember back to the early computerisation done by the Commonwealth Bank. Computerisation of the Commonwealth Bank was probably the most successful of all banks, because the Commonwealth Bank had the sense to tell the computer companies about the system under which it operated and that the computers needed to work in that system, whereas many of the private banks bought a computer system and then tried to amend their procedures to fit in with the computer. The Commonwealth Bank computer system and its on-line telling machines, which were the first in Australia, were very much at the forefront of technological change in the Australian banking industry. I think they were of great credit to the Corporation. Many of the services that the Bank has introduced were leaders in the banking field. We have looked at a whole range of issues and services that the Bank now provides. It provides a very efficient world-wide network for its corporate clients. The Commonwealth Bank is in the position of being able to compete with a vast range of services.

The honourable member for Bennelong mentioned the vast number of school children who learnt how to save through the Commonwealth Bank. I think that is one of the most vital areas in which the Commonwealth Bank used to participate. I can remember very memorable days when I used to do school savings bank transactions. One of our most enjoyable tasks was of great credit to the Commonwealth Bank. It used to have a policy of sending Commonwealth Bank officers to the schools for the handicapped near the branch in which I worked to teach the intellectually handicapped and the disabled the systems of banking. This was a community service that the Commonwealth Bank provided. It was of great benefit to society. In the early days, the private banks were not very interested in savings banks. They learnt, to their detriment later, that many people who learnt to save with the Commonwealth Bank tended to stay with the Commonwealth Bank and bank with it throughout their banking careers. There is now a great cry from many of the private banks that they should get into the system. I understand they have been successful in some schools.

The Commonwealth Bank has grown enormously over the last 10 years. In 1974 the Commonwealth Trading Bank had assets of $3,447m. Today it has assets of $13,527m . The Commonwealth Banking Corporation as a whole has assets of some $26,201m. So I understand when the honourable member for Benelong says that he would find it difficult to justify selling off the Commonwealth Bank. I think it would be very difficult to find somebody within Australia with enough capital to buy it. The Commonwealth Bank has shown that an Australian government enterprise can compete with private enterprises in a heavily mixed economy. In fact, I maintain that without the Commonwealth Bank, Australia's banking system would be a much less competitive sector of the Australian economy.

In Australia, we have often discussed the banking system in isolation, compared with the financial systems. One of the great recent innovations at the Commonwealth Bank has been the operation of the Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation. Having worked in the finance industry, I think that the operations and methods of the Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation keep many of its competitors extremely honest. Without the influence of the Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation in that sector, I think that many of the interest rates that business has to pay and ordinary consumers have to pay would have been much higher. The Commonwealth Bank Finance Corporation has always operated on a much smaller lending margin than have other private finance companies, even though it raised its capital in similar ways.

Other areas in which the Commonwealth Bank has expanded in the last few years include the provision of the Commonwealth Bank Travel Service. This has been extremely successful, with 24 full time officers in Australia, and it operates throughout the thousand-odd Commonwealth Bank branches. At a time last year when travel was restricted and not as profitable, the Commonwealth Bank Travel Service grew by some 21 per cent. This showed that it was fulfilling a further need in the community. The amendments proposed in this Bill are very sensible. I urge the Government to continue to consult with the Commonwealth Bank so that its legislation can be upgraded in many other areas. I urge the Government to look at developing more strategies for the Commonwealth Bank to invest in industry, particularly through the Commonwealth Development Bank. Changes have already been made in that area. With the limited amount of time available, I thank the House for the opportunity to speak to this Bill and I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1984 I would like to examine the legislation from the small business point of view, to look at the operations of the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Development Bank from the point of view of small business. One of the greatest problems facing small and medium sized businesses and enterprises in Australia is and has been the lack of appropriate finance, either loan or capital. The Commonwealth Development bank has played its part in making funds available to small business. What are we talking about when we talk about the size of the small business sector? There are some 750,000 enterprises in Australia. Ninety- nine per cent of them employ fewer than 100 people. Ninety-three per cent of them employ fewer than 10 people. So when we talk about small business we are, in fact, talking about the vast majority, the bulk, of firms, businesses and enterprises in Australia. So small business is important.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Bank, particularly the Commonwealth Development Bank, which, under this legislation, will become a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank, has been an important lender to small business. I think it is worth reminding the Government that the former Government's commitment to the Commonwealth Development Bank should be remembered. The previous Government had a great record. I pay tribute to Sir Phillip Lynch who, as Treasurer, changed the charter of the Commonwealth Development Bank to enable it to lend to small business and greater funds were committed to the Commonwealth Development Bank under the former Government.

Let us look at the arrangements that might occur under this legislation when the Commonwealth Development Bank becomes a subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank rather than a separate organisation. I would like the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in concluding this debate, to give some answers on that. The Government has not revealed what the new arrangements will be. As I have said, the Commonwealth Development Bank is now, and will be until this legislation is passed, a separate bank. Now that it is to merge or become a subsidiary, one has to ask whether the Board and the Managing Director will, in fact, have a conflict of interest, because at present all the private banks act as agents for the existing Commonwealth Development Bank. Will the private banks-this is a very serious question- have the same confidence in the Commonwealth Development Bank now as they have had in the past because they are now dealing directly with a competitor?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are always against the people's interest and protecting the private interest.

—The Minister may interject, but it is a serious question because the amendments may, in fact, defeat the purpose of the Act. I know that left wing socialists such as he is might not understand that, but that is the truth of the matter. I am asking a legitimate question. We might, in fact, be throwing out the baby with the bathwater.
—Why should you be always protecting the very wealthy?

—I am asking honourable members opposite, including the Minister who is interjecting, to state what are the management procedures. I think that the Commonwealth Development Bank, its customers and potential customers, members of this House, the people of Australia and every small business ought to know whether, in fact, they can go to their own bank manager, whether it is a private bank or a government bank, and still deal as a lender of last resort with the Commonwealth Development Bank, which will now be a subsidiary, or whether there will be a conflict of interest and in fact they will not be able to do so. It is a most serious question.

SPEECH.PARA: All this proves to me more and more that the entry of foreign banks into Australia is needed. Undoubtedly, we need to assist small business by allowing the entry of foreign banks into Australia. However, I will come to that in a second. The Government and the Commonwealth Bank must establish a set of procedures and guidelines so that the private banks can have confidence in the new arrangements and so that the Managing Director and Board of the Commonwealth Bank do not have a conflict of interest. The Commonwealth Development Bank is losing its independence, the independence that it has had to deal with small business. That is at real risk under this legislation.

Let us consider the question of the entry of foreign banks into Australia. Before I do that, I pay tribute to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer and present shadow Treasurer. He has been criticised by the Government tonight, but none of the deregulation that has occurred in the Australian banking and financial system under the Hawke Government, for which the shadow Treasurer tonight gave the Government support, saying that it had bipartisan support in this Parliament, would have come about in Australia but for the honourable member for Bennelong. If he as Treasurer had not caused the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System to operate, we would not have had the Campbell report and we would not have had the climate, the discussion and the debate on deregulation which were started by the former Treasurer, the current shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong. Indeed, if the honourable member for Bennelong had not, in January 1983, made the decision that he referred to during the debate this evening-the decision in principle by the former Government to allow for the initial entry into the Australian banking system of around 10 banks-we would not be having this debate in Australia today. The Government would not have had the report of the Martin Committee on the Review of the Australian Financial System. The whole foreign bank debate would not be occurring. We would still be in the dark ages.

I think that the shadow Treasurer has been magnanimous in supporting the Government. But what about a little support and congratulations for the honourable member for Bennelong? What about some recognition for the role he has played in the debate on deregulation? The benefits that are occuring in the Australian financial system to customers and borrowers-and, after all, people are what it is all about-who deal with banks would not have taken place but for the honourable member for Bennelong. I would like the next speaker on the Government side and the Treasurer when he is summing up in the debate, in the spirit of bipartisanship that the honourable member for Bennelong has expressed, to reciprocate in some way because without these achievements we would have had nothing.

I return to the subject of foreign banks. I believe that small and medium sized businesses will gain the biggest advantage by the entry of foreign banks. It is time that the Government stepped in and made a decision, and I will say more about that in a moment. More banks mean more competition and that means a better deal for small businesses and customers because if small businesses can borrow and get funds in a competitive financial system they can invest and that will create jobs. Undoubtedly, the flexibility and range of overseas lending techniques and know-how that foreign banks have should make more money available to the small business sector and provide more competition in the Australian banking system that can only benefit Australian consumers. The operation of foreign banks should widen the availability of methods of financing which are not readily accessible to the small business sector at this time. Forms of lending would, I believe, be based on more flexible terms as found overseas. Without doubt, the experience of overseas and international banks which provide a range of services for small business will be of assistance and will widen the availability of finance for Australia's small business.

The honourable member for Bennelong, the Opposition spokesman on this subject and shadow Treasurer, talked of the bipartisan approach of the Opposition. I referred to the contribution he made when leading for the Opposition in this debate. But what worries me is that the Government in fact will not be able to act. As I said, but for the former Government and the persistence of the honourable member for Bennelong we would not be here debating this matter tonight. I believe that the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer have nearly gone about as far as the left wing-the socialist Left, some of whom are in the chamber tonight-will let them go. The Government is unable to make a decision on this matter. It is paralysed at present because it is awaiting the July conference of the Australian Labor Party before it can make a decision.

Tonight the honourable member for Casey (Mr Steedman) indicated by way of interjection to the honourable member for Bennelong that in fact he was not too keen in letting any foreign banks in at all. What worries me is that the debate has been deferred. The Prime Minister and Treasurer will have the rug pulled from under them at the July conference and we will not be allowed to have any foreign banks at all. That would be a great tragedy. I think it is a touch and go situation at present as to whether the Government will be able to legislate and allow foreign banks to compete in Australia because the socialist Left is marshalling its forces for that July conference.

In the time remaining, I should like to examine the size of the government banking sector and the private banking sector in Australia. Approximately 56.4 per cent of savings banks in Australia are government banks-that is, a combination of the various State banks and the Commonwealth Bank. The Commonwealth Bank represents 32.9 per cent in terms of assets, and the various State banks represent 23.5 per cent. So 56 per cent of savings banks are owned by the government sector. In the trading bank sector, about 30 per cent of the banks are government banks. Considering together the 30 per cent of banks in the trading bank sector that are government banks and the 56 per cent of banks in the savings bank sector that are government banks, one can appreciate that there is only a limited private sector trading bank operation. The mergers of trading banks that have recently taken place have led to a concentration in the hands of the majors-the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, National Australian Bank and the Westpac Banking Corporation. Those mergers took place in rationalisation preparatory to the anticipated entry of foreign banks under the previous Government. That makes it all the more important to have competition in our banking system from the entry of foreign banks, and this to restore the balance. There is a serious threat of too much government banking and not enough private sector trading banking. After all, competition is what it is all about. To me, this points to all the more need for foreign banks.

I believe that we need foreign banks. I conclude my remarks on this legislation by referring to the Opposition's economic policy, to which the honourable member for Bennelong referred. Under the coalition's economic policy, the Commonwealth Bank will be a great bank, a more efficient bank, and a more effective bank.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Beddall) on his speech, particularly as he is the first Commonwealth Bank employee from Queensland who has been elected to this House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill 1984 has been formulated with a view to improving the financial and administrative structure of the constituent banks of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation so that they are better able to compete with other major banking and non-banking institutions. It is interesting to note what was said by the Prime Minister and Treasurer, Mr Andrew Fisher, on 15 November 1911, when the Commonwealth Bank Bill had its second reading. He said:
This will be a bank belonging to the people and directly managed by the people' s own agents.

Of course, in those days, as now, some honourable members were concerned about States rights, and a good deal of the debate was taken up with the unfair competition for the State savings banks which would result from the creation of the new Commonwealth Bank. A major reconstitution of the Commonwealth Bank took place in 1959. When the Treasurer, Mr Harold Holt, introduced the second reading of the Commonwealth Bank Bill 1959, members of my Party at that time were most concerned that the Bill enabled the structure of the existing Commonwealth Bank to be dismembered and, in consequence, reduced its effectiveness as a competitor of the private banks. The present Bill before the House will remove a number of the restrictions in the 1959 Act which were so vigorously objected to by the Labor Party in opposition.

The present Bill will re-establish the original name of the Commonwealth Bank and will make the Commonwealth Savings Bank a wholly owned subsidiary of the trading bank. As the then Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) indicated, this will mean that there will be far more scope for improvement in the range of services offered by both banks. With the decision by the Board of the Corporation to revalue their premises in accordance with current market valuations and the addition of $15m from the Government plus a $75m transfer from the Commonwealth Development Bank, the capital structure of the Commonwealth Bank will provide a strong financial base for an expansion of its activities.

I am not quite sure who said it but the comment that bankers and financiers are generally in favour of tight money, loose regulation and a warm place to count the profits is most apt in relation to the current debate about necessary changes to the banking system in Australia. I am pleased that the people's bank, as the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) called it, the Commonwealth Bank , is to become more competitive in relation to the private banks. However, I am a little worried as to whether the Bank regards itself as the people's bank or whether it will be able, even with its enlarged capital base, to resist an onslaught from the international banking and financial institutions.

One of the difficulties of any discussion involving Australian banks is to ascertain exactly how their financial structures are linked with foreign banks. Australian banks are not large by world standards. Even the Westpac Banking Corporation is only No. 72 in world ranking size. The largest banking group in the world is Citicorp, with assets of about $US110 billion. This bank is so large that, by itself, it is larger than all of the major Australian banks put together, including the Commonwealth Bank.

It is worthy of note that this foreign bank was accused of evasion of regulations and falsification of documents after an in-house study by a United States House of Representatives sub-committee report. According to the study, the report and the Citicorp documents submitted to the sub-committee indicated that the bank resorted to numerous devices to evade the banking laws of foreign countries in which it operated. If this bank is ever allowed to commence full- scale operations in Australia the Commonwealth Bank would need government intervention to prevent it from being subjected to the questionable trading practices of Citicorp. The documents detailed questionable banking dealings in Germany, Britain, France and 13 other countries, including seven countries in Europe and seven in Asia. Naturally enough, tax evasion headed the list of questionable practices as this is probably one of the most profitable areas for foreign bank dealing in countries lacking the huge financial resources of Citicorp. Citicorp has not escaped retribution for its shady activities as it has agreed to pay over $11m in back taxes on its illegal foreign exchange transactions in at least one country.

The dealings of Citicorp pose a threat to the whole international financial system according to the report. A senior Commonwealth Bank official commented to me several days ago when I indicated my fears about the licensing of some foreign banks for trading bank operations in Australia that the Commonwealth Bank had no fears about overseas competition. I am afraid I do not share his confidence. Banks rely on each other for 70 per cent of their loans and, in consequence, the problems of one bank can be transmitted to another through the inter-bank market. The United States report started:

Citibank is no ordinary bank; when it gambles the entire financial system is in on the bet. Since Citibank is one of the largest banks world-wide and the largest player in the Eurodollar market, it has the potential for creating a very systemic disturbance.

The Euro currency market is relatively unregulated and the trans-financial institutions, such as Citicorp, have a history of continually trying to avoid government regulation. There are lessons for Australia in the mounting statistical evidence of the increasing inter-penetration of foreign ownership and control of our financial system. There is no doubt that the restructuring of the Commonwealth Bank will result in a more flexible and a more efficient organisation, together with an additional strengthening of its financial resources. Hopefully, the efficiency resulting from the restructuring will mean an expansion of activities requiring additional staff to balance the loss of staff which will inevitably result from the technological changes in the financial business of the bank.

I trust that the Bank will ensure that the employees do not suffer any financial hardship if staff members are reduced. I am concerned that even a strengthening of the financial structure of the Commonwealth Bank will not withstand the onslaught of foreign banks such as Citibank and Deutsche Bank if those banks are granted licences for full trading and savings banks operations in Australia. It is noticeable that the foreign banks have stepped up their lobbying for banking licences over the last few years. However, it is quite clear from their overseas record that they do not want to be involved in setting up branch networks all over Australia to provide services for the needs of the small business and domestic customers of Australian banks. They are interested only in the highly profitable area of lending money to corporations and to governments and their institutions.

The result of foreign banks being allowed a wider range of financial activities would be an acceleration in the present rationalisation of banking operations in Australia with cut-backs in staff and services and a higher cost of banking for the Australian public. The international capital market is one of the main reasons for the instability of the international capitalist system because it acts virtually outside the control of the countries of the world. In this sense it is vital that the Government resists foreign bank pressure to give trading bank status so that the Commonwealth Bank can establish itself on the basis of its new financial structure without being subject to the questionable business practices of the foreign banks.

There is one other matter I would like to refer to before I conclude my remarks on the Bill. I commend the Government for repealing section 95 of the 1959 Principal Act and replacing it with a new section 95 which reduces the outdated restrictions on the appointment of university graduates in relation to age and numbers. The new section also covers graduates of colleges of advanced education and other tertiary institutions, as previously they could have been required to complete the entrance examination. However, I notice that there has been no attempt to include some form of employee participation in the decision-making structure of the Bank. It would no doubt be argued by some people that it would be quite inappropriate or even improper for employees to play any part in the decision-making structure of a bank. That is a view which I believe is becoming rapidly outdated, as the number of employee representations on governing boards of public corporations all over Australia can testify. Section 16 of the principal Act in fact appears specifically to disqualify any officer or any employee of the Bank from being appointed to membership of the governing board.

The Federal Australian Labor Party Government should ensure whenever it has the opportunity that the participation of employees of all public corporations in the decision-making structures of their work place is supported by legislative measures. The implementation of employees decision-making processes is part of a total process of industrial democracy which in its turn can lead to a greater participation by the people in the processes of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of concerns about the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill before the House this evening insofar as it relates to the Commonwealth Development Bank. One hardly need point out the importance of the Commonwealth Development Bank to rural producers in this country as well as, in later days, to small business. It is interesting to note that no Government speaker, certainly not the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), in his second reading speech, has addressed himself or herself to this very important factor; that is, how does the Commonwealth Development Bank fare under this legislation? My colleague and good friend the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) touched on some of his concerns a little earlier, and I am grateful to him for raising those matters before the Parliament this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: More particularly, it needs to be pointed out to honourable members on the Government benches that the Commonwealth Development Bank over the last 24 years has made a great many contributions to developments within rural Australia. The Commonwealth Development Bank has always been the bank of last resort to which primary producers and, in later days, small businessmen can go to obtain funding because the Commonwealth Development Bank does not require the same amount of capital from its borrowers. The fact is that so many projects that we see in Gippsland and throughout rural Australia would not have come about but for the Commonwealth Development Bank. My concern, and I wish to raise these questions with the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), is how the Commonwealth Development Bank is treated under this legislation.

I have three major concerns. First there is the matter under the legislation of a transfer of $75m from the Development Bank's reserves to the newly formed Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Just how is this to be done? Can any member of the Government or the Minister advise this House and rural Australia how this $ 75m is to be transferred from the Development Bank to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —We want the answer tonight.

—We want the answer tonight, as the honourable member for Braddon so wisely interjects. Neither the Treasurer's Press release, his second reading speech, nor the legislation details for us how this reserve is to be transferred . How that $75m is to be transfered has the most profound implications for the standing and financial status of the Development Bank. If the transfer is effected by a book entry which reduces the Development Bank's reserves and correspondingly increases the Development Bank's liability to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the CBA will charge interest on what is effectively a loan to the Development Bank. The reason is that from the point of view of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the cost of this loan is the interest which it would otherwise have received had it not lent the money to the Development Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Before coming into this House this evening I did some research on the current interest rates both on small overdrafts and uncontrolled overdrafts. Of course, the measure taken by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to determine what interest rate is to be applied will determine the amount of money that must be paid by the Development Bank. But certainly, on my calculations, the mid-point of the range of the various interests rates is 13.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is before the establishment fee.

—That is before the establishment fee. If we apply this rate to the $75m, it yields $10m in interest. So I say to the Minister that, unless he advises this House how the transfer is to be taken, we can conclude only that by way of a book entry the Development Bank will be out of pocket to the tune of $ 10m. Of course, this will have a subsequent effect on the many borrowers of the Development Bank because the Bank will have to increase its interest rates as a result.
—Small businessmen will suffer.
—Small businessmen also will suffer, as the honourable member for Braddon said.
—And primary producers.

—Of course, primary produces will also suffer. Most borrowers with the Development Bank have a floating interest rate. Therefore, if the Development Bank has to borrow money or incurs extra charges, those charges, those costs, are passed on to the borrower. I should be grateful if the Government would address itself to this vital issue this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: The second concern I have with the legislation, so far as the Development Bank is concerned, is the imposition, for the first time in the Development Bank's history, of company tax. This will be at a rate of 46c in the dollar. Last year the Development Bank accumulated, through wise management, good policies and careful management, a profit of $23m. If company tax had been applied last year- we cannot be certain that that same profit will be produced in this financial year; it may be higher or lower-the Development Bank would have paid $10.6m in taxation.

The Development Bank is, therefore, left with two alternatives. One is that it can reduce by that same amount the amount it allows out to be borrowed, as a result of which primary producers and small businessmen would not be able to borrow that amount of $10.6m. The other alternative is that the Development Bank can borrow that money in the commercial market-place at commercial interest rates thereby, of course, incurring further interest, further charges, again to be passed on to the borrower. Either one of those alternatives will result in increased cost to borrowers.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a reduction of loans available.

—Or a reduction of loans available. If this Government is fair dinkum about assisting rural Australia or small businesses it will not tax to this extent the Development Bank. The Development Bank has a special place, a special role, to fulfil in our banking system in the economy of rural Australia. Yet this Government in a contemptuous fashion, in a sly, underhanded fashion, is attempting to upset the balance that has been carefully created to assist those disadvantaged and adventurous primary producers who simply want to get on in life. They are people who will work, borrow money and produce for this country, and yet this Government is saying that they cannot do that to the same extent.

SPEECH.PARA: My third concern, which is not properly addressed by the legislation, is what effect the restructuring of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia will have on the Development Bank. Under the previous structure, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation had three wings, shall we say. It had the Trading Bank, the Savings Bank, and of course, the Development Bank. Presiding over all of these three banks was a managing director and a deputy managing director who reported to the board. This legislation more or less merges the Savings Bank and the Trading Bank by making the Savings Bank a wholly owned subsidiary of the Trading Bank. That appears to be slightly confusing but in plain English it merges the trading and savings banks. Therefore, on the one hand we would have a huge banking organisation and on the other the Development Bank, both of which come under a managing director and a deputy managing director. My point is that a conflict of interests could easily arise between what are now two wings of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. No longer are there three wings; there are two, and one is clearly larger than the other.

It is interesting to note that 70 per cent of the Development Bank's clients, its borrowers, are referred to it or are clients of private banks. Only one- third or 30 per cent are clients of the Commonwealth Trading Bank. Therefore we have a situation in which a conflict of interests, a parting of ways, could easily occur. Yet what protection is there of the independence and the strength of the Development Bank to determine its own decisions? Where is the protection of that essential right that the Development Bank remain independent, a fighter and a provider for rural Australia?

The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) has entered the chamber-that is a good thing because he represents a rural electorate-even though the debate will conclude in 30 minutes. Where do the honourable member for Bendigo and other members of rural electorates on the Government side stand on this issue? It is interesting to note, although it is quite expected, that only one member of the Government who represents a rural electorate is in the chamber. I ask where the honourable member for Bendigo stands. Does he stand to protect his constituents? Does he stand to protect rural Australia and small businesses or will he fall in line with the overpowering, overriding concerns of his left wing Government?

It is of particular interest, besides the presence of the honourable member for Bendigo, that the Minister for Territories and Local Government has charge of the Bill this evening. He is an outstanding member of the socialist Left. As I put these three matters to the Minister, I do not expect an answer of any substance, yet perhaps he will take my concerns, my questions, to the Treasurer and provide this House with specific answers to my specific questions, specific concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset of my remarks on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill I make a couple of comments in respect of the matters raised by my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) . Some years ago I was a constituent of the electorate of Gippsland but I am very glad that I am not now. Indeed, if it were encumbent upon me to choose an area of country Victoria in which to reside, I would have absolutely no hesitation in choosing Bendigo, because in Bendigo, unlike Gippsland, the representation at the Federal level is outstanding.
—Why isn't he speaking?

—The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) does not rely on rhetorical flourish. He relies on hard work for his constituents. Let me get back to some of the comments made by my colleague the agrarian socialist from the National Party of Australia. He talked about the need to improve the operations of what will be the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, as well he should . The Commonwealth Bank was formed as a result of a Labor government initiative. The honourable member for Gippsland quite rightly gave credit by implication to a former Labor government for so doing and it is important to note, having regard to his comments, that over time the bank has fallen back because of its relatively antiquated structure. For example, I inform the honourable member for Gippsland about the gearing ratio.
—He would not understand that.

—He might know about the gearing ratio in England. He is nodding his head. Perhaps he can tell us. No, the honourable member for Gippsland is unaware of the gearing ratio. I inform the House that the gearing ratio in the United Kingdom is approximately 70 to 1.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is simply that a question was put to me but I gave no answer. I do know the gearing ratio. It is a dishonest misrepresentation.
— Order! There is no point of order.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Gippsland also adverted to the policies of the socalled left wing Government. I shall not comment on that, apart from noting that my colleague the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) nearly fell off his chair when that comment was made. I think that was evidence of the attitude of many people in our community. Let us get back to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. If the honourable member for Gippsland is to represent his constituents properly he ought to dwell for some moments on the comments I am about to make. It is obvious that at the recent Liberal Party Thredbo retreat a group of members of the Liberal Party sat around the fire in the evening, I suppose over a brandy or two, and tried to come up with some policies. What did they come up with?
—Nothing.

—In a word, nothing. I thank the honourable member for Bendigo for his assistance. In fact they did come up with a couple of suggestions, amongst which was the selling off of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.
—Stick to the Bill.
—Order! The House will come to order. I ask the honourable member for Maribyrnong to keep to the Bill at hand and I ask the honourable member for Gippsland to cease interjecting.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I am addressing myself to the Bill before the House. In fact, I was commenting on why the Opposition came to this ludicrous decision to sell off the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. If the honourable member for Gippsland endorses in its totality the role of the Commonwealth Bank, as he has done, and particularly its historical role in country Australia, he ought to show the intestinal fortitude to address his comments to the views of the Liberal component of this discredited Opposition because, in a word, the Liberals want to sell it off. Earlier this evening the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) tried to manoeuvre his way out of that position, as well he might have, but of course on 14 April this year the Liberal Party put out a Press release and I draw the attention of the House to a small component of that release. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A Coalition government would dispose of those commercial enterprises or their assets wholly or partly owned by the Government . . .
It goes on to say, mentioning the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and many others :
This examination will include an assessment of the desirability and feasibility of the disposal of the whole or part of the Government's interest in such enterprises.
The backpedalling tonight on this issue of the honourable member for Bennelong reminded me very much indeed-
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well might Opposition members interject because this will be a major issue at the next election. They want to sell the great Australian institutions to their corporate mates. Well might the honourable member for Bennelong be in retreat tonight, talking about 20 per cent only. Would that 20 per cent go to ordinary Australians? Of course not. Mr Twenty Per Cent would hock the assets of this great Australian institution to his mates. If we go back in history we will find that that is what happened previously. We heard earlier tonight that the Commonwealth oil refineries were sold holus bolus to the corporate mates of honourable members opposite. Let us dwell for a moment on why the Opposition went into retreat on this issue. Amongst other things, it did so because of a couple of editorials from which I will quote. The Sunday Mail of 15 April stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Nor will the conservative parties win votes by offering to sell . . . the Commonwealth Bank.
The West Australian of 16 April, in describing the policy as unimaginative and stale, stated:
. . . the coalition could have been expected to produce a few more fresh ideas.

That is certainly a view endorsed by the overwhelming majority of the Australian community. That is not all it would do. It would not hock only the Commonwealth Bank and in so doing abrogate its responsibilities to country Australians, those who have benefited over very many years indeed from this great Australian institution. Of course, I do not need to remind the House that this great Australian institution was established by the Labor Party. The National Party member for Gippsland spent a great deal of time-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is too young.

—He may not be aware of that as he is too young. I notice that the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) is here. Perhaps the honourable member for Franklin will address himself to the next question. The Liberal Party also wants to sell the Australian National Line. What will that do for Tasmania? I will tell the House what it will do for Tasmania.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. Apart from being quite untrue, the honourable member's comments are not relevant to the Bill. The Australian National Line is not mentioned in this Bill.
— Order! I accept the point of order. I ask the honourable member for Maribyrnong to restrict his comments to the Bill under discussion at the moment.

—There is a well known and long-standing relationship between the Commonwealth Bank and Telecom Australia. I ask the Opposition to state what it intends to do with Telecom. What will happen to country consumers if Telecom is sold off?
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I believe a grave insult has been delivered to the Chair in the last few moments.
—Is the honourable member for Gippsland raising a point of order?
—Yes, Madam Deputy Speaker. The point of order is that he honourable member for Maribyrnong-
—There is no point of order.

—When the honourable member for Bennelong backpedalled so rapidly on this issue tonight I was reminded of a meeting I had many years ago with a gentleman who was describing to me the history of the attacks on Darwin during the Second World War. I said to him: 'You were in Darwin at that time?' He said: 'Yes, I was there for a short while. Shortly after that I was in Tennant Creek'. I said to him: 'How did you get to Tennant Creek?' He said: 'On my bicycle'. I said: 'How long did it take you to get to Tennant Creek on your bicycle?' He said: 'Three days'. I said: 'Three days! That was doing it all right'. He said: 'Well, as a matter of fact it didn't even have a chain on it'. He moved so quickly in the face of adversity that I was reminded of that instance listening to the honourable member for Bennelong tonight. He is the latter day equivalent. There are many complex issues relating to this-
—And you have not addressed any of them.
—The honourable member for Gippsland inspires me to comment again.
—Will you give us a signal when to laugh at that?
—The honourable member for Maribyrnong is the only member in this House who has the call. Would others please be quiet.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Gippsland, in his rhetorical flourish, has inspired me to comment once again on the implications for country Australians of the selling off of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The implications are quite clear. Those constituents whom the honourable member for Gippsland would profess to represent in this House would be quite significantly disadvantaged, because the Commonwealth Bank of Australia has a long history indeed of directing most of its attention, or a good part of its attention, to the benefit of country Australians. I hope that the honourable member for Gippsland will show the intestinal fortitude to consult with some of his Liberal Party colleagues this evening and to impress upon them the undesirability of hawking off this great Australian institution to the Liberal Party supporters.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague, the honourable member for Bendigo, of course is well aware of the implications of this for country Australians. I know that he has pressed very strongly that this Australian institution not be sold off but that its role for country Australians be enhanced so that he can better represent the electorate of Bendigo. He ought to be given credit for that. The Opposition ought to remember one thing about this issue: It ought to get with the strength and continually support the Government's policies because they have been proven to be successful. To use the Commonwealth Bank term, it should 'get with the strength'. But it should also do something else: It should never forget that the elephant never forgets and that any party that goes to the Australian community with these sorts of policies, particularly a policy that would sell down the drain this great Australian institution, will receive a response from the Australian community that will resound very long in its ears after the next election, whenever that may be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Groom The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I use the occasion of speaking on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill to refer to a great member of the Australian Labor Party. I am not speaking about the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths). He said that he would not want to live in Gippsland. The people there would not want him. The man I want to speak about tonight is the great King O'Malley who formerly represented the seat that I now represent, which was then called Darwin .
—A great Australian.

—He was a great Australian and a great character, one of the great characters produced in this House. He was the driving force which established the first Commonwealth Bank in 1912. He had a lot of opposition in those days. There were splits in the Labor Party then as there are now. Many people within the Labor Party worked against King O'Malley and did not believe that his idea was worthwhile. But through his strength of character and perseverance he fought Fisher; he fought Hughes, who was involved in those days; and he fought other colleagues. He finished up getting this great Commonwealth Bank established. He was always proud of the Bank. It was almost an obsession with him. When the doors of the Bank first opened in July 1912, Fisher was the first man to deposit funds. The second depositor was the notorious John Wren. The third depositor was King O'Malley. He was a very interesting character. He was a true troglodyte because he actually lived in a cave for two years. I think that some honourable members opposite should try the same trick.
—At Thredbo.
—The honourable member mentioned Thredbo. His comments on Thredbo were quite dishonest. I think the Australian Labor Party is playing dirty tricks.
—Would you like to read the release?

—Yes, I would like to read the honourable member's release. I am sure it is quite dishonest as his comments were quite dishonest. The Thredbo weekend was a working weekend. Frankly, the Liberal Party of Australia is very proud of what was achieved at Thredbo. The thrust which commenced at Thredbo-
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member is not addressing his comments to the Bill. Could you bring him back to it?
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Braddon.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I am addressing my remarks to the subject matter of the Bill because I am going to get on to something that the honourable member for Maribyrnong mentioned earlier. The thrust which was developed at Thredbo will take the Liberal Party on to victory at the next election. I know that the Labor Party is worried about what has been achieved. We have seen this in the House this week. The Labor Party and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have been worried about the enthusiasm on this side of the House. There is certainly plenty of it now. We are full of confidence and running for victory at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members have mentioned the policy of the Liberal Party. They have distorted that policy. We have not made any announcement that in office we would sell the Commonwealth Bank. In fact, what we have said-I make it quite clear to the House-is that there would be an inquiry into the Bank to see whether it is serving the public interest. We will look at the role of the Bank, the Government involvement in the Bank and will see how the Bank and its organisation might be improved. What is wrong with that kind of inquiry? That is part of the policy. We are looking at this question of privatisation which is very important. We believe in private enterprise. We believe it is a more efficient system than Government enterprise. We are not going to go off half cocked about this. We would look at the facts and have a proper thoughtful inquiry to see what might be done. I mentioned King O'Malley and what a great character he was. He was a very unusual character. I want to mention some of the great members we have had from Tasmania: The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck). There are many similarities.
