He is another great Tasmanian and a great fighter for Tasmania as O'Malley was and a Labor man and I give him credit for that. That is not the honourable member for Franklin. He is a true Liberal, but, as I say, he is a great character too. The honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman) is also a great character and great fighter for Tasmania. I take this occasion to mention the fact that I will not be standing at the next election. There are personal family reasons for that. One of the great regrets I have is that I will not continue to be a part of this team of Newman, Goodluck and our other colleagues who have fought so hard for Tasmania in this House.
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Government members to cease interjecting. The speech of the honourable member for Braddon is very interesting, but I hope he will come to the point of the Bill.

—I want to talk about two particular matters: I refer to the 1983 annual report of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. Page 15 the report mentions the Bank's involvement in lending for housing. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The CSB's housing loan approvals for 1982/83 reached a record level of $1,285 million, an increase of 29 per cent over the previous record achieved in 1981/82 .

This lending represents 35 per cent of the total housing loan approvals by all savings banks and underlines the CSB's pre-eminent position as the largest lender for housing in Australia. The total amount outstanding in CSB housing loans at 30 June 1983 was $5,050 million.
Housing loan interest rates were reduced by up to 1 per cent pa during the year .
That is very good.
At 30 June 1983 the predominant CSB interest rate for housing was 12.5 per cent pa.

This is a very important subject. I just want to make one particular point about housing interest rates. I know it is a matter of some concern to people who have borrowed funds to purchase or build a home. We have had a system in Australia over the years whereby we have had fixed rates of interest, or at least they have been fixed for a period. Let us look at the Commonwealth Bank's own practice. Between 1946 and 1963 housing interest rates tended to be fixed for a 10-year period. At the end of the 10-year period they would be reviewed and would be fixed for a further period which would normally be a further 10 years. Between 1963 and 1965 loans were fixed for five years. Between 1965 and 1969 the interest rate on loans was fixed for three years. The period has been reducing as time has gone on. More recently, of course, the housing loan interest rate has been adjusting from time to time as market rates have changed. So people may have ups and downs in the rate of interest they are paying on their house.

In recent times, interest rates have been very high. This has made it very difficult for people purchasing a house. The sad fact is that so many people are not able to reduce the amount of capital they borrow. It may be that for half of the period of the loan all they are doing is repaying interest and not capital. Many people have come into my office most surprised when, having had a housing loan for perhaps 15 years and believing they had paid off a fair bit of the capital, they are told by the bank-perhaps the Commonwealth Bank, another bank or a building society-that they have reduced their capital by only $10 a year. In a sense, those people are just paying rent on their houses. This is a very sad fact. Perhaps there is no simple answer to it. It is a pity that we cannot go back to a system whereby interest rates are fixed for a longer period so that people have a chance to get ahead by reducing the amount of money they have borrowed.

There is not much time available in this debate. I do not want to go on at length, but I make the point that we have had a boom in housing commencements in recent times. This has been very good to see. I believe there is a real danger involved here. Some of the expert commentators are seeing the danger and are making comments about it in the daily Press. When there is a boom and a large number of new homes are being built, that boom starts to eat into future demand. The demand is a set factor basically which varies, of course, because of population growth and so on. But if we suddenly build a whole lot of houses this year-more than one would expect to build this year-it will eat into the demand that might be created for next year and the year after.

I say to the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), who is in the chamber at present, that he has to watch this. He does not want to get carried away with these housing commencement figures. If we look at the history of housing we will see that Ministers suddenly become carried away with housing commencements and say: 'This is great; the number is up'. We have a wonderful record for 12 months or so and then the bust comes. I warn the Minister and the Government that because of the way the figures are going now we are heading into a bust. That bust might be 12 months or so away. The Minister and the Government have to look very carefully at their policies to ensure that these boom conditions do not continue to the point where they create a major bust. That would be disastrous for the housing industry, particularly because the housing industry has always said-I am sure that the honourable member for Bass, who was at one time a Minister responsible for housing, would agree-that it wants a steady flow of business. If the housing industry has a steady flow of business it is able to best organise its affairs.

I wish to make a couple of other points. Generally we believe the Bill is a fair Bill. It contains a number of provisions which, in a bipartisan manner, this side is prepared to support. It is a pity that we do not have the same sort of bipartisan support from the Government side in other areas of policy. This bipartisan approach is breaking down in a number of areas. The consensus about which the Government and the Prime Minister have spoken is breaking down as a result of the attitude and the comments being made on the Government side. I finish by saying that the Opposition supports the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously as there are only five minutes left in this debate I will not be able to say much. I begin by making an observation that, in listening to this debate on the Commonwealth Banks Amendment Bill, it is amusing to see the sorts of cleavages which exist in the Opposition coalition between the rural agrarians and demagogue populists and the free marketeers in the Liberal Party wing. Earlier we had the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) lamenting the fact that capital was to be transferred from the Commonwealth Development Bank to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, as it will now be called, on the ground that it might conceivably impose some interest penalty on rural borrowers. I simply say that if he thinks that is the case, if he thinks that will be a consequence of that capital transfer, the logical thing to do, if he is to follow the line of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who is a fan of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, would be to have a direct budgetary subsidy to assist people as far as interest repayments are concerned. Of course, that is not what he would advocate for a second. He would prefer to preserve the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and its constituent banks with a totally unrealistic capital structure, with a gearing ratio of 7:1 for the overseas operations of the Commonwealth Trading Bank and unrealistically high level of capitalisation for the Commonwealth Development Bank.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the threat to the Commonwealth Bank is a real one. We had some discussion earlier about the nature of the Opposition's proposals in regard to it. In considering that I think it is necessary to look at what the Campbell report had to say. It would be true to say that those who are the key determiners of economic thinking within the Opposition ranks-not the rural demagogues-are epitomised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Without any great shadow of doubt, they would favour the sort of course advocated in the Campbell report. That involves, among other things, the absorption of the Commonwealth Development Bank into the normal Commonwealth Trading Bank and ultimately, in a totally deregulated environment, the selling off of the Commonwealth Bank to the private sector. I see the Deputy Leader of the Opposition nodding his head in agreement, so I think the fears that have been expressed are real and genuine.
As far as the Campbell report is concerned, it proceeded from an ideological premise. The first paragraph in the report, paragraph 1.1, states:

The Committee starts from the view that the most efficient way to organise economic activity is through a competitive market system which is subject to a minimum of regulation and government intervention.

That is the starting point. That is not a conclusion arrived at by a systematic and thorough investigation of the operation of financial institutions. That is invoked as an ideological dogma in the first paragraph of the Campbell report. Flowing from that premise we have all sorts of recommendations, including the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. Again, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition confirms the fears people have about the course of Opposition policy by indicating assent to that.

It is worth noting that, notwithstanding Campbell's advocacy of the ultimate privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank, he is prepared to concede in various parts that there are considerations other than the efficient operation of a financial system. There are much broader social objectives that might be pursued . He concedes grudgingly that one possible way of pursuing those objectives may be through the instrument of a government-controlled banking sector. The Commonwealth Banking Corporation and its constituent banks have been criticised at various times because of the inadequacy of their commercial performance, the small rate of return on the assets, et cetera. I think it is worth reminding ourselves that the charter of the Commonwealth Bank provides that its activities are to be directed in this way:
. . . to the greatest advantage of the people of Australia and have due regard for the stability and balanced development of the Australian economy.

That is an objective that it is required to pursue that is not imposed on the private banks with which it has to compete. There is no doubt that it has had a higher level of activity in the controlled sector of banking activity-the small overdrafts, the housing area-and that largely explains its relatively poor commercial performance. In weighing up these considerations we have to look at the broader social objectives that the Commonwealth Bank is seeking to pursue. I think it would be a very bad thing from the point of view of the people of Australia were it to be sold off.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Petrol: Wholesale Price-Racial Discrimination-Turkish-Armenian Conflict-Coal Industry-Medicare-Rugby Football Codes-Ayers Rock

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Hurford) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first speech in the House, apart from my maiden speech, was on the petroleum industry and I have made several subsequently. Tonight I wish to talk about a certain situation that has occurred in Hobart. It is probably occurring all over Australia. We are all conscious of the price of petrol. It is very important. We all realise that it varies from State to State, from city to city and in country areas. We have all talked about it for many years and nobody seems to be able to come up with a way of overcoming this problem. There is a maximum wholesale price-maximum is the operative word-in every capital city and it varies very little from State to State. However, unfortunately, the oil companies-I do not want to get into an argument about them or criticise them tonight-seem to be able to vary that wholesale price. Certain Labor States-I cannot blame them although some of my colleagues may not agree-have put a freeze on the wholesale price because they could not understand why there was a wholesale price. All of a sudden somebody would start selling petrol below the wholesale price in that city. I come to the point that will interest my Tasmanian colleagues. The Tasmanian people have always paid the maximum wholesale price. As a consequence, they have always paid a high retail price-
—They should get good members.

—It is not a matter of getting a good member. I am trying to be calm and pleasant about this. It is a very pleasant situation. The people in Tasmania have always paid the maximum wholesale price. Admittedly, Tasmania is only a small market. It has 400,000 good people. There is a comparison between the larger markets of Melbourne and Sydney with 3 million people. The Tasmanians have always paid a high wholesale price and the retailers have put their margin on. The price has always been higher than in other States.
—Why do they pay a high price?
—The oil companies over the years have manipulated the market. The Tasmanian people are not silly. They read. They watch television.
—Order! The honourable member for Franklin has a handsome head of hair but I would rather see him facing the Chair.

—Tasmanians make comparisons and they realise that it is costing them a lot more money. It has a flow-on effect into the economy, into transportation, et cetera. Am I talking too fast? Can everybody understand? I will keep going. It has been very important to the economy of Tasmania because it has been high but now we have a stupid situation which has thrown the market into chaos in Tasmania, particularly in Hobart, a lovely city of 200,000 people. We have two different types of service stations, leasehold and freehold. I can understand that a freehold person has probably spent a lot of money buying the premises, et cetera, so he expects something different. All the dealers in Tasmania buy at a fixed wholesale price. But the oil companies give a kickback at the end of the month to the people who own their own sites. It could amount to 4c or 5c a litre. The poor proprietors leasing their sites from the oil companies pay everything, employ people and do the normal work that one would expect them to do in a small business. A person down the road can get a kickback .

SPEECH.PARA: Then the ethics come in. I do not want to criticise him but a particular person has thrown the market into chaos in Hobart at the moment. The consumers are benefiting; they are getting cheaper petrol. Unfortunately the poor small businessmen are suffering. We all talk about small businessmen but when it comes to the crunch, when they are really up against it, we do not give them the necessary support. In Hobart all service station proprietors are finding it very difficult to survive because of this kickback. The oil companies and governments must start to realise that the pricing of petrol has become so complex in Australia. We all need to get involved. I notice the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) is calling for another inquiry-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter for the State government.

—It is not a matter for the State government. We should get involved . If we are to ask people in Australia to pay a high price for petrol because of import parity pricing, conservation, the need for more exploration, et cetera, we must have a fair petrol pricing system throughout Australia. It is useless to talk about free enterprise and other things if people have to pay unfair prices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw the attention of the House tonight to the recent statement by the Australian Council for Civil Liberties which calls on all members of this Parliament to observe the policies contained in the United Nations Conventions on racism. The Australian Council for Civil Liberties has adopted, as one would expect, the statements in the preamble of the International Covenant on the Elimination of All Forms of Racism which condemns the concept of racial superiority as scientifically false, morally condemnable, socially unjust and dangerous. It is important that all members of this Parliament who supported the passage of the Racial Discrimination Act and expressed their opposition to racism remember those sentiments in the context of the current debates occurring in this Parliament on issues of immigration policy and Aboriginal affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to remember that section 9 of the Federal Racial Discrimination Act states that distinctions in dealing with individuals based on race, colour, descent or national origin offend against the Act. The Australian Council for Civil Liberties has called on all members of this Parliament to observe these statements of national and international policy when considering the current calls for new criteria of skin colour and facial features in the area of immigration law. The Australian Council for Civil Liberties has also called on members of the Parliament to condemn the advocates of racial superiority and to protect the Australian community from the threat of communal disruption.

At a time when some would have the debate turn upon whether Australia should follow what they believe to be a European way of life, it is well to remember that there are legally enforceable laws against racial discrimination in Europe. All the signatories to the European Convention on Human Rights are bound by an anti-discrimination provision in Article 14 which states:

The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language , religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status.

I believe that those statements of human rights are as valid in this country as they are in Europe and would be well remembered by members of the Opposition in the context of current debates. While speaking on the subject of anti- discrimination law and practice in this country I would like to take the opportunity to highlight what I believe to be certain deficiencies in the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act. I believe that that Act is an outstanding piece of legislation which was supported in this Parliament not only by the Australian Labor Party but also by all members of Parliament. I hope that members of the Opposition share the view that it is not good enough just to enact legislation which expresses pious provisions in opposition to discrimination if that legislation is not properly administered in the interests of all Australians. I address my comments sincerely in a bipartisan manner.

It is my very great concern that the Federal Racial Discrimination Act, while appearing at face value to be legislation that is working, in substance amounts to legislation which for all practical purposes is a toothless tiger. The great emphasis in the legislation is on the process of conciliation. I think all of us would support the need to conciliate allegations of racial discrimination. But there comes a time when the process of conciliation indeed ought to be put aside and that if racial discrimination is perpetuated there ought to be legally enforceable rights in the courts. My concern is that under the Federal Racial Discrimination Act there is not a ready right of access to the courts, and that before a complainant under the Act can bring an action before the court, what is required is a certificate from the Commissioner for Community Relations pursuant to the terms of that Act. It is my concern that those certificates, throughout the nine years of the operation of the Act, have been issued only on very rare occasions. That means that the Human Rights Commission is increasingly seen by ethnic minorities and by Aboriginal people in this country as an apologist for racism. Those are very stern and sincerely directed criticisms. I hope that all of us will give consideration to those enforcement provisions in the Racial Discrimination Act because, in my opinion, the Act is a toothless tiger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The annual report of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation says that within the Australian community groups that are likely to employ violent means to achieve their political aims include Armenian terrorist groups. It goes on to say that the major threat currently is from the activities and intentions of supporters of Armenian terrorism in Australia. It notes the murder in 1980 of the Turkish Consul General and his bodyguard. All of us condemn terrorism because terrorism is murder. It is as simple as that. When a terrorist kills, he murders. But we need to know something about the Armenians and we need, as well, to understand what this organisation is really saying. The Armenians, indisputably, were the victims of the first genocide of the twentieth century. It happened in Turkey in 1915. Hundreds of thousands of people were killed, not by chance, not by disease, but as a result of deliberate policy. One can refer to any standard reference work. For example, the World Book Encyclopaedia states:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1894, the Turks began a campaign to wipe out the Armenians. The campaign reached a peak during World War I. By 1918, about 1,800,000 Armenians had been murdered and thousands more had fled to other countries.
The Encyclopaedia Britannica, on the same subject, states:

In 1915 the Young Turk government, regarding the Turkish Armenians, despite pledges of loyalty, as a dangerous foreign element with friends among the enemies who had launched the Dardanelles campaign and with cousins in the Russian army on their eastern front, resolved to deport the whole Armenian population of about 1,750,000 to Syria and Mesopotamia. It was a deportation of an entire people.
It continues:

The chances of survival in these ill-prepared desert regions were slight: it was a death sentence, a 'final solution' that Adolf Hitler was to emulate consciously in Germany. It is estimated that about 600,000 Armenians died or were massacred en route.

The Turkish Government has never admitted guilt. It has never offered amends. It has never sought to give reparation to the Armenian people. It has sought to bury the Armenian question as though the acts, the atrocities and the crimes had never happened. Terrorism is a blight on the face of the latter part of the twentieth century. It is one of the most dangerous problems we have to face, because it is so easy for a group to get hold of machine guns, to murder, bomb, kidnap and inflict immense misery in the pursuit of political aims. But the bald statement in the report casts a slur, it seems to me, upon the entire Armenian community in Australia.

I know the Armenian community in Sydney well. They are a fine and a proud people. Certainly, they are embittered by the actions of the past. But nothing that I have ever learnt suggests to me that they would in any way be involved in organised terrorism within this country. So all honourable members who read the report should bear in mind how easy it is for government departments to make generalised statements about particular groups without identifying those groups, without our knowing whether they exist in Australia, and without our being able to be sure as to whether that department may not be wholly wrong, and for such a slur, such a comment, to infect our view of the entire people. They are a fine people. They have done a great deal for this country. I certainly hope that they do not think that what is said in that report is a reflection on them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members would have this week received a letter from Utah Development Co. and a Press release attempting to justify its action for the recent damage it did to the Australian coal export industry. We were told in the release that it was Utah's view that its action was in the long term interests of Australia. That is rubbish. Its action damaged the Australian coal industry. It will cost this country millions of dollars and up to 1,000 jobs. Some long term interest! In a debate in this chamber the Opposition, which for years vandalised the Australian coal industry, tried to put the blame for this on the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is one of the few countries in the world without a national energy plan and direct public participation in resource development. Australia has been considered a pushover by energy multinationals. The events of the past few weeks have demonstrated the need for the Federal Government to intervene in price and tonnage negotiations, particularly when dealing with our major overseas customers. The queue of Australian companies lining up to deal with centralised Japanese customers and undercutting each other is a source of embarrassment and has done enormous harm to the Australian coal industry.

In addition, we have often been told by our conservative counterparts that we must be more competitive with coal producers in other countries. However, it must be pointed out that in many cases the same multinationals are involved in different countries. The Australian coal industry is highly productive and is a reliable supplier to world markets, but we must remove some of the uncertainty from the marketing of Australian coal. We need better guarantees of long term contracts with major customers before committing large funds to expanding industrial infrastructure for resource development projects.

We hear much about the oversupply of Australian coal. 'It is a buyer's market', we are told. I believe that with a proper marketing authority a deal could have been done in recent negotiations relating to coking coal and steaming coal, thus maintaining the price of both. Be that as it may, we have to ask why we have an oversupply situation. Some years ago the Japanese estimated their coal requirements. I believe they deliberately overestimated their requirements, and because we have no rational development plan for coal production in this country the producers trampled each other, with the support of the conservative Federal Government and indeed some State governments, to get into production. The Japanese must have laughed all the way to their banks, and they are still laughing on the way to their banks as they take Australian coal producers to the cleaners.

I believe that for the future of the Australian coal industry there must be rational marketing through a marketing authority, comprising producers, unions and government. The sale of Australian coal is too important to Australian jobs and too important to the Australian economy to be left in the hands of the producers only. They have shown that they are not up to the job. I believe it is essential that to have a rational marketing authority we must have a team comprising producers, union representatives and government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments in connection with the address made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis). I say to the honourable member that the multinational company in question is no longer a multinational; Utah Development Ltd is Australian owned under Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. The comments the honourable member made are just the normal rash statements that are made by certain people from another State about the state of the industry in Queensland. The honourable member talked about the centralist Japanese control of buying. The Japanese are also competing on the world market with countries such as Pakistan and the countries of Europe. I suggest to the honourable member that he look at the Pakistani deal before he makes incorrect statements, as he did tonight, for a parish pump purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer tonight to two matters relating to health. One is in connection with Medicare. I will seek the advice of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) on this matter when he returns. Cases such as the one I wish to discuss will happen right across Australia more frequently than they have in the past. Two cases involving caesarean birth were referred to me by people in my electorate. The case I want to talk about involves a distraught mother who was recently discharged from a private hospital, having given birth by caesarean section. She needed specialist attention. Her family had been fully covered for medical and hospital expenses under the old insurance scheme. They had to drop that insurance-they had no option-and they had to join the Medicare scheme on 1 February of this year.

So what happened? On returning home from the hospital she made her claims and found out to her regret and to her loss that the specialist's fees, which had been charged at the approved Australian Medical Association rates, were not the same as the schedule fees set by the Government at greatly reduced values. She discovered that the 85 per cent refund of the schedule fee went nowhere towards the recovery of the actual cost. As a result, that family is hundreds of dollars out of pocket. In that case the insurance cover was taken out when the person was employed. The family now no longer has a breadwinner. That person was retrenched and there is no income coming in. The advice I seek from the Minister in this regard is, what does a family do in such circumstances?

The second matter I raise tonight concerns sports health. Over the last few years, I have been privileged to participate in and view the great rugby codes, Rugby League and Rugby Union. There have been certain similarities in their play . Over the last few years there has been an improvement in the standards of play which I think has encouraged a better aspect as far as injury is concerned. I refer to the ball changeover after the sixth tackle in league. The scrums, particularly in Union, are well balanced. Perhaps that could be brought over into the game of League. A fairer scoring pattern has been adopted in League in the last two seasons, particularly in regard to scrum infringements. There is no shot at penalty goal. The points for a try in League are now four as against three previously. Touch football has taken on the good aspects of football in that touch ball, although I will not say it is a great spectator sport, is a sport in which people can participate to the extent they desire. It is available not only to men but also to women. Women can play the game in a reduced numbers team but without tackles or kicking. They seem to enjoy the game and it is taking on in Australia.

Last night, after having left this place, I witnessed the 10.30 p.m. replay of the Rugby League match between New South Wales Country and Western Suburbs. A problem with the game still exists. That is the unfairness in a play of an up- and-under within the quarter of the defending team. I did not see any injury last night. But if one considers the record, one will find that the greatest risk of injury in League comes about through the up-and-under where the try could be scored as a result of chance and not of skill. I believe that medical records indicate that the greatest percentage of injuries comes about from that. I suggest that the two rugby codes adopt the touch football rule whereby if there is an up-and-under kick within the defence quarter, it will result in a changeover of the ball and no chance of a score from it or that the points for a drop goal in League be increased from one to two points--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired, and he has confused two Victorians in the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reeves Mr J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — In the short time I have available I would like to speak about what can be achieved by a little rational discussion. The Aboriginal people at Ayers Rock have put a blanket ban on filming of the Ayers Rock area. This morning, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) discussed the matter with representatives of the Aboriginal people. I am pleased to say that, as a result of that discussion, they cleared up some confusion that was apparently in the minds of the Aboriginal people about the issue. It seems that, as a result of those discussions, we can reasonably expect the blanket ban to be lifted and the whole issue sorted out by Monday.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on the issue of Ayers Rock, I want to talk about the old motel buildings at Ayers Rock. A number of old motel buildings there were bought by the Commonwealth Government some years ago. It was planned that they would be demolished after the Yulara complex was completed. This was to be done for environmental reasons, because of erosion and because they are an eyesore. The Aboriginal people wanted to retain some of those buildings to use for an arts and crafts centre, a store, a shop and so on. Frankly, I think the best solution is that the buildings should be demolished because they are an eyesore. But I cannot see why a store that blended in with the environment at Ayers Rock could not be built for the Aboriginal people so that they could sell their arts and crafts to the tourists visiting Ayers Rock and partake in the tourist industry along with the other residents of the area. I note that a new ranger station has recently been constructed at Ayers Rock which blends in well with the environment. I think that sort of building would achieve the purpose of the Aboriginal people. I think the old motels there should be removed because, as I said, they are an eyesore.

I wish to refer to the issue concerning the control and management of Ayers Rock and Uluru National Park that has arisen since the decision of the Government to transfer the lease to the traditional owners. I believe that the bottom line is that the Government should have the ultimate control over the management of a national park. I do not see why Aboriginal people in the area should not play a part in any decision-making process affecting the rock along with representatives from the tourist industry, the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal Development Commission: Arts Conference in Townsville

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Aboriginal Development Commission hold an arts conference in Townsville between 29 and 31 August 1983; if so (a) what was the total cost of the conference and (b) what amount was spent on travel expenses.
(2) Was the conference funded by his Department and the Aboriginal Development Commission; if so, what amount was funded.

(3) With regard to the conference (a) what was its purpose, (b) what is the status of the report and any resolutions, (c) will he table a copy of the report and recommendations, (d) how many people participated, (e) what were the criteria for selection of the participants and (f) is he able to give the name and designation of each participant; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) and (b) Yes. The total amount provided for the conference was $41,041, of which $38,720 was spent on travel.
(2) Yes. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs provided $20,000, and the balance was funded by the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC).
(3) (a) The purpose of the conference was to discuss major contemporary issues of Aboriginal art and culture and to identify possible future problem areas.
(b) The conference was convened by the ADC and the status of the recommendations is derived from the broad basis of Aboriginal Arts and crafts representation.
As such I have indicated a willingness to consider those recommendations which relate to a need for Government action, after consultation with the National Aboriginal Conference.
(c) A copy of the resolutions has been provided to the honourable member.
(d) Between 60 and 65 people attended, of whom 46 were invited participants. The remainder were local people attending as observers.
(e) Participants were invited on the basis of regional representation and to ensure a representative range of artistic endeavour. Because of budget restrictions only 50 people could be invited.
(f) A list of names and designations of participants has been provided to the honourable member.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Justice Hope report in 1977 that the Australian Secret Intelligence Service needed the right to break and enter embassies, steal documents, support underground resistance movements, fund unions and rescue political prisoners.
(2) Was forced entry of a United States embassy in Iran condemned by Australia.

(3) Is he able to say whether certain Australians, a United States President and certain United States law officers have been sacked from public office for stealing documents or condoning related illegal actions.

(4) Is he able to say whether underground resistance movements are distinguishable at law from terrorist organisations, or is the distinction determined essentially by the political preference of the describer.
(5) What steps has the Government taken to ensure that its officers conform with international law.
(6) Will he publicly disown suggestions that Australians should use illegal means of collecting information.

(7) How does Australia's spending (a) in 1982-83 and (b) seven years previously , on peace-building, peace-keeping and peace-making compare with our expenditure on secret intelligence gathering in the same years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (5) and (6) In accordance with the well-established and bi-partisan practice followed by successive Australian governments, I do not intend to comment on the matters raised in these questions beyond noting that the activities and effectiveness of Australia's security and intelligence organisations are currently being reviewed by the Royal Commission on Australia' s Security and Intelligence Agencies.
(2) Australia and many other governments condemned the seizure of the United States Embassy in Tehran and the holding hostage of its staff.
(3) I would require details of the specific cases referred to before wishing to offer any comment.
(4) I agree that distinction between the two groups is not always easy to draw, legally or otherwise.

(7) Although it would be difficult to arrive at precise figures, not least because of the difficulties of definition involved, expenditure on foreign intelligence collection in the periods mentioned would amount to only a fraction of the expenditure by Australia on a wide range of undertakings, bilateral and multilateral, through the United Nations and otherwise, that contribute to the maintenance of peace and the peaceful settlement of disputes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 30 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say during what periods the International Red Cross has (a) been excluded from East Timor or (b) voluntarily withdrawn because of restrictions on its activities by Indonesian authorities; if so, what are the details.
(2) What representations has Australia made to help resolve this grave situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) relief activities in East Timor commenced in 1979. Relief operations on the main island of East Timor were suspended in July 1983 as a result of restrictions placed on the movement of ICRC delegates by the Indonesian authorites. However, the ICRC's family reunion, tracing and mailing activities, and its relief program on Atauro Island, have continued uninterrupted.

(2) As a major contributor to ICRC operations in East Timor, the Australian Government was naturally concerned by the restrictions placed on ICRC relief operations on the main island. The Government's concerns were made known to the Indonesian authorities last November and were reiterated on a number of subsequent occasions.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation: Reasons for Withdrawal of United States

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the United States Government informed the Australian Government of the reasons for the United States' decision to withdraw from the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation; if so, what are the United States' principal grievances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The United States Secretary of State, Hon. George Shultz, wrote to me on 27 December 1983 concerning the United States' decision to give notification of withdrawal from UNESCO. The principal concerns relate to the degree of politicisation in UNESCO and perceived inadequacies in the organisation's management and budget practices. A full explanation of the United States' decision is contained in the letter which the Secretary of State sent to the Director-General of UNESCO conveying notification of withdrawal. This letter is now a public document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 4 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Asian Wall Street Journal of 12 March 1984 stating that there is hard evidence that in 1982 the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Vietnam had decided to embark on a large agricultural program to grow opium to cover its debts; if so, can he say whether (a) any credence should be placed in the article, (b) the information is contained in a Document, 11TT/SN, signed by Ly Xi Po, Assistant Director of Agriculture for the Dong Van district, dated 10 October 1982, (c) the northern provinces of Ha Tuyen, Lai Chau, Haong Lien Son, Cao Bang and Lang Son are included in the program and (d) the purpose of this official production program of opium is for introduction of heroin on a large scale into the international illicit drug market.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The article in the Asian Wall Street Journal of 12 March 1984 on Vietnam's opium production contains a mixture of fact and unproven, and in some cases incorrect, allegations. My responses to the honourable member's specific questions are as follows:

(a) While some of the description of the situation given in the article appears authentic, other aspects do not and the overall theme of the article is misleading. The article does not therefore merit much credence.

(b) There is no reason to doubt that a document may exist which is designated 11TT/SN and is signed by Ly Xi Po, Assistant Director of Agriculture for the Dong Van district, nor that the document is dated 10 October 1982. There is no apparent cause for the article to describe such a document as 'smuggled'.

(c) The northern Vietnamese provinces of Ha Tuyen, Lai Chau, Hoang Lien Son, Cao Bang and Lang Son may well be included in an official Vietnamese program to grow opium: Like Australia, Vietnam has a declared legal opium growing industry, which is concentrated for climate reasons in its northern provinces. It is not in any way secret.
(d) There is no reason to believe that the purpose of this program would be to introduce heroin into the international illegal drug market.

As with other agricultural industries in Vietnam, opium marketing is on the basis of a contract system under which farmers provide a quota of their crops, set by the Government, to the authorities, and keep any surplus (it is probable that government supervision of the disposal of any such surpluses is particular close in the case of opium). The existence of a government document setting out quotas for opium is therefore routine.

The opium supplied to the government for the Vietnamese industry is exported mainly to the Soviet Union and East European countries for the legal production of codeine, morphine and other derivatives. There is no proof offered in the article that the existence of a government quota-setting document 'points to an official government program for the production of illegal drugs that can only be aimed at the international market'.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Use of Chemical Weapons Against Iranians

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to the opinion of Belgian toxicologist, Professor Aubin Heyndrickx, that chemical weapons used against the Iranians came from the Soviet Union; if so, is he able to say whether (a) there is any evidence to confirm the opinion, (b) the opinion is based on tests conducted on Iranian soldiers by Professor Heyndrickx, (c) the chemical compounds found in these tests do not exist in the West, (d) mustard gas and mycotoxins have been used in combination and (e) this combination is the same as or similar to the analysis of yellow rain by US scientists who claim that Vietnam has used chemical warfare in South East Asia and Afghanistan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of reports, notably in the Wall Street Journal of 13 March, quoting the Belgian toxicologist, Professor Aubin Heyndrickx, to the effect that he has found mycotoxins, as well as mustard gas, on Iranian soldiers flown to Europe for treatment and that he believes that the Soviet Union must be the source of these mycotoxins.

(a) Professor Heyndrickx has not published the detailed results of his analyses , although he reports that they have been confirmed by a Swedish laboratory; nor has he described his analytical methods. I therefore cannot comment on Professor Heyndrickx's findings. I know of no evidence from other sources to support the finding of mycotoxins in patients from Iran. Nor am I aware of any evidence which links the Soviet Union with the supply of chemical weapons used against Iranian troops.
(b) Professor Heyndrickx says that his findings are based on tests he conducted on Iranian soldiers in a hospital in Vienna.

(c) In the reports I have seen, Professor Heyndrickx does not seem to have said that mustard gas or mycotoxins do not exist 'in the West' (mycotoxins have in fact been found in nature in many countries, including countries in North America and Europe). Rather Professor Heyndrickx's point seems to have been that there is little experience 'in the West' in the medical treatment of mycotoxin poisoning. The apparent implication is that Professor Heyndrickx thinks there may be more experience elsewhere, presumably in the Soviet Union. This is a matter for conjecture on which I have no information. There are reports of outbreaks of mycotoxin poisoning from natural causes in the Soviet Union in the 1940s.

(d) I do not know whether mustard gas and mycotoxins have been used in combination anywhere. For what it may be worth as negative evidence, a sample of mustard gas collected by the United Nations team of experts which visited Iran in mid-March was analysed for mycotoxins at a Swiss laboratory: the test, designed to find concentrations as small as five parts per million, was negative .

(e) United States allegations of chemical warfare in South East Asia and Afghanistan relate to mycotoxins but not, as far as I know, to mustard gas. Please also see my reply to your question No. 751 of 16 November 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 April 1984:

(2) What was the cost of each advertisement.
(3) When and where did each advertisement appear.
(4) What are the names of the advertising agencies hired in preparation of these advertisements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There have been no such advertisements.
(2) Not applicable.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to vigils held in Australia and many other countries during the week 23 to 31 March 1984 to draw attention to the plight of Mr Yuri Shukhevych.

(2) Is he able to say whether (a) Mr Shukhevych is the Union of Soviet Social Socialist Republic's longest serving political prisoner, having been first confined in a Soviet prison in 1948, when aged only 14, for not denouncing his father as a traitor to the Soviet State and (b) he has served over 31 years in Soviet prison and labour camps for essentially political considerations and has experienced gross violation of his human rights.
(3) Is it a fact that Mr Shukhevych has been sponsored for immigration to Australia.

(4) Can he confirm that Australian diplomatic personnel in Moscow have endeavoured to interview Mr Shukhevych at the institution for debilitated people , Lesnaya Dacha, at a village near the Siberian city of Tomsk, where he has been required to stay in internal exile from the Ukraine under the terms of his last sentence.

(5) Will the Government approach the Government of the USSR to explore the creation of a better climate for mutual relations which would facilitate his coming to Australia with his wife and children to join relatives here.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of public demonstrations of support for Mr Shukhevych during the period mentioned.
(2) This information is essentially correct.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Australian Embassy in Moscow has written to Mr Shukhevych at his place of exile to ascertain whether he wishes to take up the sponsorship for immigration to Australia, lodged by his aunt. No reply to the Embassy's letter has yet been received.

(5) The Government considers that the existing state of bilateral relations should be adequate to enable the resolution of outstanding cases of family reunion from the Soviet Union. It is, however, a regrettable fact that the Soviet Government regards the granting to Soviet citizens of permission to emigrate as a purely internal matter in which other governments have no role. The Australian Government's capacity to exert influence is thus severely limited . The Embassy in Moscow will nonetheless continue to make representations to the Soviet authorities on this and other family reunion cases.
